('24', 0, 1, 2, 43) 1. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, BOMBAY 1
('24', 0, 2, 3, 75) July 22, 1921
('24', 0, 3, 4, 89) Mahatma Gandhi, who, on rising to speak, received an ovation, said that he had been addressing men and women everywhere in the city and he thought he would not be in a position to speak to them anything new on swadeshi.
('24', 0, 3, 5, 309) A gentleman had come to him from Lucknow who told him that something was going wrong in the United Provinces.
('24', 0, 3, 6, 419) A man had been incarcerated by Government for three days in a very dark cell for some trivial offence and was still in jail.
('24', 0, 3, 7, 544) The gentleman from Lucknow asked the speaker as to what a man in that position should do.
('24', 0, 3, 8, 634) He advised him to bear all hardships with patience.
('24', 0, 3, 9, 686) They should all create in their hearts the virtue of patience.
('24', 0, 3, 10, 749) He was not sure whether that story told by the gentleman was true or not, for it was very difficult to remain incarcerated for three days in a dark room.
('24', 0, 3, 11, 903) Of course, he had an experience of such an incident, because they had not forgotten as yet the cruelties perpetrated on Indians by foreigners in the Punjab.
('24', 0, 3, 12, 1060) Therefore the story related to him might be true.
('24', 0, 4, 13, 1110) He would again tell them that, if they did not understand their duty towards the country, they were not then right in asking for freedom.
('24', 0, 4, 14, 1248) He was going to speak to them on swadeshi that night.
('24', 0, 4, 15, 1302) There were other stories related to him by someone that there were three persons arrested by Government.
('24', 0, 4, 16, 1407) One of them was a Congress Secre tary who on being arrested by Government apologized to the Government and the remaining two also apologized.
('24', 0, 4, 17, 1549) They (the three men) had now given up the national cause and were remaining aloof from the movement.
('24', 0, 4, 18, 1650) They should feel ashamed of such action.
('24', 0, 4, 19, 1691) He would appeal to those present to be fearless as far as possible, for when their object was laudable, why should they care for the Government?
('24', 0, 4, 20, 1836) If they were not willing to undergo hardships and troubles they should give up the movement at this stage.
('24', 0, 4, 21, 1943) He, therefore, appealed to every man and women present in the hall to be ready for dukha (pain) at any time for the sake of their country.
('24', 0, 5, 22, 2082) The had opened a depot for foreign made clothes, where they could send their clothes without any hesitation.
('24', 0, 5, 23, 2191) If they did not succeed in boycotting foreign cloth by 31st July they would be put to great shame in the eyes of their fellow men and in the eyes of the world at large.
('24', 0, 6, 24, 2360) The Mahatma asked whether they had made any preparations for the 1st of August.
('24', 0, 6, 25, 2440) There was no shame at all in sending away their clothes to that depot for foreign made clothes.
('24', 0, 6, 26, 2536) Some bahens (sisters) when asked to boycott
('24', 0, 7, 27, 2580) their foreign made saris said that they were unwilling to do so.
('24', 0, 7, 28, 2645) No doubt there were

('24', 1, 15, 21, 4087) August and thereafter in khadi to raise their hands.
('24', 1, 15, 22, 4140) At that request nearly all present

('24', 1, 16, 24, 4207) Some women were found somewhat unwilling to raise
('24', 1, 17, 25, 4257) their hands.
('24', 1, 18, 26, 4270) The Mahatma again appealed to them to boycott foreign made clothes and
('24', 1, 19, 27, 4341) wear khaddar dress without any fear or favour.
('24', 1, 19, 28, 4388) Still he would ask them not to be led
('24', 1, 20, 29, 4426) away by any threats .
('24', 1, 21, 30, 4448) Concluding, the Mahatma said he had nothing more to speak on the swadeshi
('24', 1, 22, 31, 4522) movement, for he had been speaking constantly on the same theme for the last so
('24', 1, 23, 32, 4602) many days.
('24', 1, 23, 33, 4613) He had great faith in his countrymen and he therefore prayed to God that
('24', 1, 24, 34, 4686) the great movement he had set on foot would bear good results in the end.

('24', 2, 1, 2, 4855) 2. SPEECH AT BOMBAY MEETING 1
('24', 2, 2, 3, 4885) July 23, 1921
('24', 2, 3, 4, 4899) Mahatma Gandhi said before he commenced the proceedings of the meeting, he would read out a letter from Mr. Jayakar 2 who was laid up with fever and, therefore, had expressed his inability to attend the meeting and contribute his quota of tribute to the memory of the Lokamanya.
('24', 2, 3, 5, 5178) He then requested Mr. Lalit to recite his song about the late Lokamanya.
('24', 2, 4, 6, 5251) In addressing the meeting, the Mahatma said that the work for which they had gathered was sacred.
('24', 2, 4, 7, 5349) They had a long programme that afternoon.
('24', 2, 4, 8, 5391) He would not detain them long.
('24', 2, 5, 9, 5422) Mr. Tilak was not noted for making long speeches.
('24', 2, 5, 10, 5472) He was noted for brave deeds.
('24', 2, 5, 11, 5502) The country loved him not for his oratory.
('24', 2, 5, 12, 5545) It was possible to name some of his contemporaries who were better orators from the ornamental standpoint.
('24', 2, 5, 13, 5652) He (Mr. Gandhi) therefore did not need to detain the audience with a long speech.
('24', 2, 5, 14, 5734) He would draw their attention to some of the most marked qualities which made him the idol of the people, qualities which were so needed for the nation when it was making a supreme effort to obtain its emancipation during the year.
('24', 2, 5, 15, 5966) The truest tribute they could render to the memory of the deceased was by imitating his qualities and weaving them into their own lives.
('24', 2, 5, 16, 6103) One great quality that the country prized in the Lokamanya was his fearlessness.
('24', 2, 5, 17, 6184) It was so marked a quality in him that some even accused him of rudeness.
('24', 2, 5, 18, 6258) We know that he never spared the bureaucracy.
('24', 2, 5, 19, 6304) He therefore roused its ire and was accused of raising hatred against Englishmen.
('24', 2, 5, 20, 6386) He knew however that if Mr. Tilak was unsparing in his criticism of the bureaucracy, he was ready to give praise to its members when it was merited.
('24', 2, 5, 21, 6535) He remembered, during the last Calcutta session, which the deceased attended, Mr. Tilak presiding at a Hindi Sammelan.
('24', 2, 5, 22, 6654) He was coming from a strenuous discussion at the Congress session.
('24', 2, 5, 23, 6721) But he was able to deliver a learned extempore speech at the Sammelan.
('24', 2, 5, 24, 6792) He gave unstinted praise to English scholars for their service to the vernaculars.
('24', 2, 5, 25, 6875) He said that future historians would acknowledge their service.
('24', 2, 5, 26, 6939) That did not mean they had come to India for the purpose of benefiting the vernaculars but he said it would be unjust not to acknowledge the debt India owed to the many Englishmen who had helped them to
('24', 2, 6, 27, 7142) 1 Held at Empire Theatre, under the auspices of the Parsi Rajkiya Sabha.
('24', 2, 6, 28, 7215) Marmaduke Pickthall, Mahomed Ali and Sarojini Naidu were among those present.
('24', 2, 6, 29, 7293) A number of ladies in the audience, including Perin Captain, grand daughter of Dadabhai Naoroji, were dressed in khadi.
('24', 2, 6, 30, 7413) Money raised on admission to the function was set aside as help for the best biography of Tilak.
('24', 2, 7, 31, 7510) 2 M. R. Jayakar (1873 1959); Bombay lawyer and liberal leader, political negotiator and peace maker

('24', 3, 2, 3, 7682) The second great quality which the country needed so much was Mr. Tilaks self sacrifice.
('24', 3, 2, 4, 7771) He never stinted himself for the service of his country.
('24', 3, 2, 5, 7828) He did not bargain.
('24', 3, 2, 6, 7848) For him sacrifice of self was a pleasure.
('24', 3, 2, 7, 7890) The speaker said he did not need to give illustrations because the audience knew the examples of sacrifice better than the speaker.
('24', 3, 2, 8, 8022) The third great quality was his extreme simplicity.
('24', 3, 2, 9, 8074) Mr. Tilak had always observed swadeshi.
('24', 3, 2, 10, 8114) If khadi had been manufactured in his time he would have unhesitatingly worn it.
('24', 3, 2, 11, 8195) He could not believe him to be capable of seeking personal adornment.
('24', 3, 2, 12, 8265) He appealed to the audience to copy Mr. Tilaks swadeshi spirit.
('24', 3, 2, 13, 8329) They must not do it in a niggardly spirit.
('24', 3, 2, 14, 8372) He had heard that ladies who had done so wonderfully in June were hesitating to part with their foreign saris.
('24', 3, 2, 15, 8483) He could not forget the jewels a Parsi sister had sent at the Parsi meeting.
('24', 3, 2, 16, 8560) He wanted the ladies to continue in the same spirit about swadeshi.
('24', 3, 2, 17, 8628) If it was a difficult thing they must recall Mr. Tilaks example.
('24', 3, 2, 18, 8693) This was no time for shedding tears over their wardrobes.
('24', 3, 2, 19, 8751) He hoped that the citizens of Bombay would signalize the 1st of August by discarding all their foreign cloth and wearing khadi.
('24', 3, 2, 20, 8879) He then called upon Shrimati Sarojini Naidu to speak.

('24', 3, 3, 22, 8965) 3. MY NOTES DANGER FROM THIEVES AND ROBBERS There is always danger from thieves and robbers in Kheda district.
('24', 3, 3, 23, 9076) Such danger is there in other places, too, in greater or less degree.
('24', 3, 3, 24, 9146) Swaraj also means being able to defend ourselves.
('24', 3, 3, 25, 9196) It cannot be that others protect us and we enjoy swaraj.
('24', 3, 3, 26, 9253) The people should possess the strength to protect themselves.
('24', 3, 3, 27, 9315) Such strength may come in either of two ways.
('24', 3, 3, 28, 9361) One is to permit thieves and robbers to do their work, that is, to own no property, and the other is to use force against them.
('24', 3, 3, 29, 9489) All men are not willing to lose their belongings or to own none and so people devise means of intimidating thieves and robbers by force.
('24', 3, 3, 30, 9626) Some employ watchmen and some fight themselves.
('24', 3, 3, 31, 9674) One of the chief duties of a king is to protect his subjects from thieves and robbers.
('24', 3, 3, 32, 9761) We can enjoy swaraj only if the people take over this duty themselves.
('24', 3, 3, 33, 9832) We must, therefore, acquire this capacity.
('24', 3, 3, 34, 9875) The job is not difficult.
('24', 3, 3, 35, 9901) The residents of villages and towns should train their own volunteers and arrange for guard duty.
('24', 3, 3, 36, 9999) Every village ought to have lights.
('24', 3, 3, 37, 10035) If even this is done, the fear of thieves will largely dis appear.
('24', 3, 3, 38, 10102) But, along with this, and with greater vigour, must proceed the work of reform.
('24', 3, 3, 39, 10182) If it is important to protect oneself from a thief, it is
('24', 4, 0, 1, 10240) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 5
('24', 4, 1, 2, 10283) more important still to reclaim him.
('24', 4, 1, 3, 10320) Theft and robbery are a kind of moral disease.
('24', 4, 1, 4, 10367) We ought to have remedies for a disease.
('24', 4, 1, 5, 10408) Thieves, too, should be regarded as part of society and efforts should be made to reform them.
('24', 4, 1, 6, 10503) There is no reason to believe that they cannot be brought round, if only we meet them, explain things to them and try to educate them.
('24', 4, 1, 7, 10638) We should have patience with them and love them.
('24', 4, 1, 8, 10687) It is absolutely necessary for us to take up these two tasks.
('24', 4, 1, 9, 10749) THEFT ON RAILWAYS 1
('24', 4, 2, 10, 10769) There is no end of complaints about thefts and corruption on railways.
('24', 4, 2, 11, 10840) If all these are true, they are a matter of deep national shame, especially at a time when the whole country is passing through the fire of purification.
('24', 4, 2, 12, 10994) Government certainly have nothing to do with these malpractices; the responsibility is entirely ours.
('24', 4, 2, 13, 11096) I have even heard that a bribe must be offered in times of famine when wagons are needed for the transport of grass.
('24', 4, 2, 14, 11213) We may send anything we please by a railway parcel, but if it is at all vulnerable, its contents are bound to be tampered with.
('24', 4, 2, 15, 11341) Only recently, a Bombay merchant received a parcel of khadi through the railway and found that part of it was stolen.
('24', 4, 2, 16, 11459) If railway servants happen to see this, they will kindly consider this request of mine to have some regard for the public and to find out other and honest means of adding to their income.
('24', 4, 2, 17, 11647) It is my advice to associations of railway servants that they may lay no less stress upon their members performance of their duties than upon the vindication of their rights.
('24', 4, 2, 18, 11822) If these complaints continue to exist even under swaraj, the administration then will be as costly as it is now.
('24', 4, 2, 19, 11935) Swaraj can be maintained only where there is a majority of loyal and patriotic people to whom the good of the nation is paramount above all other considerations whatever, including their personal profit.
('24', 4, 2, 20, 12139) Swaraj means government by the many.
('24', 4, 2, 21, 12176) Where the many are immoral or selfish, their government can spell anarchy and nothing else.
('24', 4, 2, 22, 12268) I am in this movement only as I believe that the many are good and true at the bottom, but, being cowardly and careless, are ignorant of their inherent qualities, and that when once they have realized the power of goodness, they will begin to practise it and succeed in the attempt.

('24', 5, 1, 2, 12709) 4. SPEECH AT SANTA CRUZ, BOMBAY July 24, 1921
('24', 5, 2, 3, 12755) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I have come here today with a big hope in my heart.
('24', 5, 2, 4, 12829) Brother Vithaldas told me yesterday that in Bombay foreign cloth was not being collected as speedily as money had been collected and, therefore, if a good beginning was made at some place,the work would proceed vigorously and the people, too, would respond well.
('24', 5, 2, 5, 13092) In giving money, a beginning was made by Matunga but, in regard to foreign cloth, we have started with Santa Cruz in begging invitations.
('24', 5, 2, 6, 13230) I myself sought this invitation.
('24', 5, 2, 7, 13263) Why do people feel that this work is something new we have taken up?
('24', 5, 2, 8, 13332) The Congress passed the resolution on swadeshi last September.
('24', 5, 2, 9, 13395) The Khilafat Committee had accepted it even earlier.
('24', 5, 2, 10, 13448) From that time we have been propagating swadeshi jointly with Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('24', 5, 2, 11, 13531) We have spoken about it wherever we have gone.
('24', 5, 2, 12, 13578) If we succeed in securing a solution of the Khilafat problem, we shall have acquired the necessary strength for winning swaraj.
('24', 5, 2, 13, 13706) But we cannot gain that strength except through a total adoption of swadeshi.
('24', 5, 2, 14, 13784) Swadeshi has two aspects: (1) boycott of foreign cloth and (2) production of other cloth in its place.
('24', 5, 2, 15, 13887) It is my conviction that, if the mills alone produce all this cloth, India will not be able to win swaraj, or, having won it, will not be able to keep it.
('24', 5, 2, 16, 14042) Until there is a spinning wheel plying in every home in India, we shall not get swaraj.
('24', 5, 2, 17, 14130) Swadeshi, Hindu Muslim unity and peacethese three are the main planks in our movement.
('24', 5, 2, 18, 14217) This one [swadeshi] concerns all, Hindus, Muslims and Parsis.
('24', 5, 2, 19, 14279) If we had not forsaken swadeshi cloth when the East India Company came to India for trade and had not been tempted by the muslins and prints from England, our subsequent history would have been quite different.
('24', 5, 2, 20, 14490) We can now win swaraj only if we adopt swadeshi once again.
('24', 5, 2, 21, 14550) In the same manner, if we abandon Hindu Muslim unity or peace, we shall lose swaraj as well.
('24', 5, 2, 22, 14643) We have been so moulded that we are always inclined towards peace.
('24', 5, 2, 23, 14710) It is not that after we have swaraj, no one will hurt another, but even so these are the
('24', 6, 0, 1, 14799) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 7
('24', 6, 1, 2, 14842) essential conditions for winning and maintaining swaraj.
('24', 6, 1, 3, 14899) It will be quite a different matter, in my view, if other States seek to conquer India with the sword.
('24', 6, 1, 4, 15002) In any case, it cannot be denied that the bitterness between Hindus and Muslims is decreasing day by ady.
('24', 6, 1, 5, 15108) That is to say, this work [of bringing about unity between them] is proceeding and no particular effort is required for the purpose.
('24', 6, 1, 6, 15241) As regards peace, too, no fresh effort is necessary.
('24', 6, 1, 7, 15294) No sacrifice is involved in these two things.
('24', 6, 1, 8, 15340) But swadeshi certainly requires sacrifices.
('24', 6, 1, 9, 15384) We have to look after all the numerous communities with equal care.
('24', 6, 1, 10, 15452) We cannot do without the services of cobblers, carpenters or blacksmiths.
('24', 6, 1, 11, 15526) If we do not develop our strength as represented by each one of these, we shall certainly not succeed in getting swaraj.
('24', 6, 1, 12, 15647) Swadeshi cannot be brought about by the efforts of one man alone.
('24', 6, 1, 13, 15713) Money may be contributed by one person but to have one crore men and women as members of the Congress, that number of men and women are needed.
('24', 6, 1, 14, 15857) Similarly, to turn the whole country swadeshi, each and every Indian must make himself so.
('24', 6, 1, 15, 15948) For this work, thirty crores have to make sacrifices.
('24', 6, 1, 16, 16002) Everyone must boycott foreign cloth with a clear understanding of the purpose.
('24', 6, 1, 17, 16081) This was impossible a year ago.
('24', 6, 1, 18, 16113) But now if we mean to, we can ensure complete boycott as early as this August.
('24', 6, 1, 19, 16192) I have said that we can win swaraj within one month after we have ensured boycott of foreign cloth; in saying this I mean that, having done this job, we shall send an ultimatum to the Government.
('24', 6, 1, 20, 16388) We have the capacity to produce cloth, but lack faith.
('24', 6, 1, 21, 16443) The position in this matter is the same as with regard to food.
('24', 6, 1, 22, 16507) There is an oven in the house and so food is no problem.
('24', 6, 1, 23, 16564) Likewise, if there was a spinning wheel lying in the house, we would certainly work on it and by and by get used to the work.
('24', 6, 1, 24, 16690) The construction of our spinning wheel is so beautifully simple that it is quite easy to make one.
('24', 6, 1, 25, 16789) I believe we are in a position to boycott foreign cloth.
('24', 6, 1, 26, 16846) There is a magic power in the spinning wheel but, in order that this power may work, India needs to have faith.
('24', 6, 1, 27, 16958) I think, however, that India has now acquired such faith.
('24', 6, 1, 28, 17016) India s uffers from a disease.
('24', 6, 1, 29, 17047) The love of find cloth has not yet left the people.
('24', 6, 1, 30, 17099) A khadi sari is too heavy for women in India, women who observe difficult vows!
('24', 6, 1, 31, 17179) When I hear men and women say that they cannot give up fine cloth, I feel pity for them.
('24', 6, 1, 32, 17268) If people tell me this, I shall say t hat we shall not get swaraj.
('24', 6, 1, 33, 17335) If, even then, anyone offered it to us, I would decline to accept it.
('24', 6, 1, 34, 17405) I would ask him if he knew what kind of people they were to whom he offered

('24', 7, 1, 2, 17521) swaraj.
('24', 7, 1, 3, 17529) These people, I would say, have got indigestion.
('24', 7, 1, 4, 17578) We have contracted tuberculosis, there is an unnatural flush on our cheeks.

('24', 7, 4, 23, 18811) Mahatma Gandhi said that the 1st of August was nearing and they had to do their duty to their country before that date.
('24', 7, 4, 24, 18931) The witness of their duty was their own bodies; the signs of their duty and sacrifice were on their own bodies.
('24', 7, 4, 25, 19043) It would not be necessary, then, to ask anyone if he had done his duty, for the signs would be apparent to everyone.
('24', 7, 4, 26, 19160) Some people thought that by giving their quota towards the one crore already collected they had already done their duty.
('24', 7, 4, 27, 19281) They should not think so.
('24', 7, 4, 28, 19307) That fund was for the Tilak Memorial Swaraj Fund, and, as long as they had not gained swaraj, it could not be said they had done their duty to the great departed.
('24', 7, 4, 29, 19470) It was not enough to collect money; they had to get swaraj.
('24', 7, 4, 30, 19530) when they had complete swadeshi in this country, they could say they had swaraj.
('24', 7, 4, 31, 19611) He did not mean by that that on the very day they had full swadeshi they could get swaraj.

('24', 23, 5, 9, 57738) 14. DISCUSSION ON BOYCOTT AT A.I.C.C. MEETING, BOMBAY [Before July 30, 1921] 1
('24', 23, 6, 10, 57817) GANDHIJI : Where are the hopefulness and energy which we displayed when we collected a crore of rupees in the month of June?
('24', 23, 6, 11, 57942) Do we now have misgivings whether we shall succeed in bringing about boycott of foreign cloth?
('24', 23, 6, 12, 58037) Our weakness is the only cause of our fear.

('24', 23, 6, 15, 58388) If we can effect a complete boycott, only a few people will then have to court jail by offering civil disobedience or make other sacrifices.

('24', 23, 6, 17, 58608) I have with me here a number of questions about swadeshi and boycott, which I shall try to answer.
('24', 23, 7, 18, 58707) QUESTIONS.
('24', 23, 7, 19, 58718) What is wrong if we undertake not to buy any new foreign cloth henceforth and continue to wear the clothes we have till the stock is exhausted?
('24', 23, 7, 20, 58862) ANSWER.
('24', 23, 7, 21, 58870) I cannot understand how we can keep a thing after we have realized that we violate our dharma in using it.
('24', 23, 7, 22, 58977) If we violate it by using foreign cloth, how can we keep such cloth even for a moment?
('24', 23, 8, 23, 59064) 1 The A.I.C.C. met from July 28 to 30.

('24', 24, 1, 2, 59147) I shall have committed a wicked sin if we force ourselves into somebodys house and smash his oven.

('24', 32, 2, 13, 81933) 17. CONGRESS WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION ON ELECTIONS 1
('24', 32, 3, 14, 81990) [BOMBAY, July 31, 1921]
('24', 32, 4, 15, 82014) Mahatma Gandhi proposed the following resolution : XVII.
('24', 32, 4, 16, 82071) Without prejudice to the constitutional questions relating to the elections to the All India Congress Committee held in Bengal and Madras last month and without going into the merits thereof, in view of the fact that fresh elections must take place in or before November next all over India and in view of the fact that a heavy intensive programme is at present set before all Congress orga nizations, this Committee considers it undesirable, in the interests of the country, to disturb the said elections and advises such persons from Bengal and Madras as feel themselves aggrieved to co operate with the Provincial organization in both the Provinces with a view to the prosecution of the programme to a successful issue.

('24', 32, 6, 19, 82904) The resolution was seconded by Mahomed Ali and passed by a majority.

('24', 44, 2, 11, 110030) 26. CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE Civil disobedience was on the lips of every one of the members of the All India Congress Committee.
('24', 44, 2, 12, 110153) Not having really ever tried it, everyone appeared to be enamoured of it from a mistaken belief in it as a sovereign remedy for our present day ills.
('24', 44, 2, 13, 110303) I feel sure that it can be made such if we can produce the necessary atmosphere for it.
('24', 44, 2, 14, 110391) For individuals there always is that atmosphere except when their civil disobedience is certain to lead to bloodshed.
('24', 44, 2, 15, 110509) I discovered this exception during the satyagraha days.
('24', 44, 2, 16, 110565) But even so, a call may come which one dare not neglect, cost what it may.
('24', 44, 2, 17, 110640) I can clearly see the time coming to me when I must refuse obedience to every single State made law, even though there may be a certainty of bloodshed.
('24', 44, 2, 18, 110792) When neglect of the call means a denial of God, civil disobedience becomes a peremptory duty.
('24', 44, 2, 19, 110886) Mass civil disobedience stands on a different footing.
('24', 44, 2, 20, 110941) It can only be tried in a calm atmosphere.
('24', 44, 2, 21, 110984) It must be the calmness of strength not weakness, of knowledge not ignorance.
('24', 44, 2, 22, 111062) Individual civil disobedience may be and often is vicarious.
('24', 44, 2, 23, 111123) Mass civil dis obedience may be and often is selfish in the sense that individuals expect personal gain from their disobedience.
('24', 44, 2, 24, 111252) Thus, in Sout Africa, Kallenbach and Polak offered vicarious civil disobedience.
('24', 44, 2, 25, 111333) They had nothing to gain.
('24', 44, 2, 26, 111359) Thousands offered it because they expected personal gain also in the shape, say, of the removal of the annual poll

('24', 45, 1, 3, 111589) It is sufficient in mass civil disobedience if the resisters understand the working of the doctrine.
('24', 45, 1, 4, 111690) It was in a practically uninhabited tract of country that I was arres ted in South Africa when I was marching into prohibited area with over two to three thousand men and some women.
('24', 45, 1, 5, 111873) 1 The company included several Pathans and others who were ablebodied men.

('24', 57, 3, 15, 140040) 35. OPEN LETTER TO KATHIAWAR PRINCES LUCKNOW, Monday, Shravana [August 8, 1921]
('24', 57, 4, 16, 140120) SIRS, I have often thought of addressing a word to you but dropped the idea.
('24', 57, 4, 17, 140197) I have, however, heard and come to know a few things which make me feel that it is my duty to place my views before you.

('24', 58, 1, 2, 140871) in Kathiawar States.

('24', 58, 1, 4, 140949) I owe a special duty to you.
('24', 58, 1, 5, 140978) Hence, I feel pained whenever I hear stories of misrule in any of the Kathiawar States.

('24', 58, 1, 22, 142851) I hesitate to believe all this but there is so much evidence before me that all of it could not be untrue.

('24', 59, 1, 2, 143396) former brightness in the homes of the sturdy, handsome peasants of Kathiawar.
('24', 59, 1, 3, 143474) I remember I saw villages, before the famine of 35 1, overflowing with milk and butter.

('24', 60, 1, 8, 146331) I have sympathy for you.
('24', 60, 1, 9, 146356) You may not join the non co operators, but I humbly entreat you to look upon swadeshi as a separate matter and help your subjects to work for its progress independently of the rest of the programme.
('24', 60, 1, 10, 146555) May I ask one thing more?
('24', 60, 1, 11, 146581) How can liquor booths be tolerated in Kathiawar?
('24', 60, 1, 12, 146630) How can one believe that you really need the revenue which you get from liquor?
('24', 60, 1, 13, 146710) When the people are making an attempt to give up drinking and persuade others to do so, I would expect all wine bottles to be banished from your durbars too.

('24', 63, 6, 9, 152461) QUESTION : What would our duty be if the price of swadeshi cloth went on
('24', 63, 7, 10, 152534) rising and that of foreign cloth falling?
('24', 63, 7, 11, 152576) A. The meaning of the swadeshi pledge is that we are not to accept foreign cloth even if we get it gratis, just as a Hindu will not eat beef even if bread becomes too dear.

('24', 63, 9, 13, 152822) swadeshi or foreign?

('24', 84, 3, 4, 200398) While thanking the municipal commissioners for the address presented to him and his brother Maulana Mahomed Ali, [Gandhiji] asked them to take their legitimate share in the present struggle of eradicating various abuses prevailing in the country.
('24', 84, 3, 5, 200645) Referring to the cow sacrifice, he asked the Hindus to help the Mussulmans in the Khilafat question and to pray every morning for the protection of the cow if they wanted the question to be solved properly.
('24', 84, 3, 6, 200852) Concluding, he appealed to everyone present to take to the charkha and to work out the boycott of foreign cloth before the 30th September.
('24', 84, 3, 7, 200991) The whole audience maintained silence throughout their speeches.

('24', 84, 4, 10, 201229) 51. THE FEAR OF DEATH [August 14, 1921] 2
('24', 84, 5, 11, 201271) I have been collecting descriptions of swaraj.
('24', 84, 5, 12, 201318) One of these would be : Swaraj is the abandonment of the fear of death.
('24', 84, 5, 13, 201390) A nation which allows itself to be influenced by the fear of death cannot attain swaraj, and cannot retain it if somehow attained.
('24', 84, 5, 14, 201521) English people carry their lives in their pockets.
('24', 84, 5, 15, 201572) Arabs and Pathans consider death as nothing more than an ordinary ailment; they never weep when a relation dies.
('24', 84, 5, 16, 201685) Boer women are perfectly innocent of this fear.
('24', 84, 5, 17, 201733) In the Boer war, thousands of young Boer women became widowed.
('24', 84, 5, 18, 201796) They never cared.
('24', 84, 5, 19, 201814) It did not matter in the least if the husband or the son was lost; it was enough and more than enough that the countrys honour was safe.
('24', 84, 5, 20, 201951) What booted the husband if the country was enslaved?
('24', 84, 5, 21, 202004) It was infinitely better to bury a sons mortal remains and to cherish his immortal memory than to bring him up as a serf.
('24', 84, 5, 22, 202126) Thus did the Boer women steel their hearts and cheerfully give up their darlings to the angel of Death.
('24', 84, 5, 23, 202230) The people I have mentioned kill and get killed.
('24', 84, 5, 24, 202279) But what of those who do not kill but are only ready to die themselves?
('24', 84, 6, 25, 202351) 1 The meeting was held on the Debi Sarai grounds at 6 p.m.
('24', 84, 6, 26, 202410) Gandhiji was presented addresses on behalf of the Municipality and spoke after Mahomed Ali.

('24', 85, 0, 1, 202565) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 85, 1, 2, 202606) people become the objects of a worlds adoration.
('24', 85, 1, 3, 202655) They are the salt of the earth.
('24', 85, 1, 4, 202687) The English and the Germans fought one another; they killed and got killed.
('24', 85, 1, 5, 202763) The result is that animosities have increased.
('24', 85, 1, 6, 202810) There is no end of unrest, and the present condition of Europe is pitiful.
('24', 85, 1, 7, 202885) There is more of deceit, and each is anxious to circumvent the rest.
('24', 85, 1, 8, 202954) But the fearlessness which we are cultivating is of a nobler and purer order and it is therefore that we hope to achieve a signal victory within a very short time.
('24', 85, 1, 9, 203118) When we attain swaraj, many of us will have given up the fear of death; or else we shall not have attained swaraj.
('24', 85, 1, 10, 203233) Till now mostly young boys have died in the cause.
('24', 85, 1, 11, 203284) Those who died in Aligarh were all below twenty one.
('24', 85, 1, 12, 203337) No one knows who they were.
('24', 85, 1, 13, 203365) If Government resort to firing now, I am hoping that some men of the first rank will have the opportunity of offering up the supreme sacrifice.
('24', 85, 1, 14, 203509) Why should we be upset when children or young men or old men die?
('24', 85, 1, 15, 203575) Not a moment passes when someone is not born or is not dead in this world.
('24', 85, 1, 16, 203650) We should feel the stupidity of rejoicing in a birth and lamenting a death.
('24', 85, 1, 17, 203726) Those who believe in the souland what Hindu, Mussulman or Parsi is there who does not?know that the soul never dies.
('24', 85, 1, 18, 203843) The souls of the living as well as of the dead are all one.
('24', 85, 1, 19, 203903) The eternal processes of creation and destruction are going on ceaselessly.
('24', 85, 1, 20, 203979) There is nothing in it for which we might give ourselves up to joy or sorrow.
('24', 85, 1, 21, 204057) Even if we extend the idea of relationship only to our countrymen and take all the births in the country as taking place in our own family, how many births shall we celebrate?
('24', 85, 1, 22, 204233) If we weep for all the deaths in our country, the tears in our eyes would never dry.
('24', 85, 1, 23, 204318) This train of thought should help us to get rid of all fear of death.
('24', 85, 1, 24, 204388) India, they say, is a nation of philosophers; and we have not been unwilling to appropriate the compliment.
('24', 85, 1, 25, 204496) Still, hardly any other nation becomes so helpless in the face of death as we do.
('24', 85, 1, 26, 204578) And in India again, no other community perhaps betrays so much of this helplessness as the Hindus.
('24', 85, 1, 27, 204677) A single birth is enough for us to be beside ourselves with ludicrous joyfulness.
('24', 85, 1, 28, 204759) A death makes us indulge in orgies of loud lamentation which condemn the neighbourhood to sleeplessness for the night.
('24', 85, 1, 29, 204878) If we wish to attain swaraj, and if having attained it we wish to make it something to be proud of, we must perfectly renounce this unseemly fright.
('24', 86, 0, 1, 205027) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 87
('24', 86, 1, 2, 205071) And what is imprisonment to the man who is fearless of death itself?
('24', 86, 1, 3, 205140) If the reader will bestow a little thought upon the matter, he will find that if swaraj is delayed, it is delayed because we are not prepared calmly to meet death and inconveniences less than death.
('24', 86, 1, 4, 205339) As larger and larger numbers of innocent men come out to welcome death, their sacrifice will become the potent instrument for the salvation of all others; and there will be a minimum of suffering.
('24', 86, 1, 5, 205536) Suffering cheerfully endured ceases to be suffering and is transmuted into an ineffable joy.
('24', 86, 1, 6, 205629) The man who flies from suffering is the victim of endless tribulation before it has come to him, and is half dead when it does come.
('24', 86, 1, 7, 205762) But one who is cheerfully ready for anything and everything that comes escapes all pain; his cheerfulness acts as an anaesthetic.
('24', 86, 1, 8, 205892) I have been led to write about this subject because we have got to envisage even death if we will have swaraj this very year.
('24', 86, 1, 9, 206018) One who is previously prepared often escapes accidents; and this may well be the case with us.
('24', 86, 1, 10, 206113) It is my firm conviction that swadeshi constitutes this preparation.
('24', 86, 1, 11, 206182) When once swadeshi is a success, neither this Government nor any one else will feel the necessity of putting us to any further test.
('24', 86, 1, 12, 206315) Still it is best not to neglect any contingency whatever.
('24', 86, 1, 13, 206373) Possession of power makes men blind and deaf; they cannot see things which are under their very nose, and cannot hear things which invade their ears.
('24', 86, 1, 14, 206523) There is thus no knowing what this power intoxicated Government may not do.
('24', 86, 1, 15, 206599) So it seemed to me that patriotic men ought to be prepared for death, imprisonment and similar eventualities.
('24', 86, 1, 16, 206709) The brave meet death with a smile on their lips, but they are circumspect all the same.
('24', 86, 1, 17, 206797) There is no room for foolhardiness in this non violent war.
('24', 86, 1, 18, 206857) We do not propose to go to jail or to die by an immoral act.
('24', 86, 1, 19, 206918) We must mount the gallows while resisting the oppressive laws of this Government.
('24', 86, 2, 20, 207000) Young India, 13 10 1921
('24', 87, 0, 1, 207024) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 87, 1, 2, 207065) 52. DEFINITIONS OF SWARAJ
('24', 87, 2, 3, 207091) I take the readers leave to put before him the various definitions of swaraj which I keep formulating in my mind.
('24', 87, 2, 4, 207205) (1) Swaraj means rule over ones self.
('24', 87, 2, 5, 207243) One who has achieved this had fulfilled his individual pledge.
('24', 87, 2, 6, 207306) (2) We have, however, thought of swaraj in terms of some symbol or image.
('24', 87, 2, 7, 207380) Swaraj, therefore, means the complete control by the people of the countrys imports and exports, of its army and its law courts.

('24', 97, 2, 3, 229153) August 15, 1921
('24', 97, 3, 4, 229169) BROTHER HILLMEN, Munshi Kapur Singh and his associates are undergoing trouble for your sake in order to rid you of the injustices of which you are the victims for a long time past.
('24', 97, 3, 5, 229350) Are you going to give them up without efforts?
('24', 97, 3, 6, 229397) I am sure in this matter you would not incur the displeasure of the whole country.
('24', 97, 3, 7, 229480) I hope that so long as your friends and helpers are in jail you will, in pursuance of Mr. Stokes advice, refuse to give begar to the British Government and the State.
('24', 97, 3, 8, 229647) Do not allow any excess on your part; remove anger from your minds during the time your brothers are under custody.
('24', 97, 3, 9, 229763) It is much better for you to undergo hardships and be ready to fill jails for the sake of your faith (dharma) than to give begar to any official.
('24', 97, 3, 10, 229909) Remember that, if on this occasion you prove unworthy, you will perpetuate your slavery and for all time to come you shall continue to be treated as slaves.
('24', 97, 3, 11, 230066) In your efforts I am with you with all my heart and soul.
('24', 97, 3, 12, 230124) The Leader, 18 8 1921
('24', 97, 4, 13, 230146) 59. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI ON WAY TO CALCUTTA, [Before August 17, 1921] 2
('24', 97, 5, 14, 230221) BHAISHRI MAHADEV,
('24', 97, 6, 15, 230239) I have your letter.
('24', 97, 6, 16, 230259) Motilalji certainly wants you to stay on, but the main thing for you to consider is what you yourself would like to do.
('24', 97, 6, 17, 230379) If you find the work there very strenuous or if the place does not suit your health, do come away.
('24', 97, 6, 18, 230478) Can one be more important to a man than be his right hand?
('24', 97, 6, 19, 230537) If only I were the right hand could have been written either in grief or with knowledge.
('24', 97, 6, 20, 230626) If in grief, I would say you have not understood me.
('24', 97, 6, 21, 230679) If you wrote it with knowledge, all is well.
('24', 97, 6, 22, 230724) Two brains can drift apart from each other, but can a hand be separated from the brain to do anything?
('24', 97, 6, 23, 230827) I am training you to work as a brain.

('24', 99, 1, 2, 233060) 60. SPEECH AT MIRZAPUR PARK, CALCUTTA 1
('24', 99, 2, 3, 233100) August 17, 1921
('24', 99, 3, 4, 233116) Mahatma Gandhi at the outset said that he would not speak for more than five
('24', 99, 4, 5, 233193) minutes and hoped that the audience would kindly give him a patient hearing, as he
('24', 99, 5, 6, 233276) was to leave for Assam that evening by the Darjeeling mail.
('24', 99, 6, 7, 233336) He said that he believed that they had all read the resolutions of the All India
('24', 99, 7, 8, 233417) Congress Committee which had reference to the fact that there must be a complete
('24', 99, 8, 9, 233498) boycott of foreign clothes before the 30th of September next and he urged the
('24', 99, 9, 10, 233576) audience to see that that resolution was carried into effect.
('24', 99, 9, 11, 233638) He appealed to them to use
('24', 99, 10, 12, 233665) swadeshi clothes and he desired that they should burn the foreign clothes they were
('24', 99, 11, 13, 233749) still wearing or send them to Smyrna.
('24', 99, 11, 14, 233787) Pointing to his own dress which consisted of a
('24', 99, 12, 15, 233834) khadi cloth and a swaraj cap, he said that though khadi was a bit coarse they
('24', 99, 13, 16, 233912) should not be discouraged.
('24', 99, 13, 17, 233939) He reminded the audience that if they were determined to follow the resolutions in toto, he promised them swaraj and the undoing of
('24', 99, 14, 18, 234071) wrongs done to the Khilafat and to the Punjab in October next.
('24', 99, 14, 19, 234134) He also advised
('24', 99, 15, 20, 234150) themboth Hindus and Mohammedansto be united in their efforts just like two
('24', 99, 16, 21, 234225) sons of a mother, and be prepared to fight their battle peacefully and to present a bold
('24', 99, 17, 22, 234314) front in their struggle for freedom by absolutely non violent means.
('24', 99, 18, 23, 234383) In conclusion, Mahatma Gandhi again appealed to the audience to throw away
('24', 99, 19, 24, 234458) all their foreign clothes and to burn them if need be, reminding them at the same time
('24', 99, 20, 25, 234545) that he would address them again and devote a longer time when he returned to
('24', 99, 21, 26, 234623) Calcutta in the course of a few days after his tour in Assam.
('24', 99, 22, 27, 234685) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 18 8 1921
('24', 99, 23, 28, 234717) 1 Gandhiji addressed the meeting, attended by over 15,000 Hindus and Muslims, at 4.30 p.m.
('24', 99, 23, 29, 234808) Abul Kalam Azad and Mahomed Ali were present.

('24', 100, 1, 2, 234899) 61. LETTER TO KHWAJA [After August 17, 1921] 1
('24', 100, 2, 3, 234946) DEAR KHWAJA SAHEB 2, You will please forgive me for not acknowledging your wire earlier regarding cow sacrifice.
('24', 100, 2, 4, 235059) I know that in many parts of India, the work done was marvellously good indeed.
('24', 100, 2, 5, 235139) You wanted me to wire regarding scarcity of grain.
('24', 100, 2, 6, 235190) It is no use my wiring anything now.
('24', 100, 2, 7, 235227) I shall hope to meet you on the 4th 3 when you will mention the matter if the situation still requires consideration.
('24', 100, 3, 8, 235345) Yours sincerely,
('24', 100, 4, 9, 235362) From a photostat : S.N. 7599
('24', 100, 5, 10, 235391) 62. REPRESSION IN THE UNITED PROVINCES The following note was prepared for me by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, now over two months ago, reviewing repressive measures in the United Provinces to the 30th May.
('24', 100, 5, 11, 235593) Other matters having absorbed my attention, I have not been able to deal with Pandit Jawaharlal Nehrus notes.
('24', 100, 5, 12, 235703) They, however, read as fresh today as in June.
('24', 100, 5, 13, 235750) And the reader will find in them almost a complete answer to the official repudiation of the charge of repression.
('24', 100, 6, 14, 235865) Young India, 18 8 1921

('24', 101, 0, 1, 236755) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 101, 1, 2, 236797) Navajivan.
('24', 101, 1, 3, 236808) I have myself been anxious to do so.
('24', 101, 1, 4, 236845) But it has not been hitherto possible.
('24', 101, 1, 5, 236884) The editing of the Navajivan and Young India is difficult enough to cope with.
('24', 101, 1, 6, 236963) But there is no doubt that I am in love with my ideas and theories.
('24', 101, 1, 7, 237031) I am firmly of opinion that they are good for India, and if I may say it in all humility, good for all.
('24', 101, 1, 8, 237135) And so I am yielding to the pressure of friends and workers to issue a Hindi edition.
('24', 101, 1, 9, 237221) I know that several translations in Hindi appear in different parts of India.
('24', 101, 1, 10, 237299) But the desire has been to put under one cover an authorized free translation of selected articles from the Navajivan and Young India.
('24', 101, 1, 11, 237434) This is now being done.
('24', 101, 1, 12, 237458) The Hindi of the edition will really be Hindustani, a resultant of Hindi and Urdusimple words understood by both Hindus and Mussulmans.
('24', 101, 1, 13, 237594) An attempt will be made to avoid ornamentation.
('24', 101, 1, 14, 237642) Indeed I would love to give a simultaneous transcript in the Urdu characters.
('24', 101, 1, 15, 237720) But that cannot be as yet.
('24', 101, 1, 16, 237747) Let me not also hide the secret from the reader that it is my regard for the Marwari friends, and notably, Jamnalalji that hastened the issue of the Hindi Navajivan.
('24', 101, 1, 17, 237913) Jamnalalji has made the declaration as publisher and Mr. Shankarlal Banker as printer.
('24', 101, 1, 18, 238000) The Hindi Navajivan like the Gujarati and English editions will not contain any advertisements.
('24', 101, 1, 19, 238096) It has also to be self supporting like the other two and will therefore depend for existence on the support if receives.
('24', 101, 1, 20, 238217) The subscription for the Hindi edition will be Rs. 4/ yearly and Rs. 2/ half yearly.
('24', 101, 1, 21, 238302) I would advise intending subscribers to send only half yearly subscriptions.
('24', 101, 1, 22, 238379) The Hindi Navajivan is merely a trial.
('24', 101, 1, 23, 238418) I have only a limited staff.
('24', 101, 1, 24, 238447) But for the exhaustless energy and resourcefulness of Swami Anandanand I would have refused to take the responsibility.
('24', 101, 1, 25, 238567) We have found that it is voluntary labour that is most efficient.
('24', 101, 1, 26, 238633) And it is not easy to tap that class of labour whether bodily or mental.
('24', 101, 1, 27, 238706) I would therefore invite Hindi lovers of non co operation as a doctrine of life to confine their patronage to six months as a trial.
('24', 101, 1, 28, 238839) Needless to say the concerns are not meant for profit.
('24', 101, 1, 29, 238894) Any margin left therefore will be devoted to the development of the three editions.
('24', 101, 1, 30, 238978) The readers will also be interested and pleased to learn that Maulana Mahomed Ali has placed at my disposal his machinery, type and other material of the Comrade free of charge.
('24', 101, 1, 31, 239156) Thus the battle of non co operation with forces of evil (as I consider the Government to represent) is dependent upon closest co operation between forces of good as I consider non co operation to represent in spite of all the faults and limitations of non co operators.
('24', 102, 0, 1, 239426) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 103
('24', 102, 1, 2, 239471) FRAUDULENT IMITATIONS A friend writes from Madras :
('24', 102, 2, 3, 239523) The piece of cloth which I enclose herewith is a sample of what is being sold in Madras at from 10 to 15 annas per yard by the Bombay Swadeshi Stores under the name of pure khadi, i.e., hand spun and hand woven.
('24', 102, 2, 4, 239735) How is one to be protected against such frauds?
('24', 102, 2, 5, 239783) I have little doubt that the sample is of foreign make.
('24', 102, 2, 6, 239839) I have seen the sample and there is not a shadow of doubt that it is neither hand spun nor hand woven.
('24', 102, 2, 7, 239942) It is possible that it might be a production of Indian mills, though it shows Japanese rather than Indian finish.
('24', 102, 2, 8, 240056) The pity of it is that such stuff is being sold in swadeshi stores.
('24', 102, 2, 9, 240124) But we must be prepared for such frauds.
('24', 102, 2, 10, 240165) They are an eloquent testimony to the fact that the swadeshi spirit is rising.
('24', 102, 2, 11, 240244) How to detect and check these frauds is the question.
('24', 102, 2, 12, 240298) The golden rule, of course, is that we must spin our own yarn and get a weaver to weave it under our superintendence.
('24', 102, 2, 13, 240416) That time is undoubtedly coming.
('24', 102, 2, 14, 240449) When we cannot spin for ourselves, we must get the spinning done by the thousands of spinners coming into being all over the country.
('24', 102, 2, 15, 240583) Where we cannot do it, we must in choosing our khadi reject every piece of cloth that looks at all like mill made.
('24', 102, 2, 16, 240698) For coarser counts it will be most difficult to distinguish between imported cloth and that manufactured by our mills.
('24', 102, 2, 17, 240817) Hand spun khadi lacks the dead polish of the mills but is rougher to look at, porous, light to handle, and pleasant to the touch.
('24', 102, 2, 18, 240947) It is never glossy.
('24', 102, 2, 19, 240967) Another safeguard I suggest is that the cloth should be unbleached.
('24', 102, 2, 20, 241035) A third alternative which is not free from danger is that in every Congress district there should be swadeshi shops licensed by the Congress and there should be expect inspectors who should constantly inspect the stock in licensed shops.
('24', 102, 2, 21, 241273) If possible, every article should be stamped.
('24', 102, 2, 22, 241319) I know that we are not organized and trained enough for undertaking this work on a universal scale.
('24', 102, 2, 23, 241419) But till every district has begun to manufacture all khadi for itself, some such inspection is undoubtedly necessary, and whatever can be honestly improvised should be done.
('24', 102, 2, 24, 241593) PLAGUE SPOTS OF LUCKNOW An English friend writes to me at Lucknow :
('24', 102, 3, 25, 241661) I am just writing to ask you to write a word before you go to someone in authority among your supporters here in regard to the brothels in Lucknow.
('24', 102, 3, 26, 241809) I was talking to the military police this morning in Aminabad, and it seems that there are some fifty of these places in that locality frequented by soldiers
('24', 103, 0, 1, 241967) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 103, 1, 2, 242009) (some of whom have been court martialled as it is out of bounds)Europeans and Anglo Indians.
('24', 103, 1, 3, 242102) He did not say anything about Indians but I heard the other day that they also go to these women.
('24', 103, 1, 4, 242200) A word from you as to this debasing of manhood and lack of self control would do more than anything else to counteract this evil.
('24', 103, 1, 5, 242330) I will pledge myself to do all I can to help in the matter.
('24', 103, 1, 6, 242390) I wish I could share the English friends belief that my word has the power he attributes to it.
('24', 103, 1, 7, 242486) As I write this paragraph, the picture of the dear sisters who visited me at Cocanada after nightfall haunts me.
('24', 103, 1, 8, 242599) They were dearer to me after I learnt of their shame.
('24', 103, 1, 9, 242653) It was only by suggestion they could tell me what their life was.
('24', 103, 1, 10, 242719) As the spokeswoman spoke to me, she had shame and sorrow written in her eyes.
('24', 103, 1, 11, 242797) I could not bring myself to hold them guilty.
('24', 103, 1, 12, 242843) I devoted my speech after this meeting to the necessity of personal purity.
('24', 103, 1, 13, 242919) My heart, therefore, goes out to the fallen sisters of Lucknow.
('24', 103, 1, 14, 242983) They are driven to a life of shame.
('24', 103, 1, 15, 243019) I am satisfied that they do not go to it from choice.
('24', 103, 1, 16, 243073) And the beast in man has made the detestable crime a lucrative profession.
('24', 103, 1, 17, 243148) Lucknow is noted for its love of ease.
('24', 103, 1, 18, 243187) But Lucknow is also the seat of a Mussulman divine.
('24', 103, 1, 19, 243239) It has its full share of all that is noble in Islam.
('24', 103, 1, 20, 243292) For the Hindus Lucknow is the capital of the Province where the spotless Sita and Rama roamed and reigned.
('24', 103, 1, 21, 243399) It recalls the best days of Hindu purity, nobility, bravery and steadfastness to truth.
('24', 103, 1, 22, 243487) Non co operation is self purification, and I urge all the non co operators and others to deal with this moral plague of Lucknow.
('24', 103, 1, 23, 243616) I hope no custodian of Lucknows good name will remind me that Lucknow is no worse than the other cities in India.
('24', 103, 1, 24, 243730) Lucknow has come in by chance as an illustration.
('24', 103, 1, 25, 243780) We are responsible throughout India for the purity and the safety of our womanhood.
('24', 103, 1, 26, 243864) Why should not Lucknow lead?
('24', 103, 1, 27, 243893) Young India, 18 8 1921
('24', 103, 2, 28, 243916) 64. THE KHILAFAT
('24', 103, 3, 29, 243933) At Lucknow I found natural impatience on the part of the Mussulmans regarding the Khilafat.
('24', 103, 3, 30, 244025) Maulvi Salamatulla voiced in moderate language the public feeling regarding the position of the Angora Government when he said that the British attitude was becoming unbearable.
('24', 103, 3, 31, 244203) There is no doubt about the growing distrust of the British declarations about friendliness towards the Turks.
('24', 103, 3, 32, 244314) Nobody believes either that the British declarations are genuine or that
('24', 104, 0, 1, 244387) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 105
('24', 104, 1, 2, 244432) the British Government is powerless to afford relief.
('24', 104, 1, 3, 244486) In their impatient anger the Mussulmans ask for more energetic and more prompt action by the Congress and Khilafat organizations.
('24', 104, 1, 4, 244616) To the Mussul mans swaraj means, as it must mean, Indias ability to deal effectively with the Khilafat question.
('24', 104, 1, 5, 244729) The Mussul mans therefore decline to wait if the attainment of swaraj means indefinite delay or a programme that may require the Mussulmans of India to be come impotent witnesses of the extinction of Turkey in European waters.
('24', 104, 1, 6, 244956) It is impossible not to sympathize with this attitude.
('24', 104, 1, 7, 245011) I would gladly recommend immediate action if I could think of any effective course.
('24', 104, 1, 8, 245095) I would gladly ask for postponement of swaraj activity if thereby we could advance the interest of the Khilafat.
('24', 104, 1, 9, 245208) I would gladly take up measures outside non co operation, if I could think of any in order to assuage the pain caused to the millions of Mussulmans.
('24', 104, 1, 10, 245357) But, in my humble opinion, attainment of swaraj is the quickest method of righting the Khilafat wrong.
('24', 104, 1, 11, 245460) Hence it is that for me the solution of the Khilafat question is attainment of swaraj and vice versa.
('24', 104, 1, 12, 245562) The only way to help the afflicted Turks is for India to generate sufficient power to be able to assert herself.
('24', 104, 1, 13, 245675) If she cannot develop that power in time, there is no way out for India and she must resign herself to the inevitable.
('24', 104, 1, 14, 245794) What can a paralytic do to stretch forth a helping hand to a neighbour but to try to cure himself of his paralysis?
('24', 104, 1, 15, 245910) Mere ignorant, thoughtless and angry outburst of violence may give vent to pent up rage but can bring no relief to Turkey.
('24', 104, 1, 16, 246033) Nor can it increase the power of India to assert herself.
('24', 104, 1, 17, 246091) And the measures taken to put down vio lence may well lessen the speed with which we are marching to our goal.
('24', 104, 1, 18, 246202) But there is no cause whatsoever for despair.
('24', 104, 1, 19, 246248) The whole of the Congress programme has been framed and measures are being adopted to meet the Khilafat crisis.
('24', 104, 1, 20, 246360) There is no doubt that two months for finishing the swadeshi work is a most intensive measure calculated to bring the best out of the nation.
('24', 104, 1, 21, 246502) And if India completes the boycott by September and comes to her own in October, surely it must satisfy the most sanguine temperament and the most impatient and ardent Khilafatist as I claim myself to be.
('24', 104, 1, 22, 246707) The fact is that all the workers are not convinced of the possibility of completing the swadeshi programme during the time fixed or of its power to effect all that is claimed for it.
('24', 104, 1, 23, 246890) Such doubters have to stand out, unless they can suggest a better and quicker method
('24', 105, 0, 1, 246975) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 105, 1, 2, 247017) and get it accepted by the country.
('24', 105, 1, 3, 247053) In spite of their doubt, they should faithfully plunge them selves into swadeshi work and give the experiment a fair trial.
('24', 105, 1, 4, 247177) And does not this doubting of Indias ability to go through the swadeshi program me show, if the doubt is justified, that India has really no interest in the Khilafat or it has no desire to sacrifice anything for it?
('24', 105, 1, 5, 247393) Is it a big sacrifice for every Hindu and Mussulman to discard all foreign cloth and to use only khadi?
('24', 105, 1, 6, 247497) And if India is not to have that ability, will it not also be proof that India is unfit for any higher sacrifice and therefore unfit for helping Turkey?
('24', 105, 1, 7, 247650) Let us all work for complete boycott of foreign cloth and the manufacture of the required quantity of khadi and we shall be in sight of the heaven.
('24', 105, 1, 8, 247798) A suggestion was seriously put forth at Lucknow that we should boycott Ralli Bros., a Greek firm, and avenge ourselves against the Greeks and should invite the labourers to stop work on the export cargo.
('24', 105, 1, 9, 248002) The suggestions, it seems to me, are as absurd as they are impossible to carry out.
('24', 105, 1, 10, 248086) Assume for one moment that we can in a moment extinguish the business of Ralli Bros., how can that affect the Greeks?
('24', 105, 1, 11, 248204) Ralli Bros.
('24', 105, 1, 12, 248216) do not send all or a great part of their flour to Greece.
('24', 105, 1, 13, 248274) Theirs is a world trade.
('24', 105, 1, 14, 248299) And it is more difficult to deal with their trade than with swadeshi.
('24', 105, 1, 15, 248369) Any such attempt apart from its inherent wrong can only expose us to well deserved ridicule.
('24', 105, 1, 16, 248462) Interference with the labourers working on export cargo is equally fantastic.
('24', 105, 1, 17, 248540) If we had such absolute control over the masses, we should have won our battle long ago.
('24', 105, 1, 18, 248629) To stop the export of cargo requires not only a permanent or an indefinitely long stoppage of work by the existing labourers, but it presupposes our ability to stop any replacement of withdrawn labour.
('24', 105, 1, 19, 248831) I fear we are not organized enough for the work.
('24', 105, 1, 20, 248880) Any such attempt can only end in failure, if not worse.
('24', 105, 1, 21, 248936) The only feasible suggestion is the immediate taking up of civil disobedience.
('24', 105, 1, 22, 249015) I am convinced that the country is not ready for its adoption on an extensive scale.
('24', 105, 1, 23, 249100) It can be safely and successfully adopted, if the country evinces sufficient organizing ability, resource fulness and discipline necessary for bringing the eminently practical swadeshi enterprise to a successful end.
('24', 105, 1, 24, 249317) Let us hope and pray that the country will.

('24', 106, 1, 2, 249429) 65. A VENOMOUS PROSECUTION
('24', 106, 2, 3, 249456) During my travels in the United Provinces, I have come across extraordinary tales of repression.
('24', 106, 2, 4, 249553) For the present I propose only to deal with two cases of prosecution which I do not hesitate to consider venomous.
('24', 106, 2, 5, 249668) Messrs Mohansinh Darmal and Shambhunath, a Zemindar of Sitapur and ex Tahsildar, were called upon to show cause why they should not file security for an offence described thus in the summons :

('24', 106, 5, 10, 250475) On the face of it, the summons discloses no offence.

('24', 106, 5, 13, 250834) It is true, the magistrate has not the courage to mention this very relevant fact, but as the second accused made it abundantly clear in his statement, his being with and having served Panditji was the sole offence.
('24', 106, 5, 14, 251050) The accused is a well known man in his district.
('24', 106, 5, 15, 251099) He is known also to be a consumptive in the last stages.
('24', 106, 5, 16, 251156) His right lung is almost gone.
('24', 106, 5, 17, 251187) The other, and his bowels are badly affected [sic].

('24', 106, 5, 19, 251311) He had not made any speeches.
('24', 106, 5, 20, 251341) He was in Ram gadh like Panditji himself recouping his health.
('24', 106, 5, 21, 251404) Thus there was absolu tely no excuse for the magistrate to arrest the accused or to go on with his trial after the arrest.
('24', 106, 5, 22, 251527) The fact is, the magistrates idea was evidently to terrorize all those who had anything to do with non co operation even to the extent of collecting subscriptions or helping non co operation in villages.
('24', 106, 5, 23, 251731) It may be said that such things are really an exception and that their importance need not be exaggerated.
('24', 106, 5, 24, 251838) I am unable to subscribe to the doctrine.

('24', 108, 2, 13, 256627) 66. A CONFESSION OF ERROR
('24', 108, 3, 14, 256653) God only knows how often I have erred.
('24', 108, 3, 15, 256692) Those who charge me with infallibility simply do not know me.
('24', 108, 3, 16, 256754) My own experiences have taught me to be humble enough to know and to appreciate the fact that life consists in struggling against errors.
('24', 108, 3, 17, 256892) When I launched out light heartedly on civil disobedience in 1919, I saw that I erred grievously.
('24', 108, 3, 18, 256990) As soon as I perceived at Nadiad the want of foresight, I
('24', 109, 0, 1, 257048) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 109, 1, 2, 257090) called it a Himalayan miscalculation.
('24', 109, 1, 3, 257128) It was not an exaggeration.
('24', 109, 1, 4, 257156) And if India has not lost in moral growth thereby, it is because I had the wisdom to make a clean and full confession.
('24', 109, 1, 5, 257275) I wish similarly to make another confession during these few weeks of concentrated swadeshi work.
('24', 109, 1, 6, 257373) I have already made the confession in my talks with students and professors.
('24', 109, 1, 7, 257450) But a more definite and more public confession is necessary as well for my mental peace as for the present propaganda.
('24', 109, 1, 8, 257569) All these nine months experience has confirmed the correctness of the boycott of government educational institutions.
('24', 109, 1, 9, 257687) But I was weak about the alternative suggested, and I was weak because I distrusted my ability to carry conviction.
('24', 109, 1, 10, 257803) I cared for the consequence instead of leaving it to God.
('24', 109, 1, 11, 257861) And therefore in my weakness I said the boys, after leaving schools, could roam about the streets, follow the same course of instruction or best of all take to hand spinning till swaraj was established.
('24', 109, 1, 12, 258064) I discovered soon after the Nagpur Congress resolution that I had erred in suggesting several alternatives.
('24', 109, 1, 13, 258172) But the mischief was already done.
('24', 109, 1, 14, 258207) It started in September last.
('24', 109, 1, 15, 258237) I began to retrace my steps in January, but repair is always patch work.
('24', 109, 1, 16, 258310) And so the spinning wheel remains more or less an excrescence or an idle pastime in most non co operation schools.
('24', 109, 1, 17, 258425) I should have boldly said the whole truth and suggested hand spinning and hand weaving as an integral part of the proposition regarding boycott of educational institutions.
('24', 109, 1, 18, 258598) It is true that probably fewer students would have come out.
('24', 109, 1, 19, 258659) But they would have done far greater work than all the thousands who have left schools and colleges without a definite notion about the alternative.
('24', 109, 1, 20, 258808) They would by this time have become experts in hand spinning and hand weaving, and our swadeshi work would have been easier.
('24', 109, 1, 21, 258933) I know that the students and the professors of non co operation schools are doing their best.
('24', 109, 1, 22, 259027) But it must be admitted that they are labouring under a handicap.
('24', 109, 1, 23, 259093) They did not come with any conviction about hand spinning of swadeshi in general.
('24', 109, 1, 24, 259175) They simply considered the question, as they had a right to, from the educational standpoint.
('24', 109, 1, 25, 259269) It was enough for them that they diminished the prestige of the Government by withdrawing from its educational institutions.
('24', 109, 1, 26, 259394) It is hard on them now to be told that their boycott to be complete involved manufacture of yarn and khadi, that the preliminary training for the new methodthe swaraj typeof education meant during the war period the learning of hand spinning and the other processes of cloth manufacture and actual production.
('24', 109, 1, 27, 259704) But the mistake having been made, I at least must pay the
('24', 110, 0, 1, 259762) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 111
('24', 110, 1, 2, 259807) penalty of trying patiently to convince the doubters that it would have been better to have insisted on hand spinning as a necessary part of the educational item in non co operation.
('24', 110, 1, 3, 259990) I invite those who share my belief to hasten to repair the mistake and earnestly take up the work of production of yarn and khadi in all national institutions which they influence.
('24', 110, 1, 4, 260171) They will not ask me to supply them with teachers.
('24', 110, 1, 5, 260222) I have far too few.
('24', 110, 1, 6, 260242) But I jot down for them the processes that bale cotton, which is what we usually have today, has to go through.
('24', 110, 1, 7, 260354) It must be first carded.
('24', 110, 1, 8, 260379) There is no district in India which has no carders, i.e., pinjaras or dhunias.
('24', 110, 1, 9, 260458) They can card and a mere watching them for a day or two enables one to understand the process.
('24', 110, 1, 10, 260553) A weeks practice at the rate of six hours per day will enable one to card moderately well.
('24', 110, 1, 11, 260644) The carded cotton has to be turned into slivers or punis, an incredibly simple and easy process.
('24', 110, 1, 12, 260741) The cotton is now ready for hand spinning, which can be learnt from any spinner.
('24', 110, 1, 13, 260822) Yarn to be yarn must be free from dirt, even and well twisted.
('24', 110, 1, 14, 260885) If it is not well twisted or even, it cannot be woven.
('24', 110, 1, 15, 260940) The next process is sizing.
('24', 110, 1, 16, 260968) It is rather difficult to practise.
('24', 110, 1, 17, 261004) I have no scientific formula giving the quantity of ingredients.
('24', 110, 1, 18, 261069) It must be learnt from an experienced weaver.
('24', 110, 1, 19, 261115) Joining the thread is also a process to be separately learnt.
('24', 110, 1, 20, 261177) It requires like cycling a little knack which is easily acquired.
('24', 110, 1, 21, 261243) Lastly comes weaving which is purely a matter of practice.
('24', 110, 1, 22, 261302) One learns the principle in a day.
('24', 110, 1, 23, 261337) The reader must not be sur prised at the ease with which I claim processes can be learnt.
('24', 110, 1, 24, 261427) All natural and necessary work is easy.
('24', 110, 1, 25, 261467) Only it requires constant prac tice to become perfect, and it needs plodding.
('24', 110, 1, 26, 261545) Ability to plod is swaraj.
('24', 110, 1, 27, 261572) It is yoga.
('24', 110, 1, 28, 261584) Nor need the reader be frightened of the monotony.
('24', 110, 1, 29, 261635) Monotony is the law of nature.
('24', 110, 1, 30, 261666) Look at themonotonous manner in which the sun rises.
('24', 110, 1, 31, 261719) And imagine the catastrophe that would befall the universe if the sun became capricious and went in for a variety of pastimes.
('24', 110, 1, 32, 261846) But there is a monotony that sustains and a monotony that kills.
('24', 110, 1, 33, 261911) The monotony of necessary occupations is exhilarating and life giving.
('24', 110, 1, 34, 261982) An artist never tires of his art.
('24', 110, 1, 35, 262016) A spinner who has mastered his art will certainly be able to do sustained work without fatigue.
('24', 110, 1, 36, 262112) There is a music about the spindle which the practised spinner catches without fail.
('24', 110, 1, 37, 262197) And when India has monotonously worked away at turning out swaraj, she will have produced a thing of
('24', 111, 0, 1, 262298) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 111, 1, 2, 262340) beauty which will be a joy for ever.
('24', 111, 1, 3, 262377) But it cannot be without the spinning wheel.
('24', 111, 1, 4, 262422) Therefore the best national education for India is undoubtedly an intelligent handling of the spinning wheel.

('24', 115, 1, 2, 269341) 71. UNTOUCHABILITY
('24', 115, 2, 3, 269360) I have received so many comments on Shastri Vasantrams letter 1 giving his interpretation of untouchability that it would take up too much space to publish them all.
('24', 115, 2, 4, 269526) However, I regard these comments as a good sign.
('24', 115, 2, 5, 269575) Everyone of the correspondents wants the issue to be determined on a religious and philosophical level.
('24', 115, 2, 6, 269679) Their comments show that they will not be satisfied with a purely pragmatic solution of the problem.
('24', 115, 2, 7, 269780) If Hindu society, though providing Antyajas 2
('24', 115, 3, 8, 269826) with all facilities, continues to look upon them as untouchables even if they take a bath after coming into contact with filth, these fundamentalists would regard it as unbearable and sinful.
('24', 115, 3, 9, 270018) These correspondents are not reformers.

('24', 117, 3, 9, 274952) BIHAR TOUR
('24', 117, 4, 10, 274963) The Bihar tour has proved a very troublesome thing to me because of the services I had rendered in Champaran and because of the Bihari temperament.
('24', 117, 4, 11, 275111) Even in small towns, thousands of people assemble and, by their loud shouting and attempts to touch my feet, they try my patience.
('24', 117, 4, 12, 275242) With all of them wanting my darshan 2, they do not give me a moments respite.
('24', 117, 4, 13, 275320) I get no peace anywhere, by day or night.
('24', 117, 4, 14, 275362) As for going out for a walk, it is out of the question.
('24', 117, 4, 15, 275418) With a few efficient workers, any work could be got out of people with such faith, and Bihar has been doing such work.
('24', 117, 4, 16, 275537) Some of the workers in Bihar are men of such simple and pure lives and their faith in non violent non co operation is so firm that they have created a deep impression on the people and have done much good and quiet work.
('24', 117, 4, 17, 275758) In places where, only a year ago, but a few spinning wheels were plying, they are now in use in thousands of homes, thousands of yards of khadi are being woven and thousands have started wearing khadi exclusively.
('24', 117, 4, 18, 275972) In Bihar, Orissa and such other provinces, the spinning wheel which yields a daily wage of two annas is a sufficient means of livelihood for any person.
('24', 117, 4, 19, 276125) Many who work even as farm labourers do not get more than this.

('24', 118, 4, 18, 277684) All of us pleaded with them at this meeting and they have agreed to use in the future exclusively hand spun yarn for weaving, and mill yarn only if they must.
('24', 118, 4, 19, 277843) Till now, they have been using foreign yarn exclusively, though they themselves told me that their forefathers used only hand spun yarn.
('24', 118, 4, 20, 277980) From now on, if these weavers are supplied good hand spun yarn, they will most certainly use it to the exclusion of other yarn.
('24', 118, 4, 21, 278108) If no enthusiastic workers come forward, they will as certainly continue to use foreign yarn even though they have agreed to use hand spun yarn.
('24', 118, 4, 22, 278253) Our task now is to persuade weavers, carders, carpenters, blacksmiths and others to take interest in public work.
('24', 118, 4, 23, 278367) I hope that in every town of Gujarat, Congress workers will get in touch with such artisans, enrol them as members and secure their services.
('24', 118, 4, 24, 278509) Let us not mind if they earn well; we should be satisfied if only they give preference to public work and charge for such work at a little less than the prevailing rate.

('24', 123, 6, 8, 286144) 77. STATEMENT OF REPRESSION IN PRINCELY STATES
('24', 123, 7, 9, 286191) [Before August 25, 1921]
('24', 123, 8, 10, 286216) In the course of my journey to Gwalior, I was shocked to see that people at stations shrank even from approaching our train.
('24', 123, 8, 11, 286341) On platforms there was no swadeshi cloth to be seen at all.
('24', 123, 8, 12, 286401) In this State the non co operation movement has been completely stopped.
('24', 123, 8, 13, 286474) Wearing a khadi cap or possessing a charkha is regarded with disfavourit is in fact considered an offence.
('24', 123, 8, 14, 286581) I firmly believe that the Maharaja Sahibs thinking cannot be so mean.
('24', 123, 8, 15, 286651) My sympathy is wholly with the Maharaja.
('24', 123, 8, 16, 286692) The poisonous influence of the Government is nowhere so marked as it is in the Indian States.
('24', 123, 8, 17, 286786) For while the States can effect no reforms of any kind, they are frequently made to strike at the liberty of their subjects.
('24', 123, 8, 18, 286911) Besides, under the aegis of the Government they have also become, along with the rest of India, weak and irresponsible.
('24', 123, 8, 19, 287031) Therefore, if a self willed ruler wants to tyrannize over his people, he can give even more trouble than the Viceroy.
('24', 123, 8, 20, 287149) This is the greatest defect in the present administrative set up.
('24', 123, 8, 21, 287215) I hope that much of what I have been told at the Gwalior Station is exaggerated and that the repression carried on here is not as terrible as it is reported to be.

('24', 124, 1, 2, 287452) 78. NOTES
('24', 124, 2, 3, 287462) NON CO OPERATION IN ANDHRA
('24', 124, 3, 4, 287489) I am writing these notes at Mr. Mazharul Haks 1 Sadakat Ashram in Patna situated on the banks of the Ganges.
('24', 124, 3, 5, 287598) I have always considered Bihar to have done the best for non co operation.
('24', 124, 3, 6, 287673) Andhra I have put next.
('24', 124, 3, 7, 287697) But it is difficult to say which Province will do better.
('24', 124, 3, 8, 287755) Anyway the local Government are certainly assisting the people in their discipline.
('24', 124, 3, 9, 287839) This is what Mr. Konda Venkatappayya says in his latest letter:
('24', 124, 4, 10, 287903) In my last letter I informed you that after the arrests of myself and three merchant friends of mine, the pleaders of this city resolved to boycott the courts till the 31st December.
('24', 124, 4, 11, 288086) After our release the Bar at Bapatla, the next important town in this district, has also resolved to do the same.
('24', 124, 4, 12, 288200) Mr. Prakasam 2 and myself are proceeding to other stations in this district to have the courts similarly boycotted by the pleaders.
('24', 124, 4, 13, 288332) The city of Guntur has one District Court and two Sub courts besides two District Munsifs Courts and several Magisterial Courts.
('24', 124, 4, 14, 288461) In Bapatla there is a Sub court and two District Munsifs Courts.
('24', 124, 4, 15, 288526) At present all these courts stand abandoned except by a few.
('24', 124, 4, 16, 288587) We hope to have the courts in other stations in this district similarly abandoned.
('24', 124, 4, 17, 288670) Arbitration boards to hear and dispose of both original suits and appeals have been formed and the first sitting of these courts will commence the day after tomorrow (i.e., Monday, the 8th instant).
('24', 124, 4, 18, 288869) It is aimed to have all the suits and appeals now pending in the courts to be withdrawn from the British courts and referred to the arbitration courts.
('24', 124, 4, 19, 289021) After regular establishment of parallel courts and the paralysation of the administration of justice in the British courts in this district, I have every hope that other districts will soon follow the example.
('24', 124, 4, 20, 289231) Our aim is to complete this work in our district and next proceed to other districts if they do not begin to do it themselves in the meanwhile.

('24', 126, 3, 15, 293958) A South Indian lawyer sends me the following note:
('24', 126, 4, 16, 294009) Khadi is not as widely used in the Tamil province as in the other provinces, mainly because the womenfolk do not wear it.
('24', 126, 4, 17, 294131) The spinning wheel is not much in evidence for the same reason.
('24', 126, 4, 18, 294195) Plain white cannot be worn by married women here.
('24', 126, 4, 19, 294245) They can only wear dyed saris.
('24', 126, 4, 20, 294276) In former times cotton was the only wear of ladies.
('24', 126, 4, 21, 294328) Now, except by the poorest, cotton saris are discarded, and silk saris form the daily wear.
('24', 126, 4, 22, 294420) Silk saris were at first locally manufactured at Koranadu (near Mayavaram) and later on at Conjeevaram, and dyed with Indian dyes.
('24', 126, 4, 23, 294551) They cost from Rs. 10 to 30. They were only occasionally used.
('24', 126, 4, 24, 294614) Lately the market has been exclusively captured by Bangalore saris dyed with German or English dyes, the least of which costs about Rs. 50. This presses on the poor Brahmin householder, especially as he has to clothe the members of his family only with these; and when it is the daily wear, he has to go in for a number of them.
('24', 126, 4, 25, 294943) On marriage occasions the minimum cost of a sari fit for presentation is above Rs. 100. Many a decent family is ruined by a marriage, mostly on this account.
('24', 126, 4, 26, 295101) This ruinous habit, which was confined to the Brahmins, has spread among other classes also.

('24', 130, 3, 15, 303185) 79. A MOCK TRIAL
('24', 130, 4, 16, 303202) I have already dealt in a previous issue 1 with the disgraceful behaviour of a Karachi crowd on 25th July last upon the receipt of the news that Swami Krishnanand, a popular preacher, reformer and the soul of the picketing movement in Karachi, was arrested tried and sentenced to one years rigorous imprisonment inside of three hours.
('24', 130, 4, 17, 303537) The court house was surrounded by the military, and the trial took place practically with closed doors.
('24', 130, 4, 18, 303641) The Swami was arrested on the 20th but set free after an hours detention.
('24', 130, 4, 19, 303715) He was without a warning re arrested on the 25th on the same charge.
('24', 130, 4, 20, 303784) He was charged with having assaulted a constable in the discharge of his duty.
('24', 130, 4, 21, 303863) Vaswani 2 who was in touch with the Swami and who was present, at the court, testifies 3 that the Swami never assaulted the constable, but that on the other hand, he, the Swami, was fairly severely assaulted by the latter for having refused to move on whilst he was engaged in a conversation with a friend.
('24', 130, 4, 22, 304170) The crowd believed implicitly in the innocence of the Swami.
