('24', 133, 2, 14, 310724) We have not heard of any other instance in which convicted persons are quietly told that they might go home and await orders, not even bail bonds being taken from them.
('24', 133, 2, 15, 310893) Many more in Chirala Perala are prepared to fill the prisons.
('24', 133, 2, 16, 310955) The struggle is being carried on with remarkable vigour and persistence, though the dislocation of business caused by the evacuation and the loss of living in the case of poorer inhabitants have entailed serious hardship.
('24', 133, 3, 17, 311177) The property of the convicted persons has been attached and brought to sale a number of times at Bapatla and at Guntur for realizing the amount of fine levied on them.
('24', 133, 3, 18, 311345) But no bidders have come forward in either place.
('24', 133, 3, 19, 311395) This is an eloquent testimony to the sympathy generally felt for the sufferings of the Chirala Perala patriots.
('24', 133, 3, 20, 311507) Here we have a concrete instance of the meaning of the reforms and responsibility.
('24', 133, 3, 21, 311590) I doubt not that the minister believes that what he is doing is good for the people.
('24', 133, 3, 22, 311675) Did not the English officials whenever they imposed anything on us even the Rowlatt Act, seek to justify the imposition on the ground of public weal?
('24', 133, 3, 23, 311825) What non co operation is fighting among other things, is the spirit of patronage.
('24', 133, 3, 24, 311907) We must have the liberty to do evil before we learn to do good.
('24', 133, 3, 25, 311971) Even liberty must not be forced upon us.
('24', 133, 3, 26, 312012) The democratic spirit demands that a most
('24', 134, 0, 1, 312054) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 135
('24', 134, 1, 2, 312099) autocratic minister must yield to a peoples will or resign office.

('24', 134, 1, 4, 312288) The brave people of Chirala Perala have challenged the Government to do its worst and refused to have a municipality.
('24', 134, 1, 5, 312406) They need not have done so.

('24', 136, 1, 2, 315498) I shall have a talk with the representatives of planters.

('24', 136, 1, 7, 315970) The sufferings of the Indian people have to be mitigated or swarajya will have no meaning.
('24', 136, 1, 8, 316061) Our swarajya should be such that the humblest man or maid working in a tea plantation can freely go from Kashmir to Cape Comorin without a single ruffian teasing them; otherwise it would be no swarajya.
('24', 136, 1, 9, 316264) The struggle that is going on started because the British rule has done India no good.
('24', 136, 1, 10, 316351) I cannot get entangled any more in petty things.
('24', 136, 1, 11, 316400) For a time I had thought that love would put everything right.
('24', 136, 1, 12, 316463) But the experience of the Punjab and the injustice committed against Muslims in the name of justice have convinced me that in no other regime would such tyranny be possible.
('24', 136, 1, 13, 316637) And since then I have called this a Satanic regime.
('24', 136, 1, 14, 316689) If we wish to remove this Satanism, if we wish to mitigate the suffering of the workers and stop the atrocities inflicted on women, there is no power that can prevent us.
('24', 136, 1, 15, 316860) If we had not lacked faith in God this stark poverty would not have descended on India.
('24', 136, 1, 16, 316948) Our struggle does not spring from enmity.
('24', 136, 1, 17, 316990) But we cannot accept anyones overlordship.
('24', 136, 1, 18, 317033) We accept no one except God as our Lord and Master.
('24', 136, 1, 19, 317085) This is the meaning of swarajya.
('24', 136, 1, 20, 317118) It is heinous to love a regime where untruth reigns, barbarities are perpetrated, and false despatches are sent.
('24', 136, 1, 21, 317231) We therefore seek no justice from its courts and do not wish to have our children educated in its schools and colleges.
('24', 136, 1, 22, 317351) This is called non co operation.
('24', 136, 1, 23, 317384) We do not incite anyone to rioting.
('24', 136, 1, 24, 317420) We can achieve swarajya prayerfully and peaceably and heal the wound of the Muslims.
('24', 136, 1, 25, 317505) We must understand thoroughly what self purification means.
('24', 136, 1, 26, 317565) Give up drinking alcohol, smoking ganja and eating opium.
('24', 136, 1, 27, 317623) Give up visiting prostitutes.
('24', 136, 1, 28, 317653) I am well acquainted with the habits of workers.
('24', 136, 1, 29, 317702) You cannot live comfortably on your wage of eight or nine rupees a month.
('24', 136, 1, 30, 317776) You drink in order to forget your misery.
('24', 136, 1, 31, 317818) But the simplest remedy for misery is that, while you should put up with suffering, you should [not] put up with any unjust punishment that a tyrant may
('24', 137, 0, 1, 317971) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 137, 1, 2, 318013) inflict on you.
('24', 137, 1, 3, 318029) India has not yet understood this principle fully.
('24', 137, 1, 4, 318080) The day I am persuaded that India has learnt this, the country can become free.
('24', 137, 1, 5, 318160) Today India lacks the power for peaceful, civil disobedience of laws.
('24', 137, 1, 6, 318230) I hope we shall have this power by October.
('24', 137, 1, 7, 318274) But this power will not come through drinking and debauchery.
('24', 137, 1, 8, 318336) Therefore give up drinking, give up debauchery.
('24', 137, 1, 9, 318384) This has a very deep meaning.
('24', 137, 1, 10, 318414) If you would rather have nothing to do with dirty things, you should become pure yourselves.
('24', 137, 1, 11, 318507) We do not realize how our country has fallen through foreign tradeeven more than it has by drinking and opium.
('24', 137, 1, 12, 318618) We have not looked at the evil and sin there is in it.

('24', 137, 1, 22, 319591) Why do workers have to come here [to Assam] from such great distances?

('24', 140, 4, 15, 324460) 87. SPEECH TO RAILWAY WORKERS, CHITTAGONG
('24', 140, 5, 16, 324502) August 31, 1921
('24', 140, 6, 17, 324518) (The workers of the Assam Bengal Railway had gone on a strike to serve no selfish interest but to secure to the labourers who had abandoned the tea plantations justice for the cruelty which they had suffered at Chandpur.
('24', 140, 6, 18, 324739) The Government had beaten up and driven them from the railway station, and refused to help them to return to their home towns.
('24', 140, 6, 19, 324866) This had hurt the railway workers.
('24', 140, 6, 20, 324901) They had no common bond with the plantation labourers.
('24', 140, 6, 21, 324956) The latter hailed from Bihar and other provinces whereas most of the railway workers came from Bengal.
('24', 140, 6, 22, 325059) Their strike, thus, had no element of self interest in it.
('24', 140, 6, 23, 325118) I met these strikers at Chittagong.
('24', 140, 6, 24, 325154) I told them what they should do.
('24', 140, 6, 25, 325187) Notes of that speech were taken down.
('24', 140, 6, 26, 325225) Since some of the ideas are likely to prove useful, I publish the summary here believing that, though it is not complete and I have not been able to revise and
('24', 141, 0, 1, 325385) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 141, 1, 2, 325427) abridge it, the speech may be read with profit.
('24', 141, 2, 3, 325475) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI)
('24', 141, 3, 4, 325503) I thank you all for the address which you have presented to me; but I do not wish to detain you long over expressions of gratitude.
('24', 141, 3, 5, 325635) I shall not enter into a detailed discussion whether it was proper or improper on your part to have gone on a strike and continued it for so many months, because I am not in possession of all the facts.
('24', 141, 3, 6, 325838) I know only what I heard yesterday after coming here.
('24', 141, 3, 7, 325892) It is not possible for me to express any opinion on the basis of that limited knowledge.
('24', 141, 3, 8, 325981) You must have already heard from some of your leaders what I wrote in Young India about the Assam Bengal Railway strike.
('24', 141, 3, 9, 326102) In that article also, I did not express any opinion since I did not have enough information to form one.
('24', 141, 3, 10, 326207) I did not know your circumstances, your grievance.
('24', 141, 3, 11, 326258) I did not know whether you had sufficient justification for striking work; and I do not know that even now.
('24', 141, 3, 12, 326366) I can see, however, that your strike, unlike other strikes, is not motivated by self interest.
('24', 141, 3, 13, 326461) You have struck work not for any rise in wages but for the sake of others.
('24', 141, 3, 14, 326536) You have gone on a strike to express your sympathy for the sufferings of your brothers as a result of the atrocities at Chandpur.
('24', 141, 3, 15, 326666) I did not imagine that workers in India had become strong enough to go on a strike out of concern for other peoples sufferings.
('24', 141, 3, 16, 326794) This is not true of the entire working class, but in your case, I am told, you have struck work only out of sympathy with the sufferings of your brethren.
('24', 141, 3, 17, 326949) And if that is the reason why you have gone on strike, it becomes your duty not to return to work, any of you, until the hardships of plantation labourers have ended, until they get justice.
('24', 141, 3, 18, 327140) When can we say that their hardships have ended?
('24', 141, 3, 19, 327189) When can it be said that justice has been done for the atrocities committed at Chandpur?
('24', 141, 3, 20, 327278) Only when the Government expresses regret, apologizes for the beatings and pays the labourers the railway fare which it refused under pressure from the planters.
('24', 141, 3, 21, 327440) The Commissioner who ordered Gurkha soldiers to throw out from the railway waiting sheds, in the middle of the night, poor and exhausted working men and women and their children, was born in India and is one of us.
('24', 141, 3, 22, 327655) He should be ashamed of himself.
('24', 141, 3, 23, 327688) He should, on his own, offer an apology.
('24', 141, 3, 24, 327729) You can return to work only when all this is done.
('24', 142, 0, 1, 327780) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 143
('24', 142, 1, 2, 327825) Government acts thus, one may not mind the railway company not paying you for the strike period on the ground that you had given no notice.
('24', 142, 1, 3, 327965) The railway company might employ you as if you were fresh recruits, it may tell you that you will be employed as and when vacancies arise and may even stipulate new service conditions,you may submit to all this, but only after the Government yields.
('24', 142, 1, 4, 328215) As long as the Government refuses to bend, you ought not to return to work no matter what they offer you or how hard they try to win you over.
('24', 142, 1, 5, 328358) You should not go down on your knees even if the Congress Committee does not help you with funds or your leaders desert you.
('24', 142, 1, 6, 328483) Why should a person, who can work with his hands and feet, have to go down on his knees?
('24', 142, 1, 7, 328572) Such a man ought to remain independent and not rely on others for anything.
('24', 142, 1, 8, 328648) Whether it is I or the Congress Committee, if any leader deserts you after having advised you to go on strike, you must not waver.
('24', 142, 1, 9, 328779) I have read the notice which was served on you yesterday.
('24', 142, 1, 10, 328837) It says: Many of you have now returned to work.
('24', 142, 1, 11, 328885) The rest of you also should report for duty immediately.
('24', 142, 1, 12, 328942) We are advising you in your own interest.
('24', 142, 1, 13, 328984) Some irresponsible leaders incited you to go on this strike and have now deserted you.
('24', 142, 1, 14, 329071) Do not be misled by them any more.
('24', 142, 1, 15, 329106) If you delay returning to work, you will lose your jobs too.
('24', 142, 1, 16, 329167) You need not be frightened by this notice.
('24', 142, 1, 17, 329210) You are not going back to work; do not mind those who have returned.
('24', 142, 1, 18, 329279) They have acted unworthily; you should preserve your honour.
('24', 142, 1, 19, 329340) Times change and one age succeeds another.
('24', 142, 1, 20, 329383) This one belongs to the weavers.
('24', 142, 1, 21, 329416) You can stand on your own feet if you adopt this profession.
('24', 142, 1, 22, 329477) Do not think that this work will not solve your problem.
('24', 142, 1, 23, 329534) Weavers can today earn twice as much as others.
('24', 142, 1, 24, 329582) Those of you, moreover, who wish to go back to your villages may do so, your fares will be paid to you.

('24', 149, 1, 2, 344410) HOW TO KILL SWADESHI
('24', 149, 2, 3, 344431) We are familiar with the official ban put upon the khadi cap in various parts of India.
('24', 149, 2, 4, 344519) In Bihar, I heard that a magistrate actually sent hawkers to sell foreign cloth.
('24', 149, 2, 5, 344600) Mr. Painter of Dharwar fame has gone one better, and has issued an official circular in which he says:
('24', 149, 3, 6, 344703) All officers subordinate to the Collector and District Magistrate are desired to take steps to make people realize, that inasmuch as India produces less than her population requires, a boycott of foreign cloth and its destruction or export must inevitably lead to a serious rise in prices, which may lead to a serious disorder and looting, and that these consequences will be the result, not of any action on the part of Government but of Mr. Gandhis campaign.
('24', 149, 3, 7, 345164) In two other paragraphs means are indicated of combating the swadeshi propaganda, i.e., by holding meetings, and by dealers who are opposed to boycott attending the Collectors Office at stated hours.
('24', 149, 3, 8, 345364) The Madras government have issued a still more pedantic circular.
('24', 149, 3, 9, 345430) The meaning of these circulars is obvious Pressure is to be put upon the dealers and others not to countenance boycott.
('24', 149, 3, 10, 345550) The subordinate officials will take liberties which the authors of circulars may not even have contemplated.
('24', 149, 3, 11, 345659) Fortunately for the country, these threats now produce little or no impression upon the public, and the swadeshi movement will go on in the teeth of the official opposition, be it secret or open, unscrupulous or honourable.
('24', 149, 3, 12, 345883) The officials are so ignorant and obstinate, that they will not take the only effective course for avoiding the feared disorders and looting, viz, making common cause with the public and stimulating production.

('24', 151, 1, 2, 349396) A SEASONABLE PUBLTCATION
('24', 151, 2, 3, 349421) Dr. Syed Mahmud of Patna has rendered a service to the Khilafat by bringing out this booklet on the Khilafat and England.
('24', 151, 2, 4, 349543) It is easy reading, and makes out for the busy man a fairly complete case for the Khilafat.
('24', 151, 2, 5, 349635) Dr. Mahmud has been careful to support every one of his propositions by copious extracts.
('24', 151, 2, 6, 349725) He proves the treachery of British ministers from their own writings and speeches.
('24', 151, 2, 7, 349808) He has had go difficulty in showing that England, even when she was regarded as Turkeys friend, was a friend out of necessity, because she was Russias foe.
('24', 151, 2, 8, 349964) The history of Englands relationship with Turkey has been one of betrayal, of secret treaties hostile to Turkeys interests, the brave and trusting Turks always believing in Englands promises.
('24', 151, 2, 9, 350156) Here are Lord Palmerstons reasons for the support of Turkey in his days: We support Turkey for our own sake and for our own interest. When these very sound reasons ceased, Turkey was sold.
('24', 151, 2, 10, 350345) It was at the time of the Berlin Congress of 1877, that the secret leaked out that Britain had exacted the cession of the island of Cyprus from Turkey.
('24', 151, 2, 11, 350497) Disraeli and Salisbury, the two English plenipotentiaries, kept the secret from the Congress, although they were under an obligation to disclose it.
('24', 151, 2, 12, 350646) They stood convicted of nothing less than a direct and recorded lie! Did the discovery lead to the return to Turkey Of Cyprus ?
('24', 151, 2, 13, 350774) Not at all.
('24', 151, 2, 14, 350786) England placated outraged France by recognizing the latters right at the first convenient opportunity to occupy Tunis, by recognising her special interest in Syria and giving an equal share to her in the financial spoliation of Egypt.
('24', 151, 2, 15, 351021) No wonder Mr. Blunt has said: To the Cyprus intrigue are directly or indirectly referable half the crimes against Oriental and North African liberty our generation has witnessed. Dr. Syed Mahmud traces the treacherous dealings of England regarding Egypt, Tripoli and the Balkan War, and shows clearly that Turkey was practically driven out of the alliance with England.
('24', 151, 2, 16, 351391) Is it any wonder that no Mussulman trusts British ministers friendly professions?

('24', 154, 4, 22, 357925) 89. NATIONAL EDUCATION
('24', 154, 5, 23, 357948) So many strange things have been said about my views on national education, that it would perhaps not be out of place to formulate them before the public.
('24', 154, 5, 24, 358103) In my opinion the existing system of education is defective, apart from its association with an utterly unjust Government, in
('24', 155, 0, 1, 358229) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 155, 1, 2, 358271) three most important matters: 1. It is based upon foreign culture to the almost entire exclusion of indigenous culture.
('24', 155, 1, 3, 358391) 2. It ignores the culture of the heart and the hand, and confines itself simply to the head.
('24', 155, 1, 4, 358484) 3. Real education is impossible through a foreign medium.
('24', 155, 1, 5, 358542) Let us examine the three defects.
('24', 155, 1, 6, 358576) Almost from the commencement, the text books deal, not with things the boys and the girls have always to deal with in their homes, but things to which they are perfect strangers.
('24', 155, 1, 7, 358755) It is not through the text books, that a lad learns what is right and what is wrong in the home life.
('24', 155, 1, 8, 358857) He is never taught to have any pride in his surroundings.
('24', 155, 1, 9, 358915) The higher he goes, the farther he is removed from his home, so that at the end of his education he becomes estranged from his surroundings.
('24', 155, 1, 10, 359056) He feels no poetry about the home life.
('24', 155, 1, 11, 359096) The village scenes are all a sealed book to him.
('24', 155, 1, 12, 359145) His own civilization is presented to him as imbecile, barbarous, superstitious and useless for all practical purposes.
('24', 155, 1, 13, 359264) His education is calculated to wean him from this traditional culture.
('24', 155, 1, 14, 359335) And if the mass of educated youths are not entirely denationalised, it is because the ancient culture is too deeply embedded in them to be altogether uprooted even by an education adverse to its growth.
('24', 155, 1, 15, 359538) If I had my way, I would certainly destroy the majority of the present text books and cause to be written text books which have a bearing on and correspondence with the home life, so that a boy as he learns may react upon his immediate surroundings.
('24', 155, 1, 16, 359788) Secondly, whatever may be true of other countries, in India at any rate where more than eighty per cent of the population is agricultural and another ten per cent industrial, it is a crime to make education merely literary and to unfit boys and girls for manual work in after life.
('24', 155, 1, 17, 360070) Indeed I hold that as the larger part of our time is devoted to labour for earning our bread, our children must from their infancy be taught the dignity of such labour.
('24', 155, 1, 18, 360239) Our children should not be so taught as to despise labour.
('24', 155, 1, 19, 360298) There is no reason, why a peasants son after having gone to a school should become useless as he does become as agricultural labourer.
('24', 155, 1, 20, 360433) It is a sad thing that our schoolboys look upon manual labour with disfavour, if not contempt.
('24', 155, 1, 21, 360528) Moreover, in India, if we expect, as we must, every boy and girl of school going age to attend public schools, we have not the means to finance education in accordance with the existing style, nor are millions of
('24', 156, 0, 1, 360741) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 157
('24', 156, 1, 2, 360786) parents able to pay the fees that are at present imposed.
('24', 156, 1, 3, 360844) Education to be universal must therefore be free.
('24', 156, 1, 4, 360894) I fancy that even under an ideal system of government, we shall not be able to devote two thousand million rupees which we should require for finding education for all the children of school going age.
('24', 156, 1, 5, 361096) It follows, therefore, that our children must be made to pay in labour partly or wholly for all the education they receive.
('24', 156, 1, 6, 361220) Such universal labour to be profitable can only be (to my thinking) hand spinning and hand weaving.
('24', 156, 1, 7, 361320) But for the purposes of my proposition, it is immaterial whether we have spinning or any other form of labour, so long as it can be turned to account.
('24', 156, 1, 8, 361471) Only, it will be found upon examination, that on a practical, profitable and extensive scale, there is no occupation other than the processes connected with cloth production which can be introduced in our schools throughout India.
('24', 156, 1, 9, 361702) The introduction of manual training will serve a double purpose in a poor country like ours.
('24', 156, 1, 10, 361795) It will pay for the education of our children and teach them an occupation on which they can fall back in after life, if they choose, for earning a living.
('24', 156, 1, 11, 361951) Such a system must make our children self reliant.
('24', 156, 1, 12, 362002) Nothing will demoralize the nation so much as that we should learn to despise labour.
('24', 156, 1, 13, 362088) One word only as to the education of the heart.
('24', 156, 1, 14, 362136) I do not believe, that this can be imparted through books.
('24', 156, 1, 15, 362195) It can only be done through the living touch of the teacher.
('24', 156, 1, 16, 362256) And, who are the teachers in the primary and even secondary schools?
('24', 156, 1, 17, 362325) Are they men and women of faith and character?
('24', 156, 1, 18, 362372) Have they themselves received the training of the heart ?
('24', 156, 1, 19, 362430) Are they even expected to take care of the permanent element in the boys and girls placed under their charge?
('24', 156, 1, 20, 362540) Is not the method of engaging teachers for lower schools an effective bar against character?
('24', 156, 1, 21, 362633) Do the teachers get even a living wage?
('24', 156, 1, 22, 362673) And we know, that the teachers of primary schools are not selected for their patriotism.
('24', 156, 1, 23, 362762) They only come who cannot find any other employment.
('24', 156, 1, 24, 362815) Finally, the medium of instruction.
('24', 156, 1, 25, 362851) My views on this point are too well known to need re stating.
('24', 156, 1, 26, 362913) The foreign medium has caused brain fag, put an undue strain upon the nerves of our children, made them crammers and imitators, unfitted them for original work and thought, and disabled them for filtrating their learning to the family or the masses.
('24', 156, 1, 27, 363163) The foreign medium has made our children practically foreigners in their own land.
('24', 156, 1, 28, 363246) It is the greatest tragedy of the existing system.
('24', 156, 1, 29, 363297) The foreign medium has prevented the growth of our
('24', 157, 0, 1, 363348) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 157, 1, 2, 363390) vernaculars.
('24', 157, 1, 3, 363403) If I had the powers of a despot, I would today stop the tuition of our boys and girls through a foreign medium, and require all the teachers and professors on pain of dismissal to introduce the change forthwith.
('24', 157, 1, 4, 363615) I would not wait for the preparation of text books.
('24', 157, 1, 5, 363667) They will follow the change.
('24', 157, 1, 6, 363696) It is an evil that needs a summary remedy.
('24', 157, 1, 7, 363739) My uncompromising opposition to the foreign medium has resulted in an unwarranted charge being levelled against me of being hostile to foreign culture or the learning of the English language.
('24', 157, 1, 8, 363931) No reader of Young India could have missed the statement often made by me in these pages, that I regard English as the language of international commerce and diplomacy and therefore consider its knowledge on the part of some of us as essential.
('24', 157, 1, 9, 364176) As it Contains some of the richest treasures of thought and literature, I would certainly encourage its careful study among those who have linguistic talents and expect them to translate those treasures for the nation in its vernaculars.
('24', 157, 1, 10, 364414) Nothing can be farther from my thought than that we should become exclusive or erect barriers.
('24', 157, 1, 11, 364509) But I do respectfully contend, that an appreciation of other cultures can fitly follow, never precede an appreciation and assimilation of our own.
('24', 157, 1, 12, 364656) It is my firm opinion, that no culture has treasures so rich as ours has.
('24', 157, 1, 13, 364730) We have not known it, we have been made even to deprecate its study and deprecate its value.
('24', 157, 1, 14, 364823) We have almost ceased to live it.
('24', 157, 1, 15, 364857) An academic Grasp without practice behind it is like an embalmed corpse, perhaps lovely to look at but nothing to inspire or ennoble.
('24', 157, 1, 16, 364991) My religion forbids me to belittle or disregard other cultures, as it insists under pain of civil suicide upon imbibing and living my own.

('24', 164, 6, 11, 379961) Though I am here far away in the north east at present, I have received some reports of the sudden outbreak of violence in Malabar.

('24', 169, 1, 2, 391080) 95. MY NOTES
('24', 169, 2, 3, 391093) HOW TO GUARD AGAINST BEING CHEATED
('24', 169, 3, 4, 391128) Letters are coming in from everywhere telling me that greedy persons have been selling foreign or mill made cloth by passing it off as khadi and they also put up the price of such cloth.
('24', 169, 3, 5, 391315) This does not surprise me.
('24', 169, 3, 6, 391342) When the entire system of government is based on fraud, what else can we expect from people?
('24', 169, 3, 7, 391435) Go where you will, to law courts, shops or hospitals, even to legislatures, everywhere you will see cheating.
('24', 169, 3, 8, 391545) Non co operation is intended to save us from this.
('24', 169, 3, 9, 391596) Our non co operation is directed not against individuals but against their misdeeds.
('24', 169, 3, 10, 391681) There is, however, always the danger, in trying to save ourselves from one kind of sin, of being caught in another.
('24', 169, 3, 11, 391797) And so long as we like to have cloth like that made in the mills and so long as our cloth is not woven before our eyes, so long the danger of being cheated will remain.
('24', 169, 3, 12, 391966) The easiest safeguard against this is that every village should produce its own khadi and that people in the cities should buy only such khadi as does not look like mill made cloth, and that too preferably stamped with a Congress mark.
('24', 169, 3, 13, 392202) Even if all these precautions are taken, there is no guarantee that there would be no danger of fraud.
('24', 169, 3, 14, 392305) We have no choice but to put up with this as inevitable.
('24', 169, 3, 15, 392362) It is worth noting that the complaints of fraud come only from cities.
('24', 169, 3, 16, 392433) I hope that before long people will stop ordering khadi from Bombay and that, on the contrary, the citizens of Bombay will order their requirements from neighbouring places.
('24', 169, 3, 17, 392607) There will be less possibility of fraud in the khadi coming from villages.

('24', 169, 7, 21, 392768) I had merely heard the name of Assam.

('24', 170, 1, 5, 393174) Could the Assamese feel any affection for the ignorant man who had once supposed them to be uncivilized?
('24', 170, 1, 6, 393279) But the people today have learnt to look into a persons heart, how is it possible that they should be angry with a man for his genuine ignorance ?
('24', 170, 1, 7, 393426) Even so, I took the very first opportunity in a public meeting to ask forgiveness for my mistaken description of them.
('24', 170, 1, 8, 393545) People laughed heartily when I described my error.
('24', 170, 1, 9, 393596) They had not expected me to apologize.
('24', 170, 1, 10, 393635) Who would call the people of Assam uncivilised?
('24', 170, 1, 11, 393683) Anyone who does so must himself be an uncivilised person like myself.
('24', 170, 1, 12, 393753) Who would regard as uncivilised a people whose women weave the most beautiful cloth and wear only what they themselves have woven?
('24', 170, 1, 13, 393884) As Gujarat is in the west of India and to the south of the Vindhyas, Assam is in the extreme east and north of the country.
('24', 170, 1, 14, 394008) It is the north east corner of India.
('24', 170, 1, 15, 394046) From there one can, walking along the banks of the Brahmaputra, go to Tibet and following a foot tract southwards through the mountains reach Burma.
('24', 170, 1, 16, 394195) Wherever you turn your eyes in Assam, it is all green.
('24', 170, 1, 17, 394250) One of the hills in Assam, Cherapunji, has the heaviest rainfall in India, an average of 368 inches a year.
('24', 170, 1, 18, 394358) Actually in 1861 the rainfall amounted to 805 inches, and of this 366 inches of rain fell in the month of July alone!
('24', 170, 1, 19, 394476) Nowhere is the rainfall less than 60 inches.
('24', 170, 1, 20, 394521) And so with the rainfall on the one hand and the river Brahmaputra on the other, what can one expect but greenery all round in rich profusion?
('24', 170, 1, 21, 394664) Moreover, it is all hills and hills on either side of the river, so that a scene of the highest beauty meets the eye in whichever direction it turns.
('24', 170, 1, 22, 394814) The house in which we are put up is just by the riverside.
('24', 170, 1, 23, 394873) The river, in front, flows peacefully.
('24', 170, 1, 24, 394912) I deliberately use the word peacefully.
('24', 170, 1, 25, 394952) As the water is deep, I see no turbulence in it.
('24', 170, 1, 26, 395001) So big is the Brahmaputra that large ships can sail on it throughout the year.
('24', 170, 1, 27, 395080) If only we could acquire such serenity and enjoy such peace, within what a short time we could win swaraj!
('24', 170, 1, 28, 395187) We do not want the roar of shallow waters, but want rather the peace that is in the stillness of deep waters and the strength which it reveals.
('24', 170, 1, 29, 395331) A large variety of plants and many kinds of fruit grow here.

('24', 178, 11, 22, 410993) Mr. Gandhi in the course of his address said at the outset that last time when he came to Calcutta he appealed to the people for contributions to the Tilak Swaraj Fund and he was pleased to get a ready response for the good of the whole of India.
('24', 178, 11, 23, 411240) Mr. Gandhi wanted the foreign clothes to be either burnt or sent to Smyrna.

('24', 178, 11, 25, 411451) He was prepared to give swaraj to the people of the whole of India and to undo the wrongs done to the Khilafat and to the Punjab if all of them tried their level best to clothe themselves with swadeshi clothes.

('24', 179, 3, 13, 413545) 101. SPEECH TO MARWARI MERCHANTS CALCUTTA
('24', 179, 4, 14, 413587) September 7, 1921
('24', 179, 5, 15, 413605) Mr. Gandhi had a conference with the piece goods merchants in the night at 124, Canning Street, which lasted till midnight.
('24', 179, 5, 16, 413729) Mr. Gandhi urged them not to sell foreign cloth and not to enter into a fresh contract.
('24', 179, 5, 17, 413817) The merchants, however, stated that they had already agreed to act according to the resolution passed by the Marwari Chamber of Commerce which expressly stated that they were not going to purchase foreign cloth till 31st December, 1921. Mr. Gandhi wanted from them an undertaking that they would not purchase any more foreign cloth without any specified time limit.
('24', 179, 5, 18, 414183) Mahatma Gandhi, however, gave them further time to consider the matter and promised to address them again before the 13th instant when he was expected to leave Calcutta.

('24', 196, 15, 26, 455145) Whenever I think of Parsi philanthropy, I realize that if the tiny Parsi community has become renowned in the world, it is because of its philanthropy.
('24', 196, 15, 27, 455297) Among the well known communities the Parsis are the smallest.
('24', 196, 15, 28, 455359) Why does the world care for a community of eighty thousand men and women?
('24', 196, 15, 29, 455433) The Parsis possess no armed strength, they employ no craftiness nor do they practise any magic; or, one may say, their philanthropy is their magic.

('24', 203, 2, 3, 470523) ELEPHANTS OF ASSAM
('24', 203, 3, 4, 470542) Assam is as well known for its elephants as it is for the weaving skill of its women.
('24', 203, 3, 5, 470628) I was even shown a work on hasti vidya 1, written on bark, which was two hundred years old.
('24', 203, 3, 6, 470720) Besides the writing, it contained many beautiful pictures of elephants and other things.
('24', 203, 3, 7, 470809) The colours used in these were exquisite, such as one hardly comes across nowadays.
('24', 203, 3, 8, 470893) The paintings are so well proportioned that, looking at them, one cannot but take pride in the ancient art of Assam.
('24', 203, 3, 9, 471010) An elephant is valued at anything up to Rs. 6,000. He is used as a beast of burden and in hunting.
('24', 203, 3, 10, 471109) A person who knows about these matters told me that a wild elephant is subjected to much cruelty when it is first caught.
('24', 203, 3, 11, 471231) As the elephant likes music, the mahout also tries to win him over with it.
('24', 203, 3, 12, 471307) It understands our language so well that it can clearly recognize words of anger or affection.
('24', 203, 3, 13, 471402) This person told me that every elephant in Assam is familiar with the word shabash 2. Needless to say, ivory is inplenty in Assam.
('24', 203, 3, 14, 471533) I was happy to learn that here not only is the elephant not killed for the sake of his tusks but that killing it for this purpose is actually forbidden.
('24', 203, 4, 15, 471686) ASSAM SILK
('24', 203, 5, 16, 471697) Two varieties of silk are produced in Assam.
('24', 203, 5, 17, 471742) Both these are obtained from worms.
('24', 203, 5, 18, 471778) One type of worm is called andikeri and the other mooga.
('24', 203, 5, 19, 471835) In obtaining the formers silk, the worm is not destroyed in the process.
('24', 203, 5, 20, 471908) Its cocoon is spun like cotton.
('24', 203, 5, 21, 471940) The mooga spins its own silk.
('24', 203, 5, 22, 471970) When the mooga has completed the spinning, it is exposed to sun and destroyed.
('24', 203, 5, 23, 472049) The cocoon is then boiled and the silk is pulled out by wrapping it round a bobbin.
('24', 203, 5, 24, 472133) This process was carried out before me.
('24', 203, 5, 25, 472173) Both these varieties of silk are produced in large quantities in Assam but, though the industry is still alive, the use of foreign yarn has become widespread and many weaversboth men and women use only such yarn as warp.
('24', 203, 6, 26, 472394) PROCESSING OF COTTON
('24', 203, 7, 27, 472415) I also observed cotton being processed.
('24', 203, 7, 28, 472455) I see that fine cloth like that made in Andhra will by and by be produced here too.

('24', 204, 1, 2, 472614) been given a sample recently made.
('24', 204, 1, 3, 472649) I was shown saris of very fine cotton which were two hundred years old.
('24', 204, 1, 4, 472721) In many places even Egyptian cotton has been planted.
('24', 204, 1, 5, 472775) I saw such cotton being spun unginned.
('24', 204, 1, 6, 472814) The other cotton, I saw, was being spun in the same way as it is done in Andhra.
('24', 204, 1, 7, 472895) Each seed is first combed out with fish teeth, so that all the fibres are separated.
('24', 204, 1, 8, 472980) The cotton that remains entangled in the comb is spun as it is and then woven into khadi.
('24', 204, 1, 9, 473070) The seeds and the cotton which is still sticking to them are then separated and the latter is carded.
('24', 204, 1, 10, 473172) Each seed is processed in this way.
('24', 204, 1, 11, 473208) Such cotton is spun and the finest yarn is prepared out of it.

('24', 204, 2, 16, 473632) SHONITPUR
('24', 204, 3, 17, 473642) We have now reached Tezpur.
('24', 204, 3, 18, 473670) Its ancient name is Shonitpur.
('24', 204, 3, 19, 473701) It is said a British officer found it difficult to pronounce Shonitpur.
('24', 204, 3, 20, 473773) He asked what shonit 1 meant in Assamese and was told that the Assamese equivalent was Tez.
('24', 204, 3, 21, 473865) He then named Shonitpur Tezpur !
('24', 204, 3, 22, 473898) In ancient times, Tezpur was the capital of Banasura and it is for this reason that the authors of Puranas are supposed to have called it Shonitpur.
('24', 204, 3, 23, 474047) The legend about this place says that Chitralekha carried off Aniruddha from Dwaraka and brought him here for Usha.

('24', 213, 2, 3, 492962) CHILDREN S BLESSINGS
('24', 213, 3, 4, 492983) Many sisters write to me, as also many youths; it is only from children that I seldom get a letter.
('24', 213, 3, 5, 493083) An unexpected letter has come from one and here it is: I am very eager to do what you want us to do.
('24', 213, 3, 6, 493184) I have started wearing khadi....
('24', 213, 3, 7, 493217) 1 and I have believed in non co operation from the very beginning....

('24', 213, 3, 9, 493312) But now he believes in it.
('24', 213, 3, 10, 493339) If you get all the children in the country to join non co operation, your success will be certain.
('24', 213, 3, 11, 493438) At every place I ask for womens blessings in this holy struggle, for I believe that they are pure and tender hearted, that they are free from guile or deceit.
('24', 213, 3, 12, 493597) They sincerely believe this struggle to be for a holy cause.
('24', 213, 3, 13, 493658) But children are even more innocent at heart than women.
('24', 213, 3, 14, 493715) In what way can one ask for their blessings?
('24', 213, 3, 15, 493760) Can they take even one step without their parents permission?
('24', 213, 3, 16, 493822) Hence, I have done nothing in regard to children except to play with them.
('24', 213, 3, 17, 493897) I was, therefore, pleased to get this letter.
('24', 213, 3, 18, 493943) I can see that the language is not a childs.
('24', 213, 3, 19, 493988) The letter seems to have been inspired by their teacher.
('24', 213, 3, 20, 494045) But it is indeed what I ask and desire, that parents give their children educat ion in the essentials of dharma, teach them non co operation with sin and the use of the weapon of non violence and obtain their blessings in this sacred tasks.
('24', 213, 3, 21, 494286) Women, children, the lame, the crippled, all can join the movement, and they should.
('24', 213, 3, 22, 494371) The greater the number of these that join, the sooner shall we win.
('24', 213, 3, 23, 494439) There is no distinction here of high or low, of big or small.
('24', 213, 3, 24, 494501) Anyone who has a big heart is big, and anyone with a small heart is small, is a cripple.
('24', 213, 3, 25, 494590) Hence childrens blessings are sweet to me.
('24', 213, 3, 26, 494633) The Viceroys goodwill will not help us to win swaraj, but the blessings of pure hearted children certainly will.

('24', 215, 3, 4, 496801) Mr. Gandhi said: From the nature of my reception at Midnapore I cannot persuade myself to believe that the educated folk of Bengal have been estranged from me or have discountenanced my movement or the attainment of swaraj.

('24', 217, 5, 20, 501113) I give it below for the benefit of the reader 1.
('24', 217, 6, 21, 501162) As regards the hartal, you hold it to be a bad step.

('24', 217, 6, 23, 501409) The restraint and self discipline, which they have cultivated within this short time, are also remarkable.
('24', 217, 6, 24, 501516) No doubt there was some disturbance on the fifth day of the hartal.
('24', 217, 6, 25, 501584) The reason for our release is not the discovery of anything to contradict the evidence against us, but the fact that the voice of the people was against him [the District Magistrate].
('24', 217, 6, 26, 501768) The merchants closed the shops, the pleaders boycotted the courts, the people

('24', 218, 1, 3, 502042) There was a move amongst the clerks in the Government offices to resign their appointments.

('24', 218, 1, 5, 502202) These were the causes of our release.

('24', 219, 0, 1, 503973) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 219, 1, 2, 504015) 119. A PROTEST AGAINST BURNING
('24', 219, 2, 3, 504046) TO THE EDITOR YOUNG INDIA
('24', 219, 4, 4, 504072) Your idea that all foreign cloth collected on the 1st of August should either be burnt or seat to Smyrna, with the support it found in the last meeting of the All India Congress Committee, has bewildered me; and the issues it involves appear to me to be so far reaching, that I have ventured to write this letter.
('24', 219, 4, 5, 504386) The first of August is come and gone, and that which is destroyed can never be restored; but in our calmer moments we may reflect on our actions in a different light from that in which they were conceived, and prevent a recurrence of what on reconsideration we should find to be wrong.
('24', 219, 5, 6, 504672) The non co operation movement, shorn of its superfluities and the passing
('24', 219, 6, 7, 504746) tangle of conflicting opinion, has always appeared to me to be a symbol of Indias
('24', 219, 7, 8, 504828) regeneration, and a mighty echo of the voice of its soul, forgotten through many
('24', 219, 8, 9, 504909) years of abandoned ideals, broken power, selfishness and ignorance, and the spirit of
('24', 219, 9, 10, 504995) ahimsa in which it was conceived was to me the unfailing cure of all ills of life,
('24', 219, 10, 11, 505078) should man rise to that height of the soul.
('24', 219, 10, 12, 505122) But I cannot help thinking of the burning
('24', 219, 11, 13, 505164) of all foreign cloth in honour of the memory of Lokamanya Tilak as a travesty of
('24', 219, 12, 14, 505245) what, in my humble opinion, I regarded as the lofty ideals that inspired the
('24', 219, 13, 15, 505322) movement.
('24', 219, 14, 16, 505332) It is argued that all foreign cloth should be burnt, because (1) it is a mark of
('24', 219, 15, 17, 505413) dependence and a badge of slavery for the rich and poor alike, and (2) it is a garb of
('24', 219, 16, 18, 505500) sin forced on India by the wickedness of the East India Company and perpetuated by
('24', 219, 17, 19, 505583) our own helplessness and ignorance.
('24', 219, 17, 20, 505619) In both cases we can get rid of it only by
('24', 219, 18, 21, 505662) destruction; and the clothing of even the poorest among us with such cloth would be
('24', 219, 19, 22, 505746) as sinful as offering rotten or poisonous food to a hungry man.
('24', 219, 19, 23, 505810) But, with strange
('24', 219, 20, 24, 505828) inconsistency, we are told that it may, however, be sent to the people of Smyrna.
('24', 219, 21, 25, 505910) I do not wish to discuss the assumptions on which the foregoing arguments are
('24', 219, 22, 26, 505988) based; but, while I realize the necessity of swadeshi and believe in the moral and
('24', 219, 23, 27, 506071) partially economic value of khadi, the revival of the spinning wheel and restoration
('24', 219, 24, 28, 506156) of the great staple industry of India, I think it would be easy to prove that, so long as
('24', 219, 25, 29, 506246) the total imports of India exceed four times the value of its foreign cloth, we are as
('24', 220, 0, 1, 506333) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 221
('24', 220, 1, 2, 506378) many times dependent and so slaves for our other requirements, which, too, should on
('24', 220, 2, 3, 506463) that account be burnt.
('24', 220, 2, 4, 506486) It could even more convincingly be argued that books written
('24', 220, 3, 5, 506547) by foreigners and in a foreign language, machinery, medicines and other products of
('24', 220, 4, 6, 506631) modern science and human skill and intelligence, in which, for the present, they have
('24', 220, 5, 7, 506717) advanced more than we have, are a much deeper mark of dependence and a greater
('24', 220, 6, 8, 506796) badge of slavery, mental and physical, than foreign cloth, and we should get rid of
('24', 220, 7, 9, 506880) these as well by destruction.
('24', 220, 7, 10, 506910) And then, in the opinion of some, why not in the same
('24', 220, 8, 11, 506964) way of the foreigner toothe source of all our ills?
('24', 220, 8, 12, 507016) If, again, by yielding to the
('24', 220, 9, 13, 507046) wickedness of the East India Company which crippled our weavers and killed our
('24', 220, 10, 14, 507125) industry, Indians of those times and through them their sons of today are guilty of
('24', 220, 11, 15, 507209) sin, which may be atoned for only by setting fire to the cause of their crime, why not burn only English cloth and spare the rest?
('24', 220, 11, 16, 507340) Again, if one may not offer rotten or
('24', 220, 12, 17, 507378) poisonous food to a poor and starving Indian, might he offer it to a helpless Turk ?
('24', 220, 13, 18, 507463) send our cast off foreign clothes to the people of Smyrna appears to me to be much
('24', 220, 14, 19, 507546) more sinful than offering them to our own countrymen; for it is dishonourable for one
('24', 220, 15, 20, 507632) nation to offer its shreds and leavings to another, and the wrong done to Islam by the
('24', 220, 16, 21, 507719) foreigners, the allies, is more recent and in the opinion of many, greater than the
('24', 220, 17, 22, 507803) harm done by the East India Company to ourselves; and can we regard it moral or in
('24', 220, 18, 23, 507886) any way justifiable to send to the people of Smyrna cloth manufactured by those very
('24', 220, 19, 24, 507971) foreigners and cast off by us as the garb of sin?
('24', 220, 19, 25, 508021) Well may such charity be said to
('24', 220, 20, 26, 508054) degrade both the giver and the receiver.
('24', 220, 21, 27, 508095) In conclusion I would point out, Sir, that the analogy between rotten food and
('24', 220, 22, 28, 508174) foreign cloth can hardly be maintained; and so long as there are thousands of our own
('24', 220, 23, 29, 508260) countrymen who are literally naked ant enough khadi has not been manufactured to
('24', 220, 24, 30, 508341) clothe them, there are many who would regard it as a sin to burn a single yard of
('24', 220, 25, 31, 508423) foreign cloth or send it out of the country when it is required more urgently at home.
('24', 220, 26, 32, 508510) I do not question the spectacular effect of destruction by fire or its efficacy to
('24', 220, 27, 33, 508593) catch popular imagination and rouse quick, if temporary, enthusiasm; but I cannot
('24', 220, 28, 34, 508675) think that, you have been actuated by such considerations in the face of such utter
('24', 220, 29, 35, 508759) need of so many of our poor, naked and famine stricken countrymen.
('24', 220, 30, 36, 508826) Yours, etc.,
('24', 220, 31, 37, 508839) N. V. THADANI 1
('24', 220, 32, 38, 508855) H YDERABAD,
('24', 220, 33, 39, 508867) 1 Principal, Hindu College, Delhi and Sind National College, Hyderabad, Sind; educationist; author of the Mystery of the Mahabharata

('24', 221, 3, 3, 509059) I gladly print Mr. Thadanis closely reasoned letter.

('24', 222, 1, 2, 510368) 120. CONFUSION OF THOUGHT
('24', 222, 2, 3, 510394) TO THE EDITOR YOUNG INDIA
('24', 222, 3, 4, 510420) DEAR SIR,
('24', 222, 4, 5, 510430) I have seen your argument about the utility of picketing.
('24', 222, 4, 6, 510488) The very same arguments appealed to non co operating students of Bengal, when they fell flat before the gates of Calcutta University College and the Senate House, and thereby hoped to dissuade the law examinees from taking their examinations.
('24', 222, 4, 7, 510731) With folded hands they entreated their examinee brothers not to drink the insidious poison.
('24', 222, 4, 8, 510823) And you are certainly aware of the amount of success they obtained in their novel way of picketing.
('24', 222, 4, 9, 510923) The examination halls wore a deserted appearance and a subsequent supplementary examination had to be held.
('24', 222, 4, 10, 511031) But it was you who then disapproved of the picketing, and everything had to be given up.
('24', 222, 4, 11, 511120) The results so nobly achieved were lost, and Bengal repents today that her youths have a tarnished fame on their brow to be proud of.
('24', 222, 4, 12, 511254) When the picketing party laid themselves flat before the gateways, they did so on the very argument that diseased persons have got to be helped against themselves. As brothers, who deemed themselves blessed in truly understanding your advice about modern education and in possessing boldness enough to leave their colleges, they thought it a duty incumbent upon them to dissuade their brothers from appearing at the examination.
('24', 222, 4, 13, 511683) Lying flat on the ground is indisputably an oriental way of moral persuasion.
('24', 222, 4, 14, 511761) It was nothing but humility preached in its real aspect.
('24', 222, 4, 15, 511818) If I am truly inspired with the feeling that drinking is a dire vice and everyone has to be saved from its clutches, shall I be deemed using physical force if I lie down in front of the drinking den and ask the intending drinker to trample over my body and get his drink?
('24', 222, 4, 16, 512090) Here in this case I appeal to his heart.
('24', 222, 4, 17, 512131) And by moral persuasion I understand appealing to the heart.

('24', 222, 4, 19, 512342) I shall be glad to know why you disapproved of the method of the Bengal pickets, as they used to appeal to the heart of the examinees and did not use physical force in any way.
('24', 222, 4, 20, 512519) BENARES, 12th July, 1921 S. N. RAY The writer assumes without warrant, that I would countenance liquor shop picketing of the type described in his letter.
('24', 223, 0, 1, 512674) 224 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 223, 1, 2, 512716) unseemly obstruction of the passage had been persisted in, there would have been a revulsion of feeling in the country, such as would have thoroughly discredited non co operation.
('24', 223, 1, 3, 512896) Moreover, it is a far fetched analogy to compare the drink habit with education.
('24', 223, 1, 4, 512977) In the matter of education, it is a conflict of ideals, and non co operation is for this generation a new ideal.
('24', 223, 1, 5, 513090) Whereas in the matter of drink, the conflict is between abstinence and a recognized vice.
('24', 223, 1, 6, 513180) A young lad considers it a virtue to go to a Government college, a drinker knows drinking to be an evil habit.
('24', 223, 1, 7, 513291) The educated youth read newspapers, know all the arguments for and against.
('24', 223, 1, 8, 513367) Visitors to liquor shops read nothing, and not being in the habit of attending meetings, hear nothing.
('24', 223, 1, 9, 513470) Picketing, therefore, in the case of colleges and schools was not only superfluous, but in the manner it was carried out, constituted a sort of violence utterly unjustified in any event, and for a non co operator a breach of his pledge.
('24', 223, 1, 10, 513707) I am glad, therefore, that the picketing stopped, if it did, as a result of my severe criticism.

('24', 223, 4, 13, 513851) The first occasion I had of meeting those women who earn their livelihood out of their shame was at Coconada in the Andhra province.

('24', 223, 4, 15, 514053) The second occasion was at Barisal.

('24', 226, 7, 11, 520722) 124. INTERVIEW TO DAILY EXPRESS
('24', 226, 8, 12, 520754) MADRAS September 15, 1921
('24', 226, 9, 13, 520780) Taking advantage of the arrival of Mr. Gandhi in Madras on Thursday morning, a representative of the Daily Express called on the non co operation leader
('24', 226, 10, 14, 520933) and interviewed him in regard to various questions that are at present agitating the minds of the public in which Mr. Gandhi is either directly or indirectly concerned.
('24', 226, 11, 15, 521102) Asked what proportion of the Crore Fund had been collected and where the money had been deposited, Mr. Gandhi said that the bulk of the Fund had been collected and was deposited with the several provincial committees.
('24', 226, 11, 16, 521320) So far as he was aware the monies were deposited in various banks the largest part of it being deposited in Bombay.
('24', 226, 12, 17, 521436) [REPRESENTATIVE :] How will the amount collected be utilized ?
('24', 226, 12, 18, 521499) [GANDHIJI:] The amount collected is being utilized chiefly for swadeshi, i.e., for encouraging hand spinning and hand weaving, in national educational institutions, for famine relief and in connection with the temperance campaign and the untouchables.
('24', 227, 0, 1, 521751) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 227, 1, 2, 521793) may take it roughly that 50 per cent will be devoted to hand spinning and hand weaving.
('24', 227, 2, 3, 521881) In view of the outbreaks of violence that have occurred in Malabar, and in other centres previously, what steps will you take to ensure adherence to non violence ?
('24', 227, 2, 4, 522045) The only answer that I can give to this question is that I will do it by speeches, by talks in private also, by correspondence and by popularizing hand spinning, because I consider hand spinning as the greatest and the most efficacious antidote.
('24', 227, 2, 5, 522291) If I could only get the whole of India to become busy with this development, it would stop all violence in the movement
('24', 227, 3, 6, 522411) Do you think that there are bound to be exceptions to observance of nonviolence as in the case of the Moplahs?
('24', 227, 3, 7, 522522) Yes, there are bound to be exceptions, but I am positive that there would have been much greater violence, more widespread, if there had been no non co operation continuously emphasizing non violence.
('24', 227, 3, 8, 522723) I should like to answer fully and frankly all the questions that may arise from my answer in order to make my position absolutely clear.
('24', 227, 4, 9, 522860) With regard to the question of picketing, I take it that there is a strong body of opinion that objects to picketing.
('24', 227, 4, 10, 522978) If you find, after experience, that the two opposing forces would result in any form of disorder, do you intend that, in spite of that, picketing shall continue?
('24', 227, 4, 11, 523140) Yes, it will continue so long as there is no violence used by those who are picketing.
('24', 227, 4, 12, 523227) I would not take into consideration the violence that may be offered either by the liquor dealers or by the people who want to visit these liquor shops; the third party being the Government.
('24', 227, 4, 13, 523418) In several cases in Bihar, the Magistrate had actually given half a crown and said: Heres half a crown, you go and insist upon drinking, because it is your birthright and you are entitled to drink. So of that kind of violence, I shall take no notice so long as the non violent party remain true to their principles, but if they do not remain true then, of course, all picketing will cease.
('24', 227, 5, 14, 523808) Then there is the question of the boycott of cloth.
('24', 227, 5, 15, 523860) My information here is that there has been an increase in the price of the Indian goods that come from Bombay.
('24', 227, 5, 16, 523971) If the boycott of imported goods continues, I calculate myself that there is bound to be a further increase in the price of Indian made goods.
('24', 227, 5, 17, 524114) If that occurs, will it affect your campaign?

('24', 228, 1, 4, 524375) I therefore want the people to be totally indifferent to the mill manufactures.

('24', 233, 1, 2, 536165) 125. INTERVIEW TO MADRAS MAIL 1
('24', 233, 2, 3, 536197) [September 15, 1921]
('24', 233, 3, 4, 536218) [REPRESENTATIVE:] You look upon the propaganda of boycott of foreign cloth as the constructive side of non co operation though it involves the destruction of the existing stock of foreign cloth?
('24', 233, 3, 5, 536413) [GANDHIJI:] I look upon swadeshi as the constructive side of non co operation, as I expect it to lead to the manufacture of all the cloth needed by the nation by means of hand spinning and hand weaving.
('24', 233, 4, 6, 536616) Do you think, Mr. Gandhi, it is possible in view of the existing conditions of the country to produce sufficient to meet all the needs of the people?
('24', 233, 4, 7, 536766) Certainly, even as it is possible for us to cook our daily supply of food, if the manufacture of cloth be our hands as it was only two or three hundred years ago.
('24', 233, 5, 8, 536929) Have not the conditions altered materially with the introduction of machinery, apart from other causes?
('24', 233, 5, 9, 537033) No disturbance has been really created by machinery, such as that it cannot be corrected.
('24', 233, 5, 10, 537123) It is a mental state which has got to be put right.
('24', 233, 5, 11, 537175) It is not as though hands, nor is it as if all the hours that the nation devoted to manufacturing cloth and spinning yarn, are now utilized to any other or better purpose.
('24', 233, 5, 12, 537347) The hours are there unutilized and the hands as well.
('24', 233, 6, 13, 537401) You believe that the concentration of manufacture under the factory system could equally and effectively be carried out for the purpose of meeting the needs of the nation by hand spinning on an extensive scale in the homes and cottages of the people?
('24', 233, 6, 14, 537652) Certainly.
('24', 233, 7, 15, 537663) In other words you think it is only a question of extensive manufacture through the agency of hand spinning and hand weaving in rural areas in the country rather than intensive manufacture under the factory system?
('24', 233, 7, 16, 537878) Most certainly so.
('24', 233, 8, 17, 537897) Do you think that all our modern requirements could be adequately and effectively answered without the use of machinery?
('24', 233, 9, 18, 538018) 1 A representative of Madras Mail called on Gandhiji at Ramjee Kalyanjees residence at San Thome.
('24', 234, 0, 1, 538116) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 235
('24', 234, 1, 2, 538161) Modern requirements so far as cloth is concerned, yes, they can be; but during the transition stage the nation will have to do with a limited supply till the beautiful fabric of India is revived.
('24', 234, 2, 3, 538357) But how is it necessary, Mr. Gandhi, to destroy the existing stock in use of foreign cloth in this country to achieve this end?
('24', 234, 2, 4, 538485) Because the nation has to realize the crime that it has committed in abandoning its home industries and taking to foreign cloth, it is a necessary penance in order to demonstrate a change of heart.
('24', 234, 3, 5, 538683) Penance, Mr. Gandhi, presupposes a sincere feeling for the abandonment of the practice or ideal of the people?
('24', 234, 3, 6, 538794) Certainly.
('24', 234, 4, 7, 538805) Do you think that the people of this country have actively helped in the destruction of indigenous industries or do you not agree that in any system of competition between manual labour and machinery, indigenous industries are bound to go to the wall?
('24', 234, 4, 8, 539057) Although under diabolical pressure, nevertheless people deliberately sacrificed their own national industries when there was no question of competition.
('24', 234, 5, 9, 539210) I dont quite follow you, Mr. Gandhi.
('24', 234, 5, 10, 539247) It is historically true that when we gave up our home industries there was no competition between the handloom and the machinery.
('24', 234, 6, 11, 539377) But I thought that people had not voluntarily given up their industries, but found themselves unable to cope with the competition of machine made goods imported into this country?
('24', 234, 6, 12, 539557) My point is that owing to the political advantages which the East India Company had obtained they were in a position to force upon the people machine made goods.
('24', 234, 7, 13, 539719) But were not these machine made goods at the same time cheaper than indigenous products?
('24', 234, 7, 14, 539808) Over and over again the people of the country were terrorized into giving up their occupation of cloth manufacture.
('24', 234, 7, 15, 539924) By such means as for instance the cutting of their own thumbs by the weavers themselves when their labour was impressed.
('24', 234, 8, 16, 540045) But could it have gone on such a scale as to effectively kill indigenous industries ?
('24', 234, 8, 17, 540131) Certainly, the continuance of the process over a certain length of time was bound to have that effect unless people treated those home manufactures as a part of their religion.
('24', 235, 0, 1, 540308) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 235, 1, 2, 540350) Do you consider the political conditions now favourable in your opinion for a revival Of indigenous industries, which you contend had been killed by the East India Company?
('24', 235, 1, 3, 540523) I consider the conditions very favourable because people realize that if hand spinning and hand weaving are not revived now, there is nothing but deeper and deeper starvation day after day staring the nation in the face.
('24', 235, 2, 4, 540744) It is part of your programme, then, to enforce this lesson on the masses ?

('24', 235, 6, 15, 541926) All the information that I have collected, and which I have no reason to doubt, points to the fact that violence broke out in those parts which were least touched by the activities of non co operators and my information goes further that non co operators were deliberately prevented from entering those disturbed parts.
('24', 235, 7, 16, 542246) Notwithstanding protests from respectable leaders not in your camp against the evil consequences of non co operation on a large scale, you still think that it is the only means, if not the chief means for a people situated like India to attain swaraj?

('24', 242, 1, 10, 558308) Not until the message, the peaceful and sacred message of the spinning wheel has penetrated almost every home of India is swaraj attainable by non violent methods.

('24', 246, 4, 15, 569083) 128. SPEECH AT PIECE GOODS MERCHANTS MEETING, MADRAS
('24', 246, 5, 16, 569136) September 16, 1921
('24', 246, 6, 17, 569155) An important general body meeting of the Madras Piece Goods merchants Association was held last evening in the Association premises to discuss the question of boycott of foreign cloth with Mahatma Gandhi.
('24', 246, 6, 18, 569360) The meeting was largely attended by the members of the Association.
('24', 246, 6, 19, 569428) Maulana Azad Sobhani, Messrs Yakub Hassan, C. Rajagopalachari and T. S. S. Rajan were also present at the meeting.
('24', 246, 6, 20, 569543) The speeches were in English and were translated by Mr. C. Rajagopalachari.
('24', 246, 7, 21, 569619) Mr. Ramjee Kalyanjee on behalf of the Association welcomed Mahatmaji.
('24', 246, 7, 22, 569689) Mahatma Gandhi in reply said:
('24', 246, 8, 23, 569719) GENTLEMEN, It gives me the greatest pleasure really to meet you here this afternoon.
('24', 246, 8, 24, 569804) It has been my good fortune to enjoy the sweetest of relations with the piece goods merchants.
('24', 246, 8, 25, 569899) As you know I had several meetings with them in Bombay and in Calcutta, and throughout my
('24', 247, 0, 1, 569989) 248 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 247, 1, 2, 570031) travels in the different parts of India I have taken good care to see the merchant community.
('24', 247, 1, 3, 570125) You will be glad to learn from me that in all these places they have been in full sympathy, as they ought to have been with this great swadeshi movement, and you will be glad to learn also that with the exception of Calcutta the merchants by a very large majority have agreed to stop importing any further foreign cloth.
('24', 247, 1, 4, 570446) The Calcutta merchants, I know, have found some difficulties.
('24', 247, 1, 5, 570508) They suggested that they would stop imports only up to 31st December and should reserve to themselves the liberty for exchanging and selling foreign yarns amongst them with their existing stocks.
('24', 247, 1, 6, 570704) I was unable to accept that proposition, because I felt that was nothing but camouflage.
('24', 247, 1, 7, 570793) And I would have been an unwilling instrument for entering into secret bargains.
('24', 247, 1, 8, 570874) In a movement of this character which we claim to be pure and religious, there is really no room for secrecy or for under hand dealings.
('24', 247, 1, 9, 571011) It is much better that those who cannot see their way to stop importing foreign cloth should say so frankly and openly and continue their trade than that they should say one thing in the public and do quite the opposite in private.
('24', 247, 1, 10, 571243) But of course I sympathize with our Calcutta merchant friends, in that they are the largest importers of foreign cloth throughout India.
('24', 247, 1, 11, 571380) But you will be glad to hear that even they are now taking a more patriotic attitude than they have taken hitherto.
('24', 247, 1, 12, 571496) Mr. Jamnalalji who specially remained in Calcutta in order to carry on negotiations with those big houses telegraphed to me today saying that several of them had now shown reasonableness and national interest in the subject.
('24', 247, 1, 13, 571721) So you see that the whole of India really is rallying to the swadeshi flag.
('24', 247, 1, 14, 571797) And therefore I was delighted to find assurances of your sympathy with this movement; and if you can only abide by the undertaking you have given in your statement, viz., that you will not import hereafter foreign cloth, it will largely answer the purpose which we want to fulfil.
('24', 247, 1, 15, 572078) I know that we have throughout India today, probably 40 crores worth of piece goods for sale.
('24', 247, 1, 16, 572172) I do not see much difficulty in 40 crores worth of foreign cloth even disappearing in India amongst the multitude.
('24', 247, 1, 17, 572287) But I must totally dissent from the view that the stock that you have at present is not capable of being sent out of India altogether.

('24', 249, 2, 11, 576606) Mahatma Gandhi in replying to each of the merchants agreed that the initiative should come from the consumers and said that there was not the slightest suggestion in his remarks that they should repudiate the contracts made, and, as it was incumbent upon them in the cause of the motherland to co operate with the whole of India in making the swadeshi programme a success, wished they should cease to give any further orders.
('24', 249, 2, 12, 577032) If they were able to alter the taste of the people as he expected they would surely be, the people would certainly go to them; and nobody had got a greater opportunity of doing substantial propaganda work than they, the piece goods merchants had.
('24', 249, 2, 13, 577279) He deprecated the credit system obtaining among the merchants as fatal to their commerce and commercial morality, and it should therefore never be regarded an impassable barrier to undertaking to stop future orders.
('24', 249, 2, 14, 577495) Swaraj was sure to come and with it new economic laws would come to prevail.
('24', 249, 2, 15, 577572) With regard to the suggestion that boycott should be gradual, Mahatmaji said that they had sufficient notice of it as early as one year back and an honest merchant would never find cause to complain of financial difficulties, consequent on the giving up of the credit system.
('24', 249, 2, 16, 577848) This, Mahatmaji illustrated by referring to the case of Mr. Mohamed Kachalia in South Africa who orginally carried on business on credit on a large scale and when his European customers out of political motives pressed him to clear off their dues, he boldly sold away all his property and paid his creditors to the last pie and then started business with no credit and rose to such a prosperous condition that those very European merchants were tempted to offer him their goods on credit again.
('24', 249, 2, 17, 578343) That was an example which they would do well to follow and a braver merchant they could not find.
('24', 249, 2, 18, 578441) Personal difficulties, no doubt he appreciated, but swaraj meant sacrifice, and even a merchant was called upon to take an unselfish view of his calling.

('24', 250, 2, 4, 578915) 129. SPEECH TO LABOURERS, MADRAS
('24', 250, 3, 5, 578948) September 16, 1921
('24', 250, 4, 6, 578967) Mahatma Gandhi addressed a large gathering of labourers (now on strike) at the Beach opposite the High Court at 6.45 p.m.
('24', 250, 4, 7, 579089) Among others present were Messrs Yakub Hassan, A. Rangaswami Aiyangar, S. Satyamurti, Salla Guruswami Chetty, S. Srinivasa Aiyangar, Safi Mohamed, Kasturiranga Aiyangar, Venkatarangam Naidu and M. K. Acharya.
('24', 250, 4, 8, 579298) Mahatma Gandhi spoke for more than 45 minutes in English and the speech was translated into Tamil by Mr. M. S. Subramaniya Aiyar of Swadeshamitran.
('24', 250, 4, 9, 579446) He said:
('24', 250, 5, 10, 579455) FRIENDS, I was not able to be here punctually at 6.30. I have been talking to our merchant friends and they occupied me longer than I thought I would have to be.
('24', 250, 5, 11, 579617) I well remember the scene that presented itself to me last time when I had the pleasure of meeting you.
('24', 250, 5, 12, 579721) A fellow labourer myself, my heart has always gone out to the labourers of Madras in their sorrows and their troubles.
('24', 250, 5, 13, 579840) I want to come to the subject of this evening without any further ceremony.
('24', 250, 5, 14, 579916) I know that about ten thousands of you have struck work.
('24', 250, 5, 15, 579973) It grieves me to find that you have trouble amongst yourselves.
('24', 250, 5, 16, 580037) It grieves me to find that you are divided into two parties.
('24', 250, 5, 17, 580098) It grieves me further to find that the two parties represent not two different views but two different castes.
('24', 250, 5, 18, 580209) I understand that the Adi Dravidas, our Panchama 1 friends, are ranged on one side and you, the others, on the opposite side.
('24', 250, 5, 19, 580335) I understand further that these Panchama brethren have resumed work, whereas you, a large majority have not done so.
('24', 250, 5, 20, 580452) And I understand further that there has been some pressure exerted by some of you on those brethren of ours, who have rejoined work.
('24', 250, 5, 21, 580585) I understand further there are continuous quarrels and squabbles between these two parties.
('24', 250, 5, 22, 580677) I am therefore here to warn the majority against using the slightest pressure against the minority.
('24', 250, 5, 23, 580777) As one knowing the labourers for a period of 25 years, very nearly 30 years, as one experienced in handling large strikes even affecting more than
('24', 250, 6, 24, 580924) 1 Literally, belonging to the fifth caste; an outcaste
('24', 251, 0, 1, 580979) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 251, 1, 2, 581021) 50,000 people at a time, I know that nothing is so demoralizing to labourers than that they should use force against a single one of their brethren.
('24', 251, 1, 3, 581170) The lowest one of us, the fewest of us must have the right ofexercising his own free choice even though you may consider that he has erred.
('24', 251, 1, 4, 581310) Therefore I would urge you to leave those 3,000 brethren of ours severely alone.
('24', 251, 1, 5, 581391) I would urge you not to think low of them.
('24', 251, 1, 6, 581434) I would urge you even to be kind to them.
('24', 251, 1, 7, 581476) Certainly you will never swear at them.
('24', 251, 1, 8, 581516) I would ask you not even to go to them to wean them from their service.

('24', 258, 3, 4, 597862) 133. BITTER EXPERIENCES IN CALCUTTA
('24', 258, 4, 5, 597898) I have given some description of my tour in East Bengal.
('24', 258, 4, 6, 597955) There the people assembled in their thousands and yet they did not tire me.
('24', 258, 4, 7, 598031) In Calcutta, however, I am completely exhausted.
('24', 258, 4, 8, 598080) For one thing, I could not go to sleep till midnight and, for another, there were loud shouts of victory.
('24', 258, 4, 9, 598186) It is too much for me.
('24', 258, 4, 10, 598209) I get exhausted hearing them the whole day.
('24', 258, 4, 11, 598253) My ears cannot endure them and, as they mean nothing, I find them painful.
('24', 258, 4, 12, 598328) I am quite clear in my mind that this shouting does not help us.
('24', 258, 4, 13, 598393) When people had no spirit in them, when they were afraid even to express their views, I suppose the shouting gave them some confidence in themselves.
('24', 258, 4, 14, 598543) This was my experience in Champaran.
('24', 258, 4, 15, 598580) Hundreds of people used to come and sit round me just in order to feel such confidence.
('24', 258, 4, 16, 598668) Although their love made me feel impatient, I bore with them.
('24', 258, 4, 17, 598730) Here, too, I get the same love.
('24', 258, 4, 18, 598762) Shouts of victory are an indication of unthinking adoration, which profits
('24', 259, 0, 1, 598837) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 259, 1, 2, 598879) neither the people nor me.
('24', 259, 1, 3, 598906) I have here considered this shouting from my own point of view.
('24', 259, 1, 4, 598970) Touching of my feet in reverence is equally painful.
('24', 259, 1, 5, 599023) I sometimes get hurt.
('24', 259, 1, 6, 599045) Sometimes I barely save myself from a fall.
('24', 259, 1, 7, 599089) I shiver in fear when setting out for meetings.
('24', 259, 1, 8, 599137) I see a danger in these shouts.
('24', 259, 1, 9, 599169) Let us imagine that a crowd of love crazy people has been shouting; while they are engaged in this, people hear nothing with their ears and see nothing with their eyes.
('24', 259, 1, 10, 599338) Let us imagine, further, that somebody starts trouble and two or three men hit out with sticks.
('24', 259, 1, 11, 599434) I see all this and I tell them with gestures and words to stop fighting.
('24', 259, 1, 12, 599507) But who will listen to this frail reed pipe?
('24', 259, 1, 13, 599552) Meanwhile, let us imagine, the fighting spreads, people take sides and there is bloodshed.
('24', 259, 1, 14, 599643) All this can happen without anybody wanting it.
('24', 259, 1, 15, 599691) I believe this is what happened in Amritsar 1. I do not believe that anybody had planned to kill the innocent bank manager.
('24', 259, 1, 16, 599815) But the peoples blood was boiling and some wicked persons took advantage of that situation.
('24', 259, 1, 17, 599907) I feel, therefore, that this non violent struggle of ours has no room for any shouts of victory, or, if at all, only for those utteredin the right manner, at the right time and repeated the fewest times.
('24', 259, 1, 18, 600111) It would appear that volunteers in Calcutta have not been trained to keep order at meetings, for I have noted that, if the people are instructed beforehand, they generally obey the directions.
('24', 259, 1, 19, 600304) Expression of love cannot be forced on anyone.
('24', 259, 1, 20, 600351) If it is explained to the people that remaining quiet is also a sign of love or respect, they will immediately understand the idea.
('24', 259, 1, 21, 600483) I tried this experiment in two meetings.
('24', 259, 1, 22, 600524) My feet got crushed as I was passing through the mass of people and I was irritated by the sloganshouting.
('24', 259, 1, 23, 600631) At one place, it took me twenty minutes to reach the rostrum.
('24', 259, 1, 24, 600693) At both these places I devoted one fourth of my speech to the need for remaining quiet at meetings, preserving peace and making room for the leaders to pass.
('24', 259, 1, 25, 600851) The result, at both the places, was that on our leaving the meeting they made way for us, there was no slogan shouting and the people did not get up till we had left and so, while earlier it had taken twenty minutes to make our way through the crowd, it took only one minute while leaving.
('24', 259, 1, 26, 601141) From this experience, I judge that, if the people are given instructions in advance, they will certainly understand them and act
('24', 259, 2, 27, 601270) 1 In April 1919
('24', 260, 0, 1, 601286) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 261
('24', 260, 1, 2, 601331) accordingly.
('24', 260, 1, 3, 601344) It is my belief that by and large the people realize the need for preserving peace and are eager to do so Now let us suppose the converse of all this.
('24', 260, 1, 4, 601495) Imagine for a while that the people are all quietly seated.
('24', 260, 1, 5, 601555) Everybodys eyes and attention are turned to the leader who is the guest.
('24', 260, 1, 6, 601628) Imagine now that a quarrel starts somewhere in this peaceful gathering.
('24', 260, 1, 7, 601700) Imagine that everyone remains calmly seated where he is.
('24', 260, 1, 8, 601757) The result would be that the voice of the leader would reach every person in the audience.
('24', 260, 1, 9, 601848) He can even go to the men who are fighting and calm them.
('24', 260, 1, 10, 601906) Even if this does not happen, the fighting would not spread when nobody wants it and we would not be accused of disturbing public peace.
('24', 260, 1, 11, 602043) In the army, this is how they act.
('24', 260, 1, 12, 602078) Everyone keeps to his place.
('24', 260, 1, 13, 602107) No person can leave his place and go elsewhere till he is ordered to do so, nor can he interfere in other matters.
('24', 260, 1, 14, 602222) We, too, are a non violent army fighting for swaraj.
('24', 260, 1, 15, 602275) We also have to do our duty keeping to our own place.
('24', 260, 1, 16, 602329) We need not concern ourselves with what others are doing.
