('24', 269, 0, 1, 619925) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 269, 1, 2, 619967) called upon the Mussulmans to warn any Mussulman against serving in the Army and telling every Mussulman soldier that in terms of Islam it was a sin to serve in the British Army.
('24', 269, 1, 3, 620146) I am sorry that I was not present at that historic conference in Karachi and had I been present there and had the conference permitted me, I should also have been one of those who would have supported that resolution.
('24', 269, 1, 4, 620364) (Laughter,) Only a Mussulman can say whether it is a sin for a Mussulman to serve in the British Army at the present moment, but as a Hindu and as an Indian, I know what my duty and what the duty of every Hindu, every Indian, should be on such an occasion.
('24', 269, 1, 5, 620621) I know that it is a sin for a single Indian to serve either in the British Army, or in any of the civil departments of this Government, and if a public declaration of this character even in the presence of soldiers constituted the offence of tampering with the loyalty of the soldiers of the British Army, let me tell this meeting and through this meeting the Government of India, that I have committed the offence of tampering with the soldiers serving in the British Army, times without number.
('24', 269, 1, 6, 621118) Nor is it a new offence it was an offence deliberately committed by me in the month of September last year, and it was an offence committed also by the Indian National Congress in the month of September at Calcutta 1 and deliberately repeated at Nagpur 2. If neither the Congress nor I have hitherto gone to individual soldiers and individual employees in the Government departments, it is not because of want of will, but because of want of ability.
('24', 269, 1, 7, 621569) In our unfortunate country in which poverty is day by day deepening and in which starvation faces lakhs upon lakhs of our countrymen and countrywomen, it has not been possible for us, up now to call upon the soldiers individually, to appeal to them and ask them for the sake of their country and for the sake of their religion to give up their employment and do their duty.
('24', 269, 1, 8, 621943) What I venture to warn the Government is that as soon as the country has received and assimilated the gospel of the spinning wheel and swaraj and as soon as the soldiers and others are ready to take up the spinning wheel and the handloom, I promise that if I have got still the strength left in me and the personal liberty that is vouchsafed to me by this Government, I promise that I shall undertake to go to every one of the soldiers and every one of those who are serving in the civil departments of

('24', 270, 1, 2, 622597) Government to give up his employment and take up the spinning wheel; but even at this very moment, I invite every soldier who calls himself an Indian and every servant in Government employment that if he has understood the message of swadeshi, it is his bounden duty to have his employment under this Government which has emasculated this country, which has put affronts upon Islam and which has made itself responsible for the tragedy of Jallianwala Bagh.
('24', 270, 1, 3, 623054) I say that it is a sin for anybody to serve this Government and if they have got a hope in swadeshi they will do well to leave their employment under this Government.
('24', 270, 1, 4, 623221) The second reason given by the Government of Bombay is that these Brothers have made speeches inciting to violence.
('24', 270, 1, 5, 623337) I know the Brothers, I know almost all the speeches that they have delivered and I venture from this platform to deny that charge in toto.
('24', 270, 1, 6, 623476) The Brothers have ever, in private and in public, to my knowledge weaned the people from any tendency to violence, but I shall tell you the reason why the Government have laid their hands upon the two Brothers.
('24', 270, 1, 7, 623687) They are brave, they are truthful and they are lovers of their religion and their country and they have acquired an influence upon Indians such as no other Indians have acquired during their lifetime over them.

('24', 270, 1, 10, 624106) This Government has no room for brave people, for fearless people, for people who are truthful, who are lovers of their country and their religion and who have acquired an influence over the masses, but whilst I must analyse the mentality of this Government, and whilst I must draw your attention to the sins of this Government, I would warn you against becoming excited and going in for violence.

('24', 280, 2, 7, 647735) 146. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, DINDIGUL 1
('24', 280, 3, 8, 647777) September 21, 1921
('24', 280, 4, 9, 647796) The citizens of Dindigul presented Mahatmaji with purse in aid of the Smyrna and the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('24', 280, 4, 10, 647900) Mahatma Gandhi then made the following speech which was translated into Tamil by Dr. T. S. S. Rajan: When I saw your representatives in Trichinopoly insisting upon Maulana Saheb and myself coming to this town, I thought you would show me some extraordinary results of non co operation.
('24', 280, 4, 11, 648186) I had expected you all to be dressed in khaddar homespun and homewoven.
('24', 280, 4, 12, 648258) I had expected to find every house in Dindigul with a spinning wheel.
('24', 280, 4, 13, 648328) But I find only much noise and enthusiasm here....
('24', 280, 4, 14, 648379) If we want swaraj or the release of Ali Brothers and their comrades, our enthusiasm should be developed in the proper channel.
('24', 280, 4, 15, 648506) You have only three hundred spinning wheels in Dindigul; you have a population of thirty thousand of whom ten thousand are Mohammedans and twenty thousand are Hindus.
('24', 280, 4, 16, 648673) Counting five to a family on an average, you should have at least 6,000 families here with 6,000 spinning wheels running from day to day.
('24', 280, 4, 17, 648811) There is no swaraj without swadeshi.
('24', 280, 4, 18, 648848) Swadeshi means not only the production of our countrys needs, but also getting redress for the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs in a non violent way.
('24', 280, 4, 19, 648996) I understand that you are divided into petty factions.
('24', 280, 4, 20, 649051) There is certainly no swaraj if everyone wanted to mind his own business nor if Hindus wanted to observe their superiority or segregate the Panchamas.
('24', 280, 4, 21, 649202) Throughout my travel in this Presidency nothing had oppressed me so much as the untouchability.
('24', 280, 4, 22, 649298) I claim to be a sanatani Hindu with a due sense of my responsibility to my religion.
('24', 280, 4, 23, 649383) I venture to say that
('24', 280, 5, 24, 649405) 1 At the maidan near the Rock
('24', 281, 0, 1, 649435) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 281, 1, 2, 649477) there is no warrant in Hindu Shastras for untouchability.
('24', 281, 1, 3, 649535) Unless, therefore, we are prepared to give up treating human beings as less than dogs, we have no right to swaraj.
('24', 281, 1, 4, 649650) I have given you all the conditions necessary for the attainment of swaraj and redress for the Punjab and Khilafat grievances.
('24', 281, 1, 5, 649777) If the Muslims love their Khilafat as much as their lives, if the Muslims and their Hindu brethren love Ali Brothers and if the Hindus and the Muslims want swaraj they should all take to spinning and weaving.
('24', 281, 1, 6, 649986) Let Hindus and Muslims treat one another as their blood brothers and whilst each remains firm in his faith, each must sacrifice for the other, that we should all be non violent in spite of the gravest provocation that we might receive, that Hindus should put an end to untouchability and embrace their Panchama brethren.
('24', 281, 1, 7, 650307) I dont want you to eat and drink with them or have inter marriages.
('24', 281, 1, 8, 650375) But your Hinduism demands you to give an equal right to all human beings.
('24', 281, 1, 9, 650449) I want you to give the Panchama the same right which any human being has a right to ask of you and which you claim from all the rest.
('24', 281, 1, 10, 650583) These conditions being fulfilled, I have not a shadow of doubt that we will have swaraj within this year.
('24', 281, 1, 11, 650689) May God help us in our attempts.
('24', 281, 1, 12, 650722) The Hindu, 26 9 1921
('24', 281, 2, 13, 650743) 147. SPEECH AT MADURA
('24', 281, 3, 14, 650765) September 21, 1921
('24', 281, 4, 15, 650784) FRIENDS, I thank you for these addresses this evening.
('24', 281, 4, 16, 650839) We cannot attain swaraj by presentation of ten thousand addresses even.
('24', 281, 4, 17, 650911) It makes me very sad to hear all this noise and I do not propose to tax you with words which would tackle your patience.
('24', 281, 4, 18, 651032) You say in your addresses that this is a dharma war.
('24', 281, 4, 19, 651085) Demonstrations and noise of this kind are against swaraj.
('24', 281, 4, 20, 651143) I am sorry I came to Madura to see all this babble.
('24', 281, 4, 21, 651195) I hope your leaders will tell you what your duty is for the attainment of swaraj.
('24', 281, 4, 22, 651277) If you want dharma raj in India you must work your spinning wheel which is a sign of peace and Hindu Muslim united.
('24', 281, 4, 23, 651393) You should remove untouchability because the religion does not allow it.
('24', 281, 4, 24, 651466) You should see that drinking is completely stopped.
('24', 281, 4, 25, 651518) I hope your leaders would advise on all these points.
('24', 281, 4, 26, 651572) The Hindu, 26 9 1921
('24', 282, 0, 1, 651593) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 283
('24', 282, 1, 2, 651638) 148. NOTES
('24', 282, 3, 3, 651649) Bengal is a big province, and the reader will not be surprised if he finds these notes predominantly devoted to Bengal doings.
('24', 282, 3, 4, 651776) I have not hesitated to say in private conversations, that in point of swadeshi, of all the provinces Bengal stands at the bottom.
('24', 282, 3, 5, 651907) The mass appearance in a Bengal village or town does not wear the swadeshi stamp.
('24', 282, 3, 6, 651989) Khadi is least in evidence in Bengal.
('24', 282, 3, 7, 652027) But the signs of a coming revival are not wanting.
('24', 282, 3, 8, 652078) The charkha has not taken deep root as yet, as it has done elsewhere.
('24', 282, 3, 9, 652148) But it is becoming general everywhere.
('24', 282, 3, 10, 652187) I saw it in its diminutive form at Silchar and Sylhet.
('24', 282, 3, 11, 652242) It is almost a toy.
('24', 282, 3, 12, 652262) It is good enough for spinning, but its yield is very little.
('24', 282, 3, 13, 652324) It was more in evidence at Chittagong, and of a better type.
('24', 282, 3, 14, 652385) They have devised an ingenious little portable thing which the boys and girls like.
('24', 282, 3, 15, 652469) It is neat, beautiful and cheap.
('24', 282, 3, 16, 652502) But like the Silchar pattern it does not give as much yarn as the original type.
('24', 282, 3, 17, 652583) In Barisal, on the other hand.
('24', 282, 3, 18, 652614) we saw a clever contrivance in which you move the wheelwith a pedal.
('24', 282, 3, 19, 652683) They were not able to give me the yield of the machine.
('24', 282, 3, 20, 652739) But, I should not be surprised if it gives as much as the ancient wheel.
('24', 282, 3, 21, 652812) All these inventions show that the rentio 1 is growing in popularity and has come to stay.
('24', 282, 3, 22, 652903) In Barisal, moreover, it was a pleasure to see very fine and even yarn, turned out by the boys of the National School.
('24', 282, 3, 23, 653022) The quantity displayed was not to be despised.
('24', 282, 3, 24, 653069) The weaving shed in Barisal appeared to be nice, neat and roomy.
('24', 282, 3, 25, 653134) The looms were all fly shuttle after the Serampur style.
('24', 282, 3, 26, 653191) The organizers have under their control nearly 80 looms.
('24', 282, 3, 27, 653248) In an adjoining room they had stock worth about Rs. l5,000. They have not yet learnt the absolute necessity of using only hand spun yarn both for warp and woof.
('24', 282, 3, 28, 653409) I do urge upon all Congress organisations the paramount necessity of their using only hand spun yarn for both warp and woof.
('24', 282, 3, 29, 653534) The mixed thing has already become marketable.
('24', 282, 3, 30, 653581) And the Congress workers need notought not towaste their time over things which an ordinary trader can attend to.
('24', 282, 3, 31, 653695) But, of course, these looms and the few wheels I saw cannot clothe Bengal.
('24', 282, 3, 32, 653770) And Bengal cannot help the swaraj movement, if it has
('24', 282, 4, 33, 653824) 1 Spinning wheel
('24', 283, 0, 1, 653841) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 283, 1, 2, 653883) to depend upon Bombay and Ahmedabad for the cloth supply.
('24', 283, 1, 3, 653941) Just as a man forced to be hungry cannot be induced to think of God, so may not millions of Bengalis forced to remain in a state of semi starvation, think of or appreciate swaraj.
('24', 283, 1, 4, 654121) The first indispensable condition of swaraj is, that each province be comes self contained for its food and clothing.
('24', 283, 1, 5, 654239) But Bengal will not lag behind when once she fully awaken ed.
('24', 283, 1, 6, 654301) She has a fine imagination.
('24', 283, 1, 7, 654329) Her villages retain their simplicity.
('24', 283, 1, 8, 654367) Her sons are clever and pushful, her daughters graceful, simple and lovely.
('24', 283, 1, 9, 654443) Both men and women are intensely religious.
('24', 283, 1, 10, 654487) Their faith is ennobling.
('24', 283, 1, 11, 654513) The memory of the charkha is still alive.
('24', 283, 1, 12, 654555) Bengal has but to realize, that she manufactured the finest fabrics not merely for herself, not merely for India but for the outside world as well, and she will beat her own past record, glorious as it is.
('24', 283, 1, 13, 654761) Bengal is beginning to realize, that if her millions of women have forgotten the art of spinning, no other activity has replaced it, and that the root cause of her poverty as well as of the rest of India, is the enforced idleness of her peasantry.
('24', 283, 1, 14, 655009) I feel sure, that Bengal is about to understand the full message of the spinning wheel, and then she will take India by storm.
('24', 283, 1, 15, 655136) As a friend said, Bengal has to unlearn much.
('24', 283, 1, 16, 655182) Like several other provinces, she has not a clean slate to write upon.
('24', 283, 1, 17, 655253) She has for instance to unlearn that cloth woven in Dacca from foreign yarn is swadeshi.
('24', 283, 2, 18, 655342) OF STRIKES
('24', 283, 3, 19, 655353) The Assam Bengal Railway and the steamer strikes were out of the ordinary, the first attempt, as I have found, to have strikes out of sympathy for those outside labour unions.
('24', 283, 3, 20, 655529) The strikes were therefore sympathetic, humanitarian or political.
('24', 283, 3, 21, 655596) I had the pleasure of meeting the strikers all over the railway line, but specially at Gauhati, Chitttagong and Barisal.
('24', 283, 3, 22, 655717) Having talked to them freely, I have come to the conclusion, that the people did not fully realize the cost of their undertaking.
('24', 283, 3, 23, 655847) But having embarked on the strike, they have endeavoured to suffer the consequences.
('24', 283, 3, 24, 655932) It is always dangerous and uncharitable for an outsider to say, what he would have done if he had the handling of a situation.
('24', 283, 3, 25, 656059) But if one may hazard an opinion, I think that the labourers were not ready for a philanthropic strike.
('24', 283, 3, 26, 656163) In my opinion the labourers and artisans of India have not yet arrived at that degree of national consciousness, which is necessary for successful sympathetic strikes.
('24', 283, 3, 27, 656331) The fault is ours.
('24', 283, 3, 28, 656350) We, who have interested ourselves in national service, have not until recently studied the wants
('24', 284, 0, 1, 656447) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 285
('24', 284, 1, 2, 656492) and aspirations of these classes, nor taken the trouble of informing them of the political situation.
('24', 284, 1, 3, 656594) We have hitherto believed, that only those who had passed through high schools and colleges were fit to take part in national work.
('24', 284, 1, 4, 656726) It is hardly therefore proper to expect the labouring and the artisan class all of a sudden to appreciate, and sacrifice themselves for, interests outside their own.
('24', 284, 1, 5, 656892) We may not exploit them for political or any other ends.
('24', 284, 1, 6, 656949) The best service we can render them and take from them at the present stage is to teach them self help, to give them an idea of their own duties and rights, and put them in a position to secure redress of their own just grievances.
('24', 284, 1, 7, 657181) Then and not till then are they ready for political, national or humanitarian service.
('24', 284, 1, 8, 657268) Any premature precipitation of sympathetic strikes must therefore result in infinite harm to our cause.
('24', 284, 1, 9, 657372) In the programme of non violence, we must rigidly exclude the idea of gaining anything by embarrassing the Government.
('24', 284, 1, 10, 657491) If our activity is pure and that of the Government impure, the latter is embarrassed by our purity, if it does not itself become pure.
('24', 284, 1, 11, 657626) Thus, a movement of purification benefits both parties.
('24', 284, 1, 12, 657682) Whereas a movement of mere destruction leaves the destroyer unpurified, and brings him down to the level of those whom he seeks to destroy.
('24', 284, 1, 13, 657822) Even our sympathetic strikes therefore have to be strikes of self purification, i.e., non co operation.
('24', 284, 1, 14, 657926) And so, when we declare a strike to redress a wrong, we really cease to take part in the wrong, and thus leave the wrongdoer to his own resources, in other words enable him to see the folly of continuing the wrong.
('24', 284, 1, 15, 658141) Such a strike can only succeed when behind it is the fixed determination not to revert to service.
('24', 284, 1, 16, 658240) Speaking, therefore, as one having handled large successful strikes, I repeat the following maxims, already stated in these pages, for the guidance of all strike leaders: 1. There should be no strike without a real grievance.
('24', 284, 1, 17, 658466) 2. There should be no strike, if the persons concerned are not able to support themselves out of their own savings or by engaging in some temporary occupation, such as carding, spinning and weaving.
('24', 284, 1, 18, 658665) Strikers should never depend upon public subscriptions or other charity.
('24', 284, 1, 19, 658738) 3. Strikers must fix an unalterable minimum demand, and declare it before embarking upon their strike.
('24', 285, 0, 1, 658841) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 285, 1, 2, 658883) A strike may fail in spite of a just grievance and the ability of strikers to hold out indefinitely, if there are workers to replace them.
('24', 285, 1, 3, 659022) A wise man, therefore, will not strike for increase of wages or other comforts, if he feels that he can be easily replaced.
('24', 285, 1, 4, 659146) But a philanthropic or patriotic man will strike in spite of supply being greater than the demand, when he feels for and wishes to associate himself with his neighbours distress.
('24', 285, 1, 5, 659325) Needless to say, there is no room in a civil strike of the nature described by me for violence in the shape of intimidation, incendiarism or otherwise.
('24', 285, 1, 6, 659477) I should therefore be extremely sorry to find, that the recent derailment near Chittagong was due to mischief done by any of the strikers.
('24', 285, 1, 7, 659616) Judged by the tests suggested by me, it is clear that the friends of the strikers should never have advised them to apply for or receive Congress or any other public funds for their support.
('24', 285, 1, 8, 659807) The value of the strikers sympathy was diminished to the extent, that they received or accepted financial aid.
('24', 285, 1, 9, 659918) The merit of a sympathetic strike lies in the inconvenience and the loss suffered by the sympathizers.
('24', 285, 1, 10, 660021) As to what should be done now for or by the strikers, who have in spite of threats and temptations manfully held outand they are more than 50 per centI have already given my opinion to the Bengal Provincial Congress Committee.
('24', 285, 1, 11, 660248) And by that I wish to abide.
('24', 285, 1, 12, 660277) If the strikers struck on the sole issue of sympathy for the outraged coolies at Chandpur and without intimidating their brethren, they had every moral right to do so, and they showed an unexpected measure of patriotism and fellow feeling.
('24', 285, 1, 13, 660517) I hope that they will refuse to rejoin service, until the Government have fully and frankly apologized, and refunded to the parties concerned the monies paid for the repatriation of the coolies.
('24', 285, 2, 14, 660712) MISCHIEVOUS ASSIDUITY
('24', 285, 3, 15, 660734) There is a District Propaganda Committee at Barisal, which certainly deserves credit, if mere assiduity is any passport to credit.
('24', 285, 3, 16, 660865) Experience, however, shows, that assiduity, when it is mischievous, commands not credit, but incurs discredit.
('24', 285, 3, 17, 660976) Such, it seems to me, is the activity of the District Propaganda Committee of Barisal.
('24', 285, 3, 18, 661063) It is avowedly against non co operation.
('24', 285, 3, 19, 661104) When we reached Barisal, a registered letter was delivered to me containing certain questions for me to answer at the public meeting, that was to be addressed by Maulana Mahomed Ali and me.
('24', 285, 3, 20, 661294) The questions were printed.
('24', 285, 3, 21, 661322) They were delivered to one personally by hand also.
('24', 285, 3, 22, 661374) I answered every one
('24', 286, 0, 1, 661395) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 287
('24', 286, 1, 2, 661440) of the questions fully.
('24', 286, 1, 3, 661464) The next day, to my surprise, I had a report of the answers presented to me for correction.
('24', 286, 1, 4, 661556) The report was a Caricature of my answers.
('24', 286, 1, 5, 661599) Then followed a messenger, who handed me another batch of papers for reading and explaining.
('24', 286, 1, 6, 661692) And yet up to today I do not know the author of these communications.
('24', 286, 1, 7, 661762) They were all unsigned.
('24', 286, 1, 8, 661786) I have never known such irresponsibility on the part of a public body.
('24', 286, 1, 9, 661857) I was informed that the work was all done by Government officials, and therefore, at public expense.
('24', 286, 1, 10, 661958) I missed in all this attention shown to me the slightest desire for enlightenment or attempt to convince me of my error.
('24', 286, 1, 11, 662079) It would have been something, if the Committee had invited me and my companions to a discussion It would have been still betters if being a public body it had taken advantage of our presence to bring the parties together.
('24', 286, 1, 12, 662301) The only thing I discovered in this assiduous attention was an unholy desire to discredit the work of local non co operators.
('24', 286, 1, 13, 662427) I read this activity in the light of what I have seen during my Bengal tour.
('24', 286, 1, 14, 662504) There seems to me to be wilful and malicious misrepresentation of non co operation and non co operators.
('24', 286, 1, 15, 662609) I find misrepresentation of my views.
('24', 286, 1, 16, 662647) Sentences are torn from my speeches and distorted.
('24', 286, 1, 17, 662698) The latest is the exploiting of the interview I had the privilege of having with the Poet.
('24', 286, 1, 18, 662789) Fanciful and unauthorized reports have appeared in the Press.
('24', 286, 1, 19, 662851) Whilst there was nothing secret about it, the interview has been considered to be a secret.
('24', 286, 1, 20, 662943) It almost appears to be an attempt to divide us.
('24', 286, 1, 21, 662992) But it must fail.
('24', 286, 1, 22, 663010) The Poet is too great to be touched.
('24', 286, 1, 23, 663047) Non co operators must resolutely refuse to believe anything that is imputed to him.
('24', 286, 1, 24, 663131) There are differences of opinion between us.
('24', 286, 1, 25, 663176) They do not affect my regard for the Poet in any way whatsoever.
('24', 286, 1, 26, 663241) The Poet is as good a lover of India as I claim to be, and that love is an all sufficing bond between us.
('24', 286, 1, 27, 663347) I must therefore resolutely refuse to be drawn into the controversy raging round the interview.
('24', 286, 1, 28, 663443) But to return to the questions.
('24', 286, 1, 29, 663475) In spite of my feeling that the questions were mischievously put, I answered them, as I have said, at the public meeting.
('24', 286, 1, 30, 663597) I do not propose to reproduce my answers here in detail.
('24', 286, 1, 31, 663654) But the reader will find the questions themselves interesting and showing the manner of the precious [sic] propaganda.
('24', 286, 2, 32, 663773) [QUESTION:] 1. You have denounced political strikes.
('24', 286, 2, 33, 663826) Your followers here have supported the steamer strikes and spent thousands of rupees from Congress funds in feeding the strikers.
('24', 286, 2, 34, 663956) Is this right?
('24', 286, 2, 35, 663971) [ANSWER :] See my remarks on strikes.
('24', 287, 0, 1, 664009) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 287, 1, 2, 664051) 2. Many hundred boys have left schools and colleges under your orders, and now spend their time, insulting and intimidating peaceful and law abiding people.
('24', 287, 1, 3, 664208) What is going to be the future of these boys?
('24', 287, 1, 4, 664254) How will they earn their living?

('24', 287, 3, 20, 665267) We do not want to deprive our opponents of the necessary social services.

('24', 287, 4, 22, 665430) 5. Babu Sharat Kumar Ghosh, after his arrest for inciting the crowd to insult, loyalists said that there must be no water, light, or sweeper service in the town and the place should be turned into a burning ground.

('24', 287, 4, 26, 665844) But from the glowing accounts I have received about Sharat Babus very high character and spirituality, I must refuse to believe, that there is violence in Sharat Babu.
('24', 287, 4, 27, 666012) I feel sure that if he has committed a slip, he will be the first person to acknowledge his mistake.

('24', 287, 5, 29, 666202) Do you approve of it?
('24', 287, 5, 30, 666224) If not, how will you prevent your Followers
('24', 287, 6, 31, 666268) from doing such wrong in future?
('24', 287, 6, 32, 666301) My followers, I hope, are assimilating the spirit of non violence.
('24', 287, 6, 33, 666368) But if it ever comes to pass that they, under cover of non violence resort to violence, I hope to find myself the first victim
('24', 288, 0, 1, 666495) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 289
('24', 288, 1, 2, 666540) of their violence, but if by a stroke of ill luck or by my own cowardice I find myself alive, the snow white Himalayas will claim me as their own.
('24', 288, 2, 3, 666687) 7, 8 & 9: Is there enough swadeshi cloth in the county to clothe the inhabitants?
('24', 288, 2, 4, 666769) Will not the boycott of foreign cloth raise the price?
('24', 288, 2, 5, 666824) Is not the price too high already?

('24', 288, 5, 20, 667734) If the District Propaganda Committee will, instead of raising such questions, simply concentrate on multiplying spinning wheels and looms, there will be enough cloth and to spare, for famines will practically be things of the past.

('24', 288, 5, 22, 668002) If the people had money, they could get rice.

('24', 288, 5, 26, 668235) But the present swadeshi scheme requires every province to manufa cture its own cloth and spin its own yarn.

('24', 297, 1, 2, 687163) 150. THE LAST ACT?
('24', 297, 2, 3, 687182) The much talked of arrest of Maulana Mahomed Ali took place at Waltair, whilst we were on our way to Madras.
('24', 297, 2, 4, 687291) I am writing this in the train, just after writing out a few telegrams.
('24', 297, 2, 5, 687363) The train halted at Waltair for over twenty five minutes.
('24', 297, 2, 6, 687421) Maulana Mahomed Ali and I were going outside the Station to address a meeting.
('24', 297, 2, 7, 687500) Hardly had we gone a few paces from the entrance, when I heard the Maulana shouting to me and reading the notice given to him.
('24', 297, 2, 8, 687627) I was a few paces in front of him.
('24', 297, 2, 9, 687662) Two white men and half a dozen Indian police composed the party of arrest.
('24', 297, 2, 10, 687737) The officer in charge would not let the Maulana finish reading the notice, but grasped his arm and took the Maulana away.
('24', 297, 2, 11, 687859) With a smile on his lips he waved good bye.
('24', 297, 2, 12, 687903) I understood the meaning.
('24', 297, 2, 13, 687929) I was to keep the flag flying.
('24', 297, 2, 14, 687960) May God help me to prove worthy of the message of a comrade with whom it was a privilege to work.
('24', 297, 2, 15, 688058) I continued my journey to the meeting place.
('24', 297, 2, 16, 688103) I asked the people to remain calm, and fulfil the Congress programme.
('24', 297, 2, 17, 688173) I then retraced my steps, and went where the Maulana was being detained.
('24', 297, 2, 18, 688246) I asked the officer in charge whether I could see the Maulana.

('24', 300, 0, 1, 693385) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 301
('24', 300, 1, 2, 693430) 151. WANTED EXPERTS
('24', 300, 2, 3, 693450) Attacks on hand spinning notwithstanding, I cling to the belief, that swaraj is unattaianable without the beautiful art becoming universal in India.
('24', 300, 2, 4, 693599) The reasoning applied to the proposition is incredibly simple.
('24', 300, 2, 5, 693662) India cannot live unless her homes become self supporting.
('24', 300, 2, 6, 693721) They cannot become so, unless they have a supplementary occupation.
('24', 300, 2, 7, 693789) It will, therefore, not avail if all our cloth was manufactured in our mills.
('24', 300, 2, 8, 693867) If hand spinning became universal, every home would get a share of the crores and without any complicated machinery being necessary.
('24', 300, 2, 9, 694000) And India is able to manufacture all her own cloth.
('24', 300, 2, 10, 694052) It is understood, that when spinning becomes universal, the millions of weavers and lakhs of carders will revert to their original occupation.
('24', 300, 2, 11, 694195) This is the economic aspect of hand spinning.
('24', 300, 2, 12, 694241) It will save our women from forced violation of their purity.
('24', 300, 2, 13, 694303) It will, as it must, do away with begging as a means of livelihood.
('24', 300, 2, 14, 694371) It will remove our enforced idleness.
('24', 300, 2, 15, 694409) It will steady the mind.
('24', 300, 2, 16, 694434) And I verily believe, that when millions take to it as a sacrament, it will turn our faces godward.
('24', 300, 2, 17, 694534) This is the moral aspect of spinning.
('24', 300, 2, 18, 694572) And when it has become universal and traffic in foreign cloth has become a thing of the past, it is the surest sign that India is earnest, sober, and believes in the non violent and religious character of her struggle.
('24', 300, 2, 19, 694791) At present outsiders do not believe in our ability to boycott foreign cloth and to manufacture enough for our requirements by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('24', 300, 2, 20, 694949) But when it becomes an established fact, Indias opinion, too, will become an irresistible force, and if necessary, she can then, but not till then, resort to civil disobedience in order to bend a recalcitrant Government to its will.
('24', 300, 2, 21, 695182) This is the political aspect.
('24', 300, 2, 22, 695212) Therefore I was sad to see, that in all Bengal I found no one who was a spinning expert and who devoted his whole time and attention to nothing but spreading the gospel of hand spinning, teaching, organizing and advising.
('24', 300, 2, 23, 695434) I found, that the masses were ready to take it up but they did not know how to go about it.
('24', 300, 2, 24, 695526) What is true of Bengal is perhaps true of most provinces.
('24', 300, 2, 25, 695584) We should have in each province a
('24', 301, 0, 1, 695618) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 301, 1, 2, 695660) standard charkha and a body of experts to whom one can refer for advice and guidance.
('24', 301, 1, 3, 695746) Much splendid talent could be utilized, if there was expert knowledge available.
('24', 301, 1, 4, 695827) Who is to decide upon the utility or otherwise of over fifteen inventions that were exhibited in the National College Hall at Calcutta?
('24', 301, 1, 5, 695963) I saw everywhere different kinds of charkhas in use.
('24', 301, 1, 6, 696016) But I saw no attempt to test the capacity of these wheels.
('24', 301, 1, 7, 696075) Thousands are spinning today in Bengal, but there is nobody to measure their work.
('24', 301, 1, 8, 696158) I therefore advise all Congress Committees to set apart at least six men and six women with faith in their mission in this direction.
('24', 301, 1, 9, 696292) They need not look to Satyagraha Ashram for personal guidance.
('24', 301, 1, 10, 696355) What can be given is being imparted through the special articles that are being published weekly in these pages.
('24', 301, 1, 11, 696468) I ask those who would become experts to study them with careful attention.
('24', 301, 1, 12, 696543) But no one need expect to become an expert by merely studying those articles.
('24', 301, 1, 13, 696621) Practice alone will make one perfect.
('24', 301, 1, 14, 696659) Millions will spin for supplementing their resources, all will spin as a sacrament, some must spin for reducing it to a science.
('24', 301, 1, 15, 696788) These latter must spin during the initial stage for eight hours per day.
('24', 301, 1, 16, 696861) And as they spin on, they must match the quality of the yarn.
('24', 301, 1, 17, 696923) They must measure every day their output and the exact time they have worked.
('24', 301, 1, 18, 697001) They must learn the process of carding and weaving.
('24', 301, 1, 19, 697053) They must know the different qualities of cotton, they must know the different types of wheels, and they must be able to execute ordinary repairs.
('24', 301, 1, 20, 697200) We will not attain swaraj, unless we have organized ourselves in a methodical, intelligent and co operative manner.
('24', 301, 1, 21, 697316) Swadeshi means non co operation in the second great department of national life.
('24', 301, 1, 22, 697397) We are boycotting because we are now ready for manufacture of our cloth by hand spinning and hand weaving.
('24', 301, 1, 23, 697504) But we will not be able to sustain the boycott, unless each one of us becomes a spinner during the transition period and unless each province begins to organize its own production.
('24', 301, 1, 24, 697685) This cannot be done if we have not a number of experts in each province.
('24', 301, 1, 25, 697758) Young India, 22 9 1921
('24', 302, 0, 1, 697781) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 303
('24', 302, 1, 2, 697826) 152. MESSAGE ON LOIN CLOTH, MADURA
('24', 302, 2, 3, 697861) September 22, 1921
('24', 302, 3, 4, 697880) Only a few days are left for us to complete the boycott of foreign cloth enjoined by the All India Congress Committee.
('24', 302, 3, 5, 697999) It is not yet too late if every Congress worker will devote his and her exclusive attention to the boycott.
('24', 302, 3, 6, 698107) If everyone realizes that with out swadeshi, i.e., boycott of foreign cloth and manufacture of all the required cloth by hand spinning and hand weaving, there is no swaraj, and without swaraj there is no settlement of the Khilafat and the Punjab problems, there should be no difficulty in bringing about the desired boycott and the required manufacture.
('24', 302, 3, 7, 698461) I know that many will find it difficult to replace their foreign cloth all at once.
('24', 302, 3, 8, 698545) Millions are too poor to buy enough khaddar to replace the discarded cloth.
('24', 302, 3, 9, 698621) To them I repeat my advice given on the Madras Beach.
('24', 302, 3, 10, 698675) 1 Let them be satisfied with a mere loin cloth.
('24', 302, 3, 11, 698723) In our climate we hardly need more to protect our bodies during the warm months of the year.
('24', 302, 3, 12, 698816) Let there be no prudery about dress.
('24', 302, 3, 13, 698853) India has never insisted on full covering of the body for the males as a test of culture.
('24', 302, 3, 14, 698943) I give the advice under a full sense of my responsibility.
('24', 302, 3, 15, 699002) In order therefore to set the example I propose to discard at least up to the 31st of October my topi and vest and to content myself with only a loin cloth and a chaddar whenever found necessary for the protection of the body.
('24', 302, 3, 16, 699229) I adopt the change because I have always hesitated to advise anything I may not myself be prepared to follow, also because am anxious by leading the way to make it easy for those who cannot afford to change on discarding their foreign garments.
('24', 302, 3, 17, 699474) I consider the renunciation to be also necessary for me as a sign of mourning and a bare head and a bare body is such a sign in my part of the country.
('24', 302, 3, 18, 699626) That we are in mourning is more and more being borne home to me as the end of the year is approaching and we are still without swaraj.
('24', 302, 3, 19, 699761) I wish to state clearly that I do not expect co workers to renounce the use of vest and topi unless they find it necessary to do so for their own work.
('24', 302, 4, 20, 699913) 1 Vide Speech at Madras, 15 9 1921.
('24', 303, 0, 1, 699949) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 303, 1, 2, 699991) I am positive that every province and every district can, if there are enough workers, manufacture sufficient for its needs in one month.
('24', 303, 1, 3, 700129) And to that end for one month I advise complete suspension of every other activity but swadeshi.
('24', 303, 1, 4, 700226) I would even withdraw pickets from liquor shops trusting the drinker to recognize the new spirit of purification.
('24', 303, 1, 5, 700340) I would advise every non co operator to treat imprisonments as his ordinary lot in life and not think anything about them.
('24', 303, 1, 6, 700463) If only we can go through the course of organizing manufacture and collecting foreign cloth during the month of October abstaining from all meetings and excitement, we shall produce an atmosphere calm and peaceful enough to embark upon civil disobedience, if it is then found necessary.
('24', 303, 1, 7, 700750) But I have a settled conviction that if we exhibit the strength of character, the faculty of reorganizing and the power of exemplary self control all of which is necessary for full swadeshi, we shall attain swaraj without more.
('24', 303, 2, 8, 700978) M.K.GANDHI The Hindu, 23 9 1921
('24', 303, 3, 9, 701010) 153. SPEECH AT THIRUPPATHUR
('24', 303, 4, 10, 701038) September 22, 1921
('24', 303, 5, 11, 701057) The citizens of Thiruppathur presented Mahatmaji with an address in Tamil and a purse.
('24', 303, 5, 12, 701144) Mahatma Gandhi in the course of his reply said that in India twenty two crores of people had no work for six months in the year and that if every house would have a spinning wheel which could be worked for a few hours during leisure time by every member of the family, surely, then they would be able to supply the whole of India with swadeshi clothes adequately.
('24', 303, 5, 13, 701508) Cotton grew more than what they required for the adequate clothing of thirty two crores of people.
('24', 303, 5, 14, 701607) Till that time when all Indians were able to get adequate supply of hand woven and hand spun clothes, they (the Indians) should be ready even to wear a langoti and go out.
('24', 303, 5, 15, 701779) They should take pride in
('24', 303, 6, 16, 701805) wearing hand made clothes however coarse they might be.
('24', 303, 6, 17, 701861) Mahatmaji then explained why he had changed his dress and said that he would wear only a little piece of cloth until that time when Indians rich and poor alike would be able to get adequate supply of clothes.
('24', 303, 6, 18, 702070) Mahatmaji then said that he was immensely pleased to see in the address that the citizens of Thirupathur had almost stopped drinking and wished that drinking should be completely stopped not only in that place but also in other places around Thiruppathur.
('24', 303, 6, 19, 702326) He then exhorted them to accord an equal treatment to the Panchamas.

('24', 304, 3, 16, 703449) If we do this, surely then we could have swaraj and redress to the Punjab and Khilafat wrongs and the release of the Ali Brothers.

('24', 305, 3, 5, 704469) As I dont accept any costly gifts, your silver and gold plates will go to the Tilak Swaraj Fund.

('24', 305, 3, 9, 704926) Just as there is a horse in every house here, so there should be a spinning wheel in every house.
('24', 305, 3, 10, 705024) And as prayaschitta for our past sins, I expect every man andwoman to spin for at least some time every day during leisure hours.
('24', 305, 3, 11, 705154) I cannot be satisfied so long as I see that your dhotis are made of yarn from foreign countries.

('24', 305, 3, 13, 705423) But if you wear fine garments for pleasures sake and if you decline to wear garments hand spun and hand woven by our sisters, then there will be no swaraj for India.

('24', 305, 3, 16, 705885) So, I hope that from tomorrow you will boycott all foreign clothes and use only hand spun and hand woven clothes.
('24', 305, 3, 17, 705999) I hope also that there is no drink in your village.

('24', 306, 7, 18, 707554) 158. INTERVIEW TO DESHABHIMANI
('24', 306, 8, 19, 707585) TINNEVELLY September 23, 1921
('24', 306, 9, 20, 707615) The following is an account of the interview between Mahatma Gandhi and Mr. T. K. Madhavan, Editor, Deshabhimani, Quilon and a leader of the Ezhava 2 or Tiyya 3
('24', 306, 10, 21, 707776) community of Travancore at Tinnevelly.
('24', 306, 11, 22, 707815) T. K. MADHAVAN: Thank you Mahatmaji for having given me this opportunity of paying my respects to you.
('24', 306, 11, 23, 707918) My community has been much benefited morally much more than materiallyby your charkha movement.
('24', 306, 11, 24, 708014) Weaving and toddy drawing are the two hereditary professions of my community.
('24', 306, 11, 25, 708092) We supply the greatest part of labour in Malabar.
('24', 306, 11, 26, 708142) Before you took up swadeshi and the boycott of
('24', 306, 12, 27, 708189) 1 For the text of the letter vide Notes, 22 9 1921, under the subtitle Proof.
('24', 306, 13, 28, 708267) 2 Considered to be untouchables 3 ibid
('24', 307, 0, 1, 708306) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 307, 1, 2, 708348) foreign clothes other communities used to mock at us .
('24', 307, 1, 3, 708403) The enthusiasm you have created for Indian made clothes is partly responsible for the removal of social stigma attached to weaving.
('24', 307, 1, 4, 708535) We are trying to push up weaving .
('24', 307, 2, 5, 708570) MAHATMAJI: Very glad you push up hand weaving.
('24', 307, 3, 6, 708617) Total prohibition forms one of the chief items of our programme.

('24', 310, 5, 8, 715534) Mahatma Gandhi who appeared in a single loin cloth .

('24', 310, 6, 10, 715698) FRIENDS, I thank you for the address and the purse for the Tilak Swaraj Fund.
('24', 310, 6, 11, 715776) But more than for the address and the purse I wish to thank you for the absence of any noisy demonstrations.
('24', 310, 6, 12, 715885) I must confess to you that although these noisy demonstrations are a symbol of your affection and although behind them no mischief is meant they shake my nerves.
('24', 310, 6, 13, 716047) And what with the repetition of these demonstrations and with the delicate condition of my body I have become totally unfit for these noisy demonstrations.
('24', 310, 6, 14, 716203) If I had felt that these noises advance the cause of swaraj and the redress of the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs in the least little bit I would not have minded them.
('24', 310, 6, 15, 716371) But I know that for the great work that lies in front of us during the coming three months these noises are not only unnecessary but are harmful to the cause that is dear to you and me.
('24', 310, 6, 16, 716557) If we are to gain swaraj, if we are to redress the Khilafat and Punjab wrongs this year and if we are to receive the Ali Brothers and their associates, all our work must be silent, effective and determined.

('24', 313, 4, 9, 724420) DEAR COUNTRYMEN, Whilst the arrest of Maulanas Shaukat Ali and Mahomed Ali has touched every Indian heart, I know what it has meant to you.

('24', 324, 1, 27, 750662) I am positive that Islam does not sanction the use of force if it did, would not all Muslims openly avow so?
('24', 324, 1, 28, 750771) No religion in this world has spread through the use of force.
('24', 324, 1, 29, 750834) In my opinion, the history of Muslim empires which is taught to us entitles much exaggeration.
('24', 324, 1, 30, 750929) Victory on the Khilafat issue will certainly increase the strength of Muslims and enhance their courage, but to think that they
('24', 325, 0, 1, 751057) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 325, 1, 2, 751099) will use these against Hindus is to suggest that Muslims have no sense of honour, that it is in their nature to return evil for good, that, in other words, they have no true religion in them !
('24', 325, 1, 3, 751292) All my experience is to the contrary.
('24', 325, 1, 4, 751330) I have known honour and honesty in a great many Muslims.
('24', 325, 1, 5, 751387) Hindu Muslim unity, however, does not mean that no Muslim or Hindu will ever make a mistake.
('24', 325, 1, 6, 751480) If we remain unperturbed even if somebody makes a mistake, then only can it be said that unity is a living reality.
('24', 325, 1, 7, 751596) But let us think over this problem a little more.
('24', 325, 1, 8, 751646) The Government does not forcibly cut off the tuft of hair on our head but has it left a soul in us ?
('24', 325, 1, 9, 751747) Compared to the violence of the Government, I think the violence of the Moplahs is not worth speaking of.
('24', 325, 1, 10, 751853) The other day, in an instant a Government official had people stripped of khadi and thus, both Hindus and Muslims, of their dharma.
('24', 325, 1, 11, 751985) Who deprived both Hindus and Muslims of their manliness ?
('24', 325, 1, 12, 752043) We simply do not have the strength to face the armed might of the Government.
('24', 325, 1, 13, 752121) We were not reduced to such straits during the Mughal rule.
('24', 325, 1, 14, 752181) I can right now devise methods of fighting the armed strength of the Moplahs with similar strength.
('24', 325, 1, 15, 752281) Against the military might of the Government, however, I, though I pride myself on my knowledge of these matters, cannot discover a method of armed struggle, nor have the Ali Brothers succeeded in discovering any.
('24', 325, 1, 16, 752495) Moreover, the preservation of Hindu Muslim unity depends upon the acceptance of peaceful methods by both the communities.
('24', 325, 1, 17, 752617) Leaders of both communities must agree to settle their disputes exclusively through peaceful means, that is, through the good offices of arbitrators.
('24', 325, 1, 18, 752767) Finally, those Hindus who have been forcibly converted to Islam ought not to be looked upon as Muslims or regarded as defiled, they have every right to be counted as Hindus.
('24', 325, 1, 19, 752941) They stand in no need at all of going through purificatory rites.
('24', 325, 1, 20, 753007) I should also add that every Muslim who heard the stories of Moplah atrocities was pained by them, and also that, if our people were allowed to go there at this time, the Moplahs themselves would apologize for their deeds.
('24', 325, 1, 21, 753230) I am sure that they will positively apologize when we have swaraj.
('24', 325, 1, 22, 753297) All that they know is fighting.
('24', 325, 1, 23, 753329) They are our ignorant brethren.
('24', 325, 1, 24, 753361) The Government of course has done nothing to
('24', 326, 0, 1, 753406) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 327
('24', 326, 1, 2, 753451) reform them but neither have we done anything.
('24', 326, 1, 3, 753498) Is not this the fault of the Hindus of Malabar?
('24', 326, 1, 4, 753546) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 25 9 1921
('24', 326, 2, 5, 753583) 165. MY NOTES
('24', 326, 3, 6, 753597) MOPLAH RIOTS
('24', 326, 4, 7, 753610) There is no doubt that the Moplah riots have been a great set back.
('24', 326, 4, 8, 753678) In Madras Presidency, they are becoming sceptical about Hindu Muslim unity.
('24', 326, 4, 9, 753754) Many feel that people will not remain peaceful to the end.
('24', 326, 4, 10, 753813) Others have been dazed.
('24', 326, 4, 11, 753837) Not that they do not attend public meetings or take part in other activities; there is, however, widespread fear about how things will develop.
('24', 326, 4, 12, 753981) Hundreds of Moplahs have been killed and the killing is still going on.
('24', 326, 4, 13, 754053) As a result, the swadeshi movement has come to a stop in Malabar.
('24', 326, 4, 14, 754119) That is what the Government wanted.
('24', 326, 4, 15, 754155) The declaration of martial law has given an excellent opportunity to the Government to suppress the swadeshi movement.
('24', 326, 4, 16, 754274) It is said that, with the declaration of martial law, khadi clothes worn by people were torn away and thrown into fire.
('24', 326, 4, 17, 754394) Khadi caps, spinning wheels, etc., were among the things burnt.
('24', 326, 4, 18, 754458) The result was that khadi caps and spinning wheels, which used to be displayed in the shops of Calicut, had disappeared in one day.
('24', 326, 4, 19, 754590) If the Moplahs had not turned mad these intolerable consequences would not have followed.
('24', 326, 4, 20, 754680) If they had not indulged in killing and bloodshed, any officer who dared to burn khadi clothes today would have been dismissed or khadi would have become more popular; but the Moplahs lunacy has produced the opposite result.
('24', 326, 4, 21, 754905) They themselves knew nothing about swadeshi and the rest are a cowardly lot.
('24', 326, 4, 22, 754982) These do not mind wearing khadi but they still do not have the strength to die.
('24', 326, 4, 23, 755062) Hence, out of fear, they forsook khadi and the spinning wheel.
('24', 326, 4, 24, 755125) We have an important lesson to learn from this.
('24', 326, 4, 25, 755173) We wear khadi and put on a khadi cap as a matter of religious duty.
('24', 326, 4, 26, 755241) It should be impossible for anyone, with threats and intimidation, to make us give them up.
('24', 326, 4, 27, 755333) We ought to be ready always to lay down our lives for swadeshi and should display greater zeal for popularizing khadi.
('24', 326, 5, 28, 755452) ALL HONOUR TO THAT DEVOTED WIFE
('24', 326, 6, 29, 755484) I marvel at the courage displayed by the Begum Sahiba of
('24', 327, 0, 1, 755541) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 327, 1, 2, 755583) Maulana Mahomed Ali.
('24', 327, 1, 3, 755604) When she returned after visiting her husband who had been arrested at Waltair, I asked her if she was in any way afraid.
('24', 327, 1, 4, 755725) She said she had no fear of any sort, that the arrest was to come and that her husband had done no more than his duty.
('24', 327, 1, 5, 755844) I found no trace of nervousness in her tone.
('24', 327, 1, 6, 755889) Even after the arrest, she has been touring with us and has kept up her courage.
('24', 327, 1, 7, 755970) She attends both mens and womens meetings, wearing a burka, and makes brief speeches which go straight to the heart.
('24', 327, 1, 8, 756087) She advises everybody to remain peaceful, to wear khadi and ply the spinning wheel.
('24', 327, 1, 9, 756171) She appeals to Muslims for contributions to the Smyrna Fund.
('24', 327, 1, 10, 756232) Only a few months ago, her love for luxury knew no limit.
('24', 327, 1, 11, 756290) She was very fond of fine cloth.
('24', 327, 1, 12, 756323) Today she wears a green gown made of coarse khadi.
('24', 327, 1, 13, 756374) A Muslim woman needs to wear many more garments than her Hindu sister, and the Begum Sahiba carries no light body.
('24', 327, 1, 14, 756489) Even so, she submits to these hardships for the sake of her religion and country.
('24', 327, 1, 15, 756571) As a result, Muslim sisters too come out everywhere so that they may have her darshan.
('24', 327, 1, 16, 756658) I find that the attire of Muslim sisters in the Madras Presidency is very plain.
('24', 327, 1, 17, 756739) While there is no limit to the variety of colours in the costumes of Hindu women, in the attire of Muslim sisters I see nothing but white, rough cloth.
('24', 327, 1, 18, 756891) This is a very holy sight to me.
('24', 327, 1, 19, 756924) The variously coloured saris of Hindu women disagreeable to me at the present hour.Absence of Swadeshi The use of swadeshi seems to have spread even less in the Madras Presidency than in Bengal and, among the women one may say that it is practically nil.
('24', 327, 1, 20, 757179) But I have been assured that efforts in this direction will he intensified now.
('24', 327, 1, 21, 757259) Love for spinning has spread spontaneously among the poor.
('24', 327, 1, 22, 757318) Merchants in Madras told me that the demand for foreign cloth in that part was very small and the sale of swadeshi goods had gone up very much.
('24', 327, 1, 23, 757462) This may well be so.
('24', 327, 1, 24, 757483) If it is, it is plain that the spread of swadeshi owes little to the efforts of Congress workers and that the awakening has been spontaneous.
('24', 327, 2, 25, 757625) MADRAS LEADERS
('24', 327, 3, 26, 757640) The blame for this poor spread of swadeshi certainly lies with the leaders.
('24', 327, 3, 27, 757716) And yet, the number of voluntary workers in Madras is by no means small, and Shri Rajagopalacharis ability and Dr. Rajans devotion are of the highest.
('24', 327, 3, 28, 757867) But these workers had to create a new climate, and they came up against many difficulties.
('24', 327, 3, 29, 757958) The fact that they have not been deterred by the difficulties and are carrying on the
('24', 328, 0, 1, 758044) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 329
('24', 328, 1, 2, 758089) work despite them is as surprising as it is gratifying.
('24', 328, 1, 3, 758145) I have great faith in the Madras peoples regard for dharma.
('24', 328, 1, 4, 758205) The masses are as simple hearted as in other provinces.
('24', 328, 1, 5, 758261) Their capacity for hard work is unlimited.
('24', 328, 1, 6, 758304) One cannot be certain, therefore, that Madras, which is in the rear today, will never be in the forefront.
('24', 328, 1, 7, 758411) Madras has weavers in plenty and their skill is of the highest order.

('24', 328, 1, 9, 758531) They have undertaken to use hand spun yarn exclusively.

('24', 333, 1, 2, 765645) 172. SPEECH IN REPLY TO MUNICIPAL ADDRESS, SALEM
('24', 333, 2, 3, 765694) September 27, 1921 I thank you sincerely for your beautiful address and the beautiful casket in which the address has been put.
('24', 333, 2, 4, 765822) As you are aware, I have not anything to put silver plates and silver caskets into.
('24', 333, 2, 5, 765906) The silver will therefore be devoted to public purposes.
('24', 333, 2, 6, 765963) I congratulate the Salem Municipality on the record of progress which you have shown in your address.
('24', 333, 2, 7, 766065) The more so, in that, your schools freely admit the Panchama children and that your Council contains a Panchama councillor.
('24', 333, 2, 8, 766189) Nothing less can be expected of a place which has contributed to the Congress, its President 1 and one of its Chief Secretaries.
('24', 333, 2, 9, 766318) You have told me that you are willing to do all that you can within the compass of your act.
('24', 333, 2, 10, 766411) for non co operation.
('24', 333, 2, 11, 766433) You have here mentioned the three chief things on which the attention of non co operators is concentrated and if you add two more things, I think that you complete very nearly the programme of non co operation.
('24', 333, 2, 12, 766644) I have not a shadow of doubt that your Act permits you to remain non violent and to spread the gospel non violence throughout the Salem District or throughout your town and I am sure also that your Municipal Act does not prevent you from promoting Hindu Muslim unity.
('24', 333, 2, 13, 766912) Then the last two things and temperance can best be promoted by concentrating our attention upon swadeshi and though I see more progress in swadeshi in Salem than elsewhere in the Madras Presidency I am not at all satisfied for all you have done for swadeshi.
('24', 333, 2, 14, 767172) I do not know whether the councillors have religiously carried out the gospel of swadeshi in their homes.
('24', 333, 2, 15, 767278) I do not know whether the councillors have qualified themselves for swadeshi propaganda by becoming themselves accomplished spinners.
('24', 333, 2, 16, 767412) I have a suspicion that in all your municipal schools you have not yet made spinning compulsory.
('24', 333, 2, 17, 767509) I invite you to follow the example of the Municipality of Lahore for prescribing khaddar dress for all municipal employees, and you know what the introduction of spinning wheel and khaddar means to your town.
('24', 333, 2, 18, 767718) I assure you that it adds 25 per cent to the total income of the town.
('24', 333, 2, 19, 767789) I know that you are a great weaving centre and if the Municipality will do its duty it can
('24', 333, 3, 20, 767880) 1 C. Vijayaraghavachariar
('24', 334, 0, 1, 767906) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 335
('24', 334, 1, 2, 767951) easily persuade the weavers not to touch the Japanese or any other foreign yarn and so you have a great programme of swadeshi which no act that can possibly be devised by the Madras Government can prevent you from following and you can copy the example of the Thana Municipality to undertake picketing liquor shops for yourselves and if you have sufficient funds you can devote, also like the Thana District Board, certain amount to the Congress Committee and the Khilafat Committee for picketing liquor shops.
('24', 334, 1, 3, 768462) After all, our movement is one of self purification and searching self respect.
('24', 334, 1, 4, 768542) There are other ways in which we can perform both these processes and I feel sure that the Salem Municipality will not remain behind in self purification and assertion of self respect, and I thank you once more for your address.
('24', 334, 1, 5, 768771) The Hindu, 29 9 1921
('24', 334, 2, 6, 768792) 173. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SALEM 1
('24', 334, 3, 7, 768831) September 27, 1921
('24', 334, 4, 8, 768850) After addresses were read by the District Congress Committee, the Vanniakula Kshatriyas and the Sowrashtra community, Mr. C. Vijayaraghavachariar was voted to the Chair.
('24', 334, 4, 9, 769020) Mahatmaji .
('24', 334, 4, 10, 769032) said that the more ill advised the prosecution was, the more innocent the Ali Brothers were, the more successful would be our efforts to attain our goal by suffering.
('24', 334, 4, 11, 769199) He said that the answer to the prosecution was a complete and immediate boycott of foreign cloth and the introduction of the spinning wheel in every house.
('24', 334, 4, 12, 769355) He then laid great emphasis on the removal of untouchability.

('24', 335, 5, 9, 770302) AFFLICTED MADRAS
('24', 335, 6, 10, 770319) Madras is suffering from many afflictions.
('24', 335, 6, 11, 770362) It has its Brahmin and Non Brahmin problem, it has its Panchama problem, it has its labour problem, it has repression of a severe type such as is always to be met with where a Governor is amiable but hopelessly weak and dependent purely upon his advisers.
('24', 335, 6, 12, 770618) The Chirala Perala repression 1 I have already noticed.
('24', 335, 6, 13, 770674) Now the Government is trying to exact from an unwilling peasantry a grazing tax which it can ill afford to pay.
('24', 335, 6, 14, 770786) I understand that in its mad pursuit after collection, the Government impounded about 200 cattle, some of which were torn from their calves.
('24', 335, 6, 15, 770927) The cattle were taken to a pound where there was neither sufficient water nor fodder.
('24', 335, 6, 16, 771013) That took place in the Andhra country.
('24', 335, 6, 17, 771052) Near Trichinopoly where I am writing these notes, there is a place called Karur with a population of about 20,000. Its people have done good work in the cause of temperance.
('24', 335, 6, 18, 771226) Now about 40 persons, all members of the local Congress Committee, have been arrested for alleged complicity in all investment of a theatre by the rowdies of the place, consequent upon its managers refusal to pay the subscription to a charity or to the Tilak Swaraj FundI do not know which.
('24', 335, 6, 19, 771517) This investment took place some time ago.
('24', 335, 6, 20, 771559) The crowd was dispersed.
('24', 335, 6, 21, 771584) But now these men have been arrested.
('24', 335, 6, 22, 771622) All over, there is talk of repression.
('24', 335, 6, 23, 771661) And possibly there will be still more after the arrest of the Ali Brothers.
('24', 335, 6, 24, 771737) The people however have kept calm, brave and non violent.
('24', 335, 7, 25, 771795) 1 Vide Chirala Perala 25 8 1921.

('24', 336, 1, 2, 771873) The Malabar trouble is out of the ordinary, but it has filled its cup of woe.
('24', 336, 1, 3, 771951) Panic has so far possessed the Government, that one does not know what they will do next moment.
('24', 336, 1, 4, 772048) There is a Pudukkottai Raj near here.
('24', 336, 1, 5, 772086) I had to go to a group of villages.
('24', 336, 1, 6, 772122) I was to pass through the Raj on my way.
('24', 336, 1, 7, 772163) Even this was too much for the Raj, and I received the following letter:
('24', 336, 2, 8, 772236) We have reason to believe that you are intending to proceed on the 20th instant from Trichinopoly to Chettinad; we are further informed that you proposed to travel by road through this State.
('24', 336, 3, 9, 772428) Assuming that this information is correct, I write to say that you will not be allowed to pass through this State.
('24', 336, 3, 10, 772543) If you attempt to do so, you will be stopped at the frontier by the Police.
('24', 336, 3, 11, 772619) I merely wrote as follows in reply: 1
('24', 336, 4, 12, 772657) I regard everything that these States do as an indirect act of the Government.
('24', 336, 4, 13, 772736) But as I consider them to be more helpless than the direct British subjects, I have always thought it necessary for non co operators not to give battle to them.
('24', 336, 4, 14, 772897) It would create needless complications.
('24', 336, 4, 15, 772937) But one cannot help noticing the insanity of refusing even a passage through a place.
('24', 336, 4, 16, 773023) And what could I have done to the subjects of the State but preach on temperance, swadeshi and untouchability?
('24', 336, 5, 17, 773134) THE PANCHAMAS
('24', 336, 6, 18, 773148) But I must resist the temptation of dealing with the varied problems.
('24', 336, 6, 19, 773218) As in all my Madras speeches, I have dealt most with the Panchama, i.e., the untouchables, problem, I propose to deal briefly with it in these notes.
('24', 336, 6, 20, 773368) Nowhere is the untouchable so cruelly treated as in this Presidency.
('24', 336, 6, 21, 773437) His very shadow defiles the Brahmin.
('24', 336, 6, 22, 773474) He may not even pass through Brahmin streets.
('24', 336, 6, 23, 773520) Non Brahmins treat him no better.
('24', 336, 6, 24, 773554) And between the two, the Panchama as he is called in these parts is ground to atoms.
('24', 336, 6, 25, 773639) And yet Madras is a land of mighty temples and religious devotion.
('24', 336, 6, 26, 773706) The people with their big tilak marks, their long locks and their bare clean bodies look like rishis 2. But their religion seems almost to be exhausted in these outward observances.
('24', 336, 6, 27, 773888) It is difficult to understand this Dyerism towards the most industrious

('24', 337, 1, 2, 774087) and useful citizens in a land that has produced Sankara and Ramanuja.
('24', 337, 1, 3, 774157) And in spite of the Satanic treatment of our own kith and kin in this part of India, I retain my faith in these Southern people.
('24', 337, 1, 4, 774286) I have told them at all their huge meetings in no uncertain terms, that there can be no swaraj without the removal of this curse from our midst.
('24', 337, 1, 5, 774431) I have told them, that our being treated as social lepers in practically the whole world is due to our having treated a fifth of our own race as such.
('24', 337, 1, 6, 774582) Non co operation is a plea for a change of heart, not merely in the English but equally in ourselves.
('24', 337, 1, 7, 774684) Indeed, I expect the change first in us and then as a matter of course in the English.
('24', 337, 1, 8, 774771) A nation that can throw away an age long curse in a year, a nation that can shed the drink habit as we shed our garments, a nation that can return to its original industry and suddenly utilize its spare hours to manufacture sixty crores worth of cloth during a single year is a transformed nation.
('24', 337, 1, 9, 775069) Its transformation must react upon the world.
('24', 337, 1, 10, 775115) It must constitute even for the scoffer a convincing demonstration of Gods existence and grace, and so I say, that if India can become transformed in this wise, no power on earth can deny Indias right to establish swaraj.
('24', 337, 1, 11, 775337) In spite of all the clouds that are thickening on the Indian horizon, I make bold to prophesy, that the moment India has repented for her treatment of the untouchable and has boycotted foreign cloth, that moment India will be hailed, by the very English officials who seem to have hardened their hearts, as a free and a brave nation.
('24', 337, 1, 12, 775671) And because I believe, that if Hindus will, it is possible for them to enfranchise the so called Panchamas and extend to them the same rights that they claim for themselves, and it is possible for India, if she wills, to manufacture all the cloth she needs even as she cooks all the food she eats.
('24', 337, 1, 13, 775969) I therefore also believe that swaraj is attainble this year.

('24', 337, 1, 15, 776114) But it can take place if Gods grace is with us.
('24', 337, 1, 16, 776162) Who can deny that God is working a wonderful change in the hearts of every one of us?
('24', 337, 1, 17, 776248) Anyway it is the duty of every Congress worker everywhere to befriend the untouchable brother, and to plead with the un Hindu Hindus, that Hinduism of the Vedas, the Upanishads, Hinduism of the Bhagavad Gita and of Sankara and Ramanuja contains no warrant for treating a single human being, no matter how fallen, as an untouchable.
('24', 337, 1, 18, 776580) Let every Congressman plead in the gentlest manner possible with orthodoxy, that the bar sinister is the very negation of ahimsa.

('24', 338, 2, 4, 776775) Babu Motilal Ghosh, whose mind is fresh like that of a youth though he is too frail even to move, summoned Maulana Mahomed Ali and me chiefly to urge us to invite the lawyers to the Congress fold and in effect to restore them to their original status of unquestioned leadership of public opinion.

('24', 338, 2, 17, 778417) Courage, endurance, fearlessness and above all self sacrifice are the qualities required of our leaders.

('24', 340, 2, 5, 782030) A PERTINENT QUESTIONS
('24', 340, 3, 6, 782052) I paraphrase below what a friend writes regarding the influence of the Moplah outbreak on Hindu Muslim unity:
('24', 340, 4, 7, 782162) I am a staunch believer in Hindu Muslim unity.
('24', 340, 4, 8, 782209) But this Moplah outbreak has raised doubts in me.
('24', 340, 4, 9, 782259) Success in the Khilafat means strength to Islam.
('24', 340, 4, 10, 782308) Strength to Islam means attempts at conversion.
('24', 340, 4, 11, 782356) Have we not often been given the choice between Islam and the sword?
('24', 340, 4, 12, 782425) Can people such as the Moplahs learn the beauty of non violence?
('24', 340, 4, 13, 782490) And even if they appreciate non violence for the sake of their faith, will they not use violence for the sake of spreading their faith ?
('24', 340, 4, 14, 782627) My belief in the necessity of Hindu Muslim unity is there.
('24', 340, 4, 15, 782686) But do you not think that the questions I have raised are relevant?
('24', 340, 4, 16, 782754) The questions are indeed relevant, if only because they have occurred to one so sane as the writer is.
('24', 340, 4, 17, 782857) But in my opinion there is a misunderstanding about the whole question.
('24', 340, 4, 18, 782929) Our advocacy of the Khilafat would be wrong if Islam were based on force.
('24', 340, 4, 19, 783003) There is nothing in the Koran to warrant the use of force for conversion.
('24', 340, 4, 20, 783077) The holy book says in the clearest language possible, There is no compulsion in religion. The Prophets whole life is a repudiation of compulsion in religion.
('24', 340, 4, 21, 783235) No Mussulman, to my knowledge, has ever approved of compulsion.
('24', 340, 4, 22, 783299) Islam would cease to be a world religion if it were to rely upon force for its propagation.
('24', 340, 4, 23, 783391) Secondly, historically speaking, the charge of conversion to Islam by force cannot be proved against its followers as a body.
('24', 340, 4, 24, 783517) And whenever attempts have been made to convert by force, responsible Mussulmans have repudiated such conversions.
('24', 340, 4, 25, 783632) Thirdly, the conception of Hindu Muslim unity does not pre suppose a total absence for all time of wrong by any of the parties.
('24', 340, 4, 26, 783760) On the contrary it assumes, that our loyalty to the unity will survive shocks such as the forcible conversions by Moplahs, that in every such case we shall not blame the whole body of the followers but seek relief against individuals by way of arbitration and not by way of reprisals.
('24', 340, 4, 27, 784045) Fourthly, acceptance of non violence for organizing Indias freedom involves acceptance of non violence for Hindu Muslim solidarity.
('24', 340, 4, 28, 784177) The Moplahs have certainly broken the rule.

('24', 341, 1, 4, 784427) Fifthly, we need not suspect any evil befalling India under swaraj for it is tolerably certain, that had the Congress and the Khilafat workers been permitted to penetrate the Moplah territories, they would have been able to nip the evil in the bud.

('24', 342, 2, 11, 787556) A BRAVE WOMAN

('24', 342, 3, 13, 787750) She began, last time we were in Bombay, to assist her husband publicly in his work.

('24', 342, 3, 18, 788107) Her speeches lost nothing in effect for brevity, and I do not know that she could not give lessons to her husband in the art of saying as much as possible in as few words as possible.

('24', 343, 3, 17, 790773) Six voted with reservations, and only five voted against prohibition.

('24', 344, 1, 2, 791489) 176. TAMPERING WITH LOYALTY 1
('24', 344, 2, 3, 791519) His Excellency the Governor of Bombay had warned the public some time ago, that he meant businesses, that he was no longer going to tolerate the speeches that were being made.
('24', 344, 2, 4, 791695) In his note on the Ali Brothers and others he has made clear his meaning.
('24', 344, 2, 5, 791769) The Ali Brothers are to be charged with having tampered with the loyalty of the sepoy and with having uttered sedition.
('24', 344, 2, 6, 791889) I must confess, that I was not prepared for the revelation of such hopeless ignorance on the part of the Governor of Bombay.
('24', 344, 2, 7, 792014) It is evident that he has not followed the course of Indian history during the past twelve months.
('24', 344, 2, 8, 792113) He evidently does not know, that the National Congress began to tamper with the loyalty of the sepoy in September last year, that the Central Khilafat Committee began it earlier and that I began it earlier still, for I must be permitted to take the credit or the odium of suggesting, that India had a right openly to tell the sepoy and everyone who served the Government in any capacity whatsoever, that he participated in the wrongs done by the Government.
('24', 344, 2, 9, 792571) The Conference at Karachi merely repeated the Congress declaration in terms of Islam.
('24', 344, 2, 10, 792657) Only a Mussulman divine can speak for Islam, but speaking for Hinduism and speaking for nationalism, I have no hesitation in saying, that it is sinful for anyone, either as soldier or civilian, to serve this Government which has proved treacherous to the Mussulmans of India and which has been guilty of the inhumanities of the Punjab.
('24', 344, 2, 11, 792993) I have said this from many a platform in the presence of sepoys.
('24', 344, 2, 12, 793058) And if I have not asked individual sepoys to come out, it has not been due to want of will but of ability to support them.
('24', 344, 2, 13, 793181) I have not hesitated to tell the sepoy, that if he could leave the service and support himself without the Congress or the Khilafat aid, he should leave at once.
('24', 344, 2, 14, 793343) And I promise, that as soon as the spinning wheel finds an abiding place in every home and Indians begin to feel that weaving gives anybody any day an honourable livelihood, I shall not hesitate, at the peril of being shot, to ask the Indian sepoy individually to leave his service and become a weaver.
('24', 344, 2, 15, 793646) For, has not the sepoy been used to hold India under subjection, has he not been used to murder innocent people at Jallianwala Bagh, has he not been used to drive away innocent men,

('24', 345, 1, 3, 794133) How can any Indian having a spark of humanity in him and any Mussulman having any pride in his religion feel otherwise than as the Ali Brothers have done?
('24', 345, 1, 4, 794288) The sepoy has been used more often as a hired assassin than as a soldier defending the liberty or the honour of the weak and the helpless.

('24', 348, 2, 7, 800466) 179. MY LOIN CLOTH 1
('24', 348, 3, 8, 800487) [October 2, 1921] All the alterations I have made in my course of life have been effected by momentous occasions; and they have been made after such a deep deliberation that I have hardly had to regret them.
('24', 348, 3, 9, 800695) And I did them, as I could not help doing them.
('24', 348, 3, 10, 800743) Such a radical alteration in my dress,I effected in Madura.
('24', 348, 3, 11, 800803) I had first thought of it in Barisal.
('24', 348, 3, 12, 800841) When, on behalf of the famine stricken at Khulna, I was twitted that I was burning cloth utterly regardless of the fact that they were dying of hunger and nakedness, I felt that I should content myself with a mere loincloth and send on my shirt and dhoti to Dr. Roy, for the Khulna people.
('24', 348, 3, 13, 801131) But I restrained my emotion.
('24', 348, 3, 14, 801160) It was tinged with egotism.
('24', 348, 3, 15, 801188) I knew that the taunt was groundless.
('24', 348, 3, 16, 801226) The Khulna people were being helped, and only a single zemindar could have sent all the relief necessary.
('24', 348, 3, 17, 801332) I needed therefore nothing to do there.
('24', 348, 3, 18, 801372) The next occasion came when my friend Maulana Mahomed Ali was arrested before my very eyes.
('24', 348, 3, 19, 801464) I went and addressed a meeting soon after his arrest.
('24', 348, 3, 20, 801518) I thought of dispensing with my cap and shirt that moment, but then I restrained myself fearing that I might create a scene.
('24', 348, 3, 21, 801643) The third occasion came during my Madras tour.
('24', 348, 3, 22, 801690) People began to tell me that they had not enough khadi to start with and that if khadi was available, they had no money.
('24', 348, 3, 23, 801811) If the labourers burn their foreign clothing where are they to get khadi from? That stuck into my heart.
('24', 348, 3, 24, 801916) I felt there was truth in the argument.
('24', 348, 3, 25, 801956) The plea for the poor overpowered me.
('24', 348, 3, 26, 801994) I expressed grief to Maulana Azad Sobhani, Mr. Rajagopalachariar, Doctor Rajan and others, and proposed that I

('24', 349, 1, 2, 802268) should thenceforth go about with a loin cloth.
