('24', 353, 1, 2, 811321) 181. DHARMA OR ADHARMA?
('24', 353, 2, 3, 811345) I invariably start and prick up my ears when, at times, even well wishers or others who believe in non co operation come out with difficult questions and tell of their bitter experience.
('24', 353, 2, 4, 811532) What follows is the gist of a letter from a friend who has been moved to write out of love.
('24', 353, 2, 5, 811624) He has the countrys good at heart, and is no coward.
('24', 353, 2, 6, 811677) Dharma is dear to him, while his experience of human nature is considerable.
('24', 353, 2, 7, 811754) I give here in my own words the substance of his letter as far as I can recollect it.
('24', 353, 2, 8, 811840) While no one questions your intentions and your means too are clean, would you say that what you advocated with regard to students was altogether wise?
('24', 353, 2, 9, 811992) Is it possible to be certain that your action will not have unhappy results?
('24', 353, 2, 10, 812069) To me at any rate these results are visible even today.
('24', 353, 2, 11, 812125) In trying to teach the spirit of freedom, we have lost domestic discipline.
('24', 353, 2, 12, 812201) Filial regard on the part of children seems to have disappeared.
('24', 353, 2, 13, 812266) What boots it to gain swaraj if domestic sanctities are to be its price ?
('24', 353, 2, 14, 812340) Is the spinning wheel the proper thing for a child ?
('24', 353, 2, 15, 812393) He may do as he pleases later in life.
('24', 353, 2, 16, 812432) If children disobey their parents, they cannot but lose their dharma.
('24', 353, 2, 17, 812502) It is understandable that you should have faith in your non co operators, but is it not likely that you are being deceived ?
('24', 353, 2, 18, 812627) Do you really believe that everyone is as sincere as you are ?
('24', 353, 2, 19, 812690) I for one see many around who are selfish, vain and hypocritical, I am sure you would not be happy to discover that you had lost the sincere men and retained only irrespossible people around you.
('24', 353, 2, 20, 812886) How I wish I could lend you my eyes to see that all that glitters is not gold!
('24', 353, 2, 21, 812965) It is in the hope that you may win in the end that I have voiced these misgivings and encroached upon your time.
('24', 353, 2, 22, 813078) The original letter is even more simply and politely written than I have been able to suggest.
('24', 353, 2, 23, 813173) Such letters, manifestly prompted by love, always make me wonder whether the ordinary restraints of civilized life are being violated.
('24', 353, 2, 24, 813308) Some children have possibly become rude.
('24', 353, 2, 25, 813349) But, then, if the Gita has been used to justify the throwing of bombs, why be surprised at misconstruction of my words?
('24', 353, 2, 26, 813469) I am sure, however, that the movement of leaving schools has had on the whole happy results.
('24', 353, 2, 27, 813562) The original idea was sound.
('24', 353, 2, 28, 813591) I am firmly of the view that it is a sin to attend schools
('24', 354, 0, 1, 813650) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 355
('24', 354, 1, 2, 813695) run by this Satanic Government.
('24', 354, 1, 3, 813727) Children under the age of 16 were not called upon to join this movement, while those above 16, surely, have the necessary discretion to decide for themselves.
('24', 354, 1, 4, 813886) But I always wonder if parents today have a proper under standing of their own duty.
('24', 354, 1, 5, 813971) What would be the duty of children whose parents are morally depraved?
('24', 354, 1, 6, 814042) When parents are dissolute and vice ridden, what is the right course for growing sons and daughters to follow?
('24', 354, 1, 7, 814153) What course should the children of slaves adopt ?
('24', 354, 1, 8, 814203) We should not be surprised if in these matters the consequence of too narrow an interpretation of domestic sanctities are unfortunate.
('24', 354, 1, 9, 814338) Should the children of parents subsisting on bribery agree to being supported with such riches or should they renounce them.
('24', 354, 1, 10, 814463) Simply because some Hindu parents may have forsaken their dharma, should the children follow suit?
('24', 354, 1, 11, 814562) We shall have, in this age, to set a limit to our filial devotion as much as we do to our loyalty to the State.
('24', 354, 1, 12, 814674) In a place where the king is dissolute and harasses his subjects, where he enjoys all luxuries and comforts at the expense of the people, where, instead of being a protector of his subjects he has become a parasite on themif loyalty to such a king is not a sin, then what is called virtue must be a sin.
('24', 354, 1, 13, 814978) In the past, devotion to a king meant devotion to a king like Rama, not to one like Ravana.
('24', 354, 1, 14, 815070) It is understandable that at the instance of Dasharatha Rama should readily take himself to the wild forest, but Prehlada accepting the gift of kingship from Hiranyakashipu would mean the eclipse of dharma.
('24', 354, 1, 15, 815277) You may swim in your fathers well but it does not mean you may also drown yourself in it.
('24', 354, 1, 16, 815367) At no stage of our struggle has the youth of the country been encouraged to adopt an attitude of licence.
('24', 354, 1, 17, 815473) Only those young men who were disciplined and could endure suffering were advised to leave Government schools and colleges even though they might be getting useful knowledge in them.
('24', 354, 1, 18, 815656) There are many who continue in schools to please their parents.
('24', 354, 1, 19, 815720) Only a few have left schools in defiance of their parents wishes, and of these, fewer still have subsequently taken to undisciplined ways.
('24', 354, 1, 20, 815859) There is in this world no dearth of men who in the name of conscience really gratify their selfish desires.
('24', 354, 1, 21, 815967) Such men will of course bring discredit to dharma, but should that stop us from so much as

('24', 355, 1, 2, 816100) talking about conscience?
('24', 355, 1, 3, 816126) I am absolutely certain that by placing the spinning wheel in childrens hands I have done the highest service to the country.
('24', 355, 1, 4, 816252) I look upon the spinning wheel movement as of lasting importance.
('24', 355, 1, 5, 816318) In concentrating on the training of childrens minds to the exclusion of everything else, we have done them a great wrong.
('24', 355, 1, 6, 816440) A considerable portion of our lives is taken up in trying to provide the bodys needs.
('24', 355, 1, 7, 816526) We have committed a great sin in neglecting education in the use of the means which help us to meet these needs.
('24', 355, 1, 8, 816639) The country will be happy only if this education is taken up again.
('24', 355, 1, 9, 816707) By using the spinning wheel as an instrument of vocational training, which in this case is our duty, we serve several purposes at the same time.
('24', 355, 1, 10, 816852) The second misgiving of our friend causes me concern.
('24', 355, 1, 11, 816906) Dharma would get a bad name and people would come to harm if this sacred struggle is vitiated by hypocrisy.
('24', 355, 1, 12, 817014) In that case people would fight shy of the very name of dharma or be content to accept orthodoxy as dharma.
('24', 355, 1, 13, 817122) Some undesirable elements must admittedly have found their way into our struggle, and I know that there are hypocrites who, under the cover of non co operation, are out to serve their selfish ends.
('24', 355, 1, 14, 817320) But I do not think that hypocrisy has taken possession of the movement Should that happen, our condition would be even worse than it is today because it would nurse our cowardice.
('24', 355, 1, 15, 817500) Hypocrisy flourishes only where there is fear.
('24', 355, 1, 16, 817547) The fear of the consequences of sin tempts the cowardly sinner to resort to a pretence of virtue and thus he becomes doubly a sinner.
('24', 355, 1, 17, 817681) In order to hide his godlessness, so that he may fill his belly, he makes a big show of piety and not only wastes sandalwood 1 but adds to his sins.
('24', 355, 1, 18, 817830) Whatever is humanly possible to keep such persons out of the struggle has, I feel, been done, and it is with this consideration that I have retained my freedom to act as I think best in the last resort.
('24', 355, 1, 19, 818033) The moment I see hypocrisy all round me, I shall unhesitatingly flee the struggle.
('24', 355, 1, 20, 818116) Hypocrites cannot be non co operators and it is the service of the latter I have accepted.

('24', 356, 1, 2, 818358) 182. MY NOTES
('24', 356, 2, 3, 818372) PEOPLE OF MADRAS
('24', 356, 3, 4, 818389) My tour of Madras was something of a disappointment.
('24', 356, 3, 5, 818442) I am a great admirer of the people of Madras.
('24', 356, 3, 6, 818488) Memories of the pleasant experience I had with them in South Africa are still fresh in my mind.
('24', 356, 3, 7, 818584) I have often seen their great capacity for suffering.
('24', 356, 3, 8, 818638) But in the matter of swadeshi Madras lags behind.
('24', 356, 3, 9, 818688) I see that their women remain the least touched by swadeshi.
('24', 356, 3, 10, 818749) And yet, an awakened Madras can do much.
('24', 356, 3, 11, 818790) In contrast to the smartness of the women in Madras, Gujarati women stand now where.
('24', 356, 3, 12, 818875) The former are highly intelligent.
('24', 356, 3, 13, 818910) No other Indian women are as deft with their hands.
('24', 356, 3, 14, 818962) Women there have the ingenuity to make the most worthless looking thing pay.
('24', 356, 3, 15, 819039) It is not that Madras is lacking in workers either.
('24', 356, 3, 16, 819091) Very few of our workers have the wisdom, the integrity and the ability of Shri Rajagopalachari.
('24', 356, 3, 17, 819187) He has fully understood the meaning of our struggle and, in a moment of crisis, he can be resolute and patient.
('24', 356, 3, 18, 819299) How is it, then, that Madras disappointed me?
('24', 356, 3, 19, 819345) I think there are two reasons for this.
('24', 356, 3, 20, 819385) In the first place, so deep has been the influence of the English language on the region that a person in Madras who knows English cares very little for Tamil.
('24', 356, 3, 21, 819545) The Bengali, too love English, but that has not made them give up Bengali.
('24', 356, 3, 22, 819620) In fact, hardly any other Indian language except perhaps Urdu has been able to produce the quality of literature that Bengali has, so well has it been cultivated.
('24', 356, 3, 23, 819783) Tamil in Madras has been as good as given up, with the result that not only has Tamil not prospered, but there is a wide gulf separating the English knowing section from the Tamil speaking class.
('24', 356, 3, 24, 819979) Shri Rajagopalachari and his colleagues are making every effort to bridge the gulf, but this will take some time.
('24', 356, 3, 25, 820093) The other important reason for my disappointment is that, their genuine regard for dharma notwithstanding, people in Madras have allowed blind religious orthodoxy to take such complete possession of them that mere outward forms of religion remain and the inner spirit has vanished.
('24', 356, 3, 26, 820375) The Antyajas in the region suffer more indignities than they do in almost any other part of the country.
('24', 356, 3, 27, 820480) The Brahmins are more sharply separated from the Non Brahmins than anywhere else.
('24', 356, 3, 28, 820562) And yet no other region makes such abundant use of sacred ash,
('24', 357, 0, 1, 820625) 358 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 357, 1, 2, 820667) sandalwood paste and vermilion powder.
('24', 357, 1, 3, 820706) No other part of the country has quite so many temples and is so generous in providing for their maintenance.
('24', 357, 1, 4, 820816) As a result of this, on the one hand the educated people are getting increasingly estranged from religion and becoming more cynical in consequence, and, on the other, total darkness and ignorance prevail among the orthodox.
('24', 357, 1, 5, 821040) In such a case, however, once the darkness has disappeared, light is not delayed.
('24', 357, 1, 6, 821122) As soon as the ordinary people are convinced of the darkness that is within them, it will vanish by itself.
('24', 357, 1, 7, 821230) That is why I see rays of hope even in the midst of gloom.
('24', 357, 1, 8, 821289) Congress workers tell me that, without any effort on their part, the people have taken up the spinning wheel.
('24', 357, 1, 9, 821399) Khadi is being produced even in places where they have done no work and thousands have started wearing khadi caps.
('24', 357, 1, 10, 821514) The majority of the Congress workers wear khadi exclusively.
('24', 357, 1, 11, 821575) If I am asked what conclusion I have reached from my experience in Madras, I would say that despite this experience, I have not given up hope of winning swaraj before the year is out.
('24', 357, 1, 12, 821759) He who fights from a sense of dharma never despairs.
('24', 357, 1, 13, 821812) If ones ends are clean and ones means are pure, one ought to be confident of success.
('24', 357, 1, 14, 821898) Only when such a person fails to achieve his end within the expected time will he say There must have been some error in my calculation, but I am sure of success along this path.
('24', 357, 2, 15, 822077) GUJARATIS IN MADRAS
('24', 357, 3, 16, 822097) Wherever I see Gujaratis I observe that they are bringing credit to Gujarat.
('24', 357, 3, 17, 822174) At every place they mix with the local population as much as they can.
('24', 357, 3, 18, 822245) They readily contribute what is expected of them and try to spread the message of non co operation to the best of their ability.
('24', 357, 3, 19, 822374) Everyone whom I ask has a good word for them.
('24', 357, 3, 20, 822420) They keep out of local politics.
('24', 357, 3, 21, 822453) The impression which I have thus formed of them is of a group giving priority to the claims of public service.
('24', 357, 3, 22, 822564) They have been sending money even from South and East Africa, and have been taking part in the struggles there.
('24', 357, 3, 23, 822676) I include among these Gujaratis Gujarati speaking Parsis and Muslims, for I notice that Gujarati Speaking Memons too have some work to their credit.
('24', 357, 3, 24, 822825) Wherever I come across an isolated Parsi here and there, I get an experience of their love for me.
('24', 357, 3, 25, 822924) I had such an experience even as far away as in the north east corner of Assam.
('24', 357, 3, 26, 823004) There was only one Parsi
('24', 358, 0, 1, 823029) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 359
('24', 358, 1, 2, 823074) there, but he did not hesitate to show, as well as he could, his sympathy for the cause of non co operation.

('24', 358, 2, 4, 823220) 183. DRAFT OF A MANIFESTO
('24', 358, 3, 5, 823246) October 4, 1921 We, the undersigned, consider that the communique of the Government of Bombay, dated regarding the Ali Brothers and others has laid down principles which are subversive of all freedom of expression of opinion, and we desire to state that it is the inherent right of everyone to express his opinion without restraint about the propriety of citizens offering their services to the Government whether in the civil or the military department.
('24', 358, 3, 6, 823701) We, the undersigned, state it as our opinion that it is not only contrary to the Muslim religion as declared by their Ulemas but also contrary to national dignity for any Indian to serve as a civilian and more especially as a soldier, under a system of Government which has brought about Indias economic, moral and political degradation and which has used the soldiery and the police for repressing national aspirations, as for instance at the time of the Rowlatt Act agitation, and which has used the soldiers for crushing the liberty of the Arabs, the Egyptians and the Turks who have done no harm to India.
('24', 358, 3, 7, 824311) We are also of opinion that it is the duty of every Indian soldier and civilian forthwith to resign his post and find out some honourable means to support himself.
('24', 358, 3, 8, 824475) And with that end in view we suggest to everyone in Government employ to learn hand spinning and hand weaving, which whilst advancing the national cause would enable them to earn an honest and an honourable living.
('24', 358, 3, 9, 824690) We urge the country in general to finish the boycott foreign cloth and take to hand spinning and hand weaving and stimulate manufacture of khaddar by such means.
('24', 358, 3, 10, 824852) A complete boycott of foreign cloth and manufacture by hand spinning and hand weaving will enable everyone to earn his or her living without falling back upon Government employment, and enable the Congress to call out both soldiers and civilians and even to
('24', 359, 0, 1, 825110) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 359, 1, 2, 825152) take up mass civil disobedience.
('24', 359, 2, 3, 825185) From a photostat: S.N. 7633
('24', 359, 3, 4, 825213) 184. A MANIFESTO
('24', 359, 4, 5, 825230) [BOMBAY, 6.50 p.m., October 4, l921] 2
('24', 359, 5, 6, 825269) In view of the prosecution of the Ali Brothers and others for the reasons stated in the Government of Bombay communique dated the 15th September 1921, we, the undersigned, speaking in our individual capacity, desire to state that it is the inherent right of everyone to express his opinion without restraint about the propriety of citizens offering their services to, or remaining in the employ of, the Government, whether in the civil or the military department.
('24', 359, 5, 7, 825733) We, the undersigned, state it as our opinion, that it is contrary to national dignity for any Indian to serve as a civilian, and more especially as a soldier, under a system of Government, which has brought about Indias economic, moral and political degradation and which has used the soldiery and the police for repressing national aspirations, as, for instance, at the time of the Rowlatt Act agitation, and which has used the soldiers for crushing the liberty of the Arabs, the Egyptians, the Turks and other nations who have done no harm to India.
('24', 359, 5, 8, 826285) We are also of opinion, that it is the duty of every Indian soldier and civilian to sever his connection with the Government and find some other means of livelihood.

('24', 360, 19, 20, 827721) 185. LETTER TO THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE
('24', 360, 20, 21, 827757) [Before October 5, 1921] THE EDITOR OF THE [BOMBAY] CHRONICLE
('24', 360, 21, 22, 827819) SIR, Persistent rumours supposed to be well founded were brought to me in Madras and have been repeated with greater emphasis in Bombay that my arrest is imminent.
('24', 360, 21, 23, 827983) If the rumour is well founded the Government will certainly deserve congratulations for consistency after the arrest of the Ali Brothers and their co prisoners, for, now the battle is being waged not against violence, so called or real, or incitement thereto, but against the very principle of non co operation for which the Congress and the Khilafat Committees stand, and that principle is promoting disaffection against the established Govern 
('24', 361, 0, 1, 828429) 362 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 361, 1, 2, 828471) ment and promoting non co operation with the Government by all classes, including civilians and soldiers.
('24', 361, 1, 3, 828577) The success of that propaganda, it is obvious, means the dissolution of the existing system of Government and it would be unbecoming for those who are avowed non co operators to question any steps that the Government may take in order to crush the movement, and I cannot conceive a more logical step than to arrest the author of the movement, unless the administrators of the system intend to change it in accordance with the wishes of the non co operators.
('24', 361, 1, 4, 829035) The country has shown by its dignified calm attitude after the arrests of the Ali Brothers and others, that it has realized the necessity of non violence.
('24', 361, 1, 5, 829190) I expect the retention of the same non violent atmosphere after my arrest or that of any other worker.
('24', 361, 1, 6, 829293) The people will show their true courage and appreciation of non violence and of imprisonments for the sake of ones religion and ones country as an honour to be prized not only by remaining absolutely peaceful but by refraining from hartals or any such demonstration.
('24', 361, 1, 7, 829560) Any hartal following the arrest of myself or any other worker would be a breach of discipline, and, therefore, no mark of respect or affection for the arrested worker.
('24', 361, 1, 8, 829728) The only way to show ones regard is to demonstrate greater zeal in prosecuting the Congress programme of swadeshi and hasten the advent of swaraj thereby.
('24', 361, 1, 9, 829883) I would certainly expect, in the event of my arrest, every man and woman in India who believes in the message of swadeshi, but through laziness or weakness has not yet discarded foreign cloth and taken to hand spinning and hand weaving, to discard all foreign cloth and take up the spinning wheel and the handloom.
('24', 361, 1, 10, 830198) I would expect the Hindus on no account to relax their efforts for the Khilafat or barter it away for so called swaraj, for swaraj, without the conciliation of the Mussulmans, is, in my opinion, an inconceivable thing.
('24', 361, 2, 11, 830417) Yours etc.,
('24', 361, 3, 12, 830429) M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 5 10 1921
('24', 362, 0, 1, 830474) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 363
('24', 362, 1, 2, 830519) 186. MESSAGE TO WORKERS, CEDED DISTRICTS
('24', 362, 2, 3, 830560) October 5, 1921
('24', 362, 3, 4, 830576) Mr. Harisarvothama Rao wires from Bombay under date October 5:
('24', 362, 4, 5, 830639) Mahatma Gandhi permits the sending of the following message to the Ceded Districts workers: Concentrate attention on swadeshi, boycott, completely maintain perfect silence at meetings, avoid demonstration of all description as the first essential discipline of deliberate peaceful action.
('24', 362, 4, 6, 830928) Teach volunteers to down sticks and stand to duty.
('24', 362, 4, 7, 830979) I request all to meet at Tadpatri on the 14th instant.
('24', 362, 4, 8, 831034) The Hindu, 6 10 1921
('24', 362, 5, 9, 831055) 187. NOTES
('24', 362, 6, 10, 831066) FAMINE RELIEF
('24', 362, 7, 11, 831080) The visit to the Ceded Districts brought abundant proof of the spinning wheel being the greatest insurance against famine, and being also the best measure of relief.
('24', 362, 7, 12, 831246) There is a severe famine raging in some parts of these Districts.
('24', 362, 7, 13, 831312) One of the workers told me that a woman not being able to support herself and her children had drowned herself and her children.
('24', 362, 7, 14, 831441) It is not possible to give doles of charity to hundreds of thousand of men.
('24', 362, 7, 15, 831517) And men who live on charity lose all sense of self respect.
('24', 362, 7, 16, 831577) It is not as if there is no corn to be had in the affected area.
('24', 362, 7, 17, 831642) People have no work and no money.
('24', 362, 7, 18, 831676) The Governments relief works consist in breaking and carrying stones.
('24', 362, 7, 19, 831746) A friend remarked that the Government had roads torn down and repaired in order to find work for the men and women in distress.
('24', 362, 7, 20, 831874) Whether roads are torn down or not, road repair is the only relief work the Government provides.
('24', 362, 7, 21, 831971) I understood, that the actual wage that found its way into a womans hands was an anna or five pice, and not more than ten pice into a mans hands.
('24', 362, 7, 22, 832117) I saw on the other hand, that a Congress Committee was paying three annas per day to Panchama women working at the spinning wheel for eight hours a day.
('24', 362, 7, 23, 832270) And what is being done for the Panchama women can be done for thousands of famine stricken women and for that matter men.
('24', 362, 7, 24, 832392) In these Districts three annas a day, even for men, is a veritable boon.

('24', 381, 1, 2, 876690) 192. MY NOTES
('24', 381, 2, 3, 876704) EAST AFRICA
('24', 381, 3, 4, 876716) We read reports in our newspapers about the plight of Indians in East Africa and friends over there also keep me informed about things.
('24', 381, 3, 5, 876852) 1 But I rarely refer to the matter in Navajivan or Young India.
('24', 381, 3, 6, 876916) I hope this will not be taken to imply that I am not aware of their plight or that there is a falling off in my sympathy for them.
('24', 381, 3, 7, 877047) I am in the position of a person who, attacked with swords from all sides, ignores pinpricks.
('24', 381, 3, 8, 877141) The pathetic condition of Indias economic, political and religious life pains me so deeply that by comparison all other misfortunes seem of no account to me.
('24', 381, 3, 9, 877299) It is also clear to me that the solution of East Africas problem will have to wait till Indias problem is solved.
('24', 381, 3, 10, 877413) When the well is full, water is bound to flow into the trough; in the same way, once Indias ills are cured those of the Indians in East Africa are bound to be.
('24', 381, 3, 11, 877573) If we were not busy applying effective remedies for Indias malady, all of us would have instantly combined to take up the East Africa problem.
('24', 381, 3, 12, 877716) This is not to suggest that Indians in East Africa should not make any efforts on their own.
('24', 381, 3, 13, 877809) That they must do.
('24', 381, 3, 14, 877828) All that I mean is that they will get, and have been getting, real help from India not on their specific account but as part of the struggle to cure Indias ills.
('24', 381, 3, 15, 877990) Indias strength, they realize, has grown so much that it is a constant help to them.
('24', 381, 3, 16, 878075) Their own strength, too, has increased.
('24', 381, 3, 17, 878115) The whites in East Africa have crossed the bounds of defency and seem determined to disregard all canons of English law.
('24', 381, 3, 18, 878236) This is uncivil disobedience of law.
('24', 381, 3, 19, 878273) When disobedience of law is for selfish ends, it is not civil disobedience.
('24', 381, 3, 20, 878349) The whites sought General Smuts help in their attempt, but have received none from that quarter.
('24', 381, 3, 21, 878446) I am confident that Indians in East Africa will come to no harm, provided they display courage, keep within the bounds of civility and propriety and remain truthful.
('24', 381, 3, 22, 878612) An untruthful man is always a coward.
('24', 381, 3, 23, 878650) The intentions of the British in East Africa are evil and, therefore, if the Indians scrupulously keep on the path of truth, the insolence of wickedness in the British will remain curbed.
('24', 381, 3, 24, 878838) Keeping on the path of

('24', 382, 1, 2, 879076) truth means that Indians should see that their case is strong, that it is not overstated and should overcome their own failings.
('24', 382, 1, 3, 879205) One charge which as always levelled against us, and which is justified, is that we do not know what is cleanliness, that even when we are reasonably well off, our homes are dirty, that we make things dirty everywhere and huddle together.

('24', 398, 1, 10, 916396) The place in which such sacrifices are made can be no temple, and a Hindu can never think of visiting it.
('24', 398, 1, 11, 916502) Mother Kali demands no animal sacrifices.
('24', 398, 1, 12, 916544) If anything, she wants us to sacrifice ourselves.
('24', 398, 1, 13, 916594) It is only by slaying our Sins, our evil, that we can make ourselves fit to stand before her.
('24', 398, 1, 14, 916688) To those Hindus who desire to offer a sacrifice on the eighth day, I suggest that they should, dressed in hand spun khadi, take a pledge to follow truth, practise non violence and strive to subjugate the body.
('24', 398, 1, 15, 916898) Anyone who does so will certainly be offering the purest sacrifice and such a person will also have become fit for swaraj.
('24', 398, 1, 16, 917021) I, therefore, hope that, should the priest be obstinate and stick to his intention to kill a goat, no Hindu will visit the temple and be a party to the sin of offering the sacrifice and thus blaspheme against God.
('24', 398, 1, 17, 917235) Saturday, Aso Sud 7 [October 8, 1921] [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 9 10 1921
('24', 398, 2, 18, 917310) 200. SPEECH ON WORKING COMMITTEE RESOLUTION, BOMBAY
('24', 398, 3, 19, 917362) October 9, 1921
('24', 398, 4, 20, 917378) Mrs. Naidu presided at the meeting and Mahatma Gandhi moved the resolution before the meeting, supported by the various leaders like Lala Lajpat Rai, Maulana Azad Sobhani, Babu Rajendra Lal, etc.
('24', 398, 4, 21, 917574) After the resolution, which was similar to that of the Karachi Resolution, was passed all standing, the Mahatma lighted the heap of foreign clothing and it burned on merrily amidst the loud noise of crackers and bursting flames.
('24', 399, 0, 1, 917803) 400 THE COLLECTTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 399, 1, 2, 917846) Mahatma Gandhi moved: This meeting of the citizens of Bombay re affirms the following resolution of the Working Committee held in Bombay on the 5th instant:
('24', 399, 2, 3, 918003) The Working Committee congratulates the Ali Brothers and their comrades upon their prosecution and having considered the Resolution of the Khilafat Conference held at Karachi, regarding Military Service under the Government, the Working Committee is of opinion that the Resolution virtually reaffirms the principle laid down by the Congress at its special session in Calcutta, and its ordinary session in Nagpur last year, that it is contrary to national dignity and national interest for any Indian to engage or remain in the service of a Government in any capacity what so ever, a Government that has used the soldiers for the purposes of crushing the national spirit of the Egyptians, the Turks, the Arabs and other nations.
('24', 399, 2, 4, 918731) The Working Committee has been only deterred from calling out the soldiers and the civilians in the name of the Congress because the Congress is not yet ready to support these Government servants who may leave Government service and who may not be able themselves to find means of livelihood.
('24', 399, 2, 5, 919024) The Working Committee, however, is of opinion that in pursuance of the spirit of the Congress Resolution on non co operation it is the clear duty of every Government employee, whether soldier or civilian, who can support himself without Congress assistance to leave such service.
('24', 399, 3, 6, 919304) The Working Committee draws the attention of all Indian soldiers and police to the fact that carding and hand spinning and hand weaving afford them, by undergoing training for a brief period, an honourable means for independent livelihood.
('24', 399, 3, 7, 919544) The Working Committee is further of opinion that the reasons given for the prosecution with reference to the said Karachi Resolution constitute an undue interference with religious liberty.
('24', 399, 4, 8, 919734) In proposing the resolution Mahatma Gandhi said it divided itself into two parts.
('24', 399, 4, 9, 919816) The first part dealt with the Karachi Resolution and was intended to be its confirmation from the national standpoint, And if it was a crime in the Ali Brothers and their fellow prisoners to have supported the Resolution, it was a crime for the speaker and the audience to propose and pass the resolution.
('24', 399, 4, 10, 920122) He considered it their duty to state their position clearly.
('24', 399, 4, 11, 920183) It was their duty to inform the sepoy that it was wrong to help a Government which had forfeited the confidence of the country.
('24', 399, 4, 12, 920311) The speaker was informed that the resolution was said to be worded cleverly after the fashion of a lawyer so as to avoid the clutches of the law.
('24', 399, 4, 13, 920457) It was said that, like the Khilafat Resolution, the present one did not require everyone to tell the sepoy to lay down arms.
('24', 399, 4, 14, 920582) He differed from that view.
('24', 399, 4, 15, 920610) He was of opinion that by the resolution everyone endorsing it told the sepoy that it was his duty to give up service if only he
('24', 400, 0, 1, 920739) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 401
('24', 400, 1, 2, 920784) could support himself otherwise.
('24', 400, 1, 3, 920817) If his voice could reach the sepoy he certainly told him that if he believed in his faith whether he was a Hindu or a Mussulman or believed in his own country, he should leave the service even if he had to earn his livelihood by breaking stones.
('24', 400, 1, 4, 921063) One who wanted to be a soldier of India could not be a sepoy of a Government which has served against India.
('24', 400, 1, 5, 921172) Those who murdered the innocent men of Jallianwala were no soldiers; they were mere animals.
('24', 400, 1, 6, 921265) Those who ran no risks, but only killed were again no soldiers but animals.
('24', 400, 1, 7, 921341) He had, therefore, no hesitation in telling the sepoy through the audience that he should lose no time in severing his connection with the Government if he cared for his country and religion.
('24', 400, 2, 8, 921533) One thing the resolution did not require the people to do namely to carry on secret propaganda.
('24', 400, 2, 9, 921629) They had ruled out secrecy from their book of non co operation.
('24', 400, 2, 10, 921693) They were ashamed to say in secret what they were not prepared to say in public.
('24', 400, 2, 11, 921774) If therefore the Government held it a crime to recite the creed of non co operation, he invited them to arrest those who took part in the evenings proceedings.
('24', 400, 2, 12, 921934) If it was a crime to tell the soldier that it was unlawful for him to serve the Government in terms of his religion and nationalism, he (the speaker ) invited Government to arrest him and those who supported and carried the resolution.
('24', 400, 3, 13, 922170) The other part of the resolution pointed out to the soldier the way to an honourable livelihood.
('24', 400, 3, 14, 922267) It referred to swadeshi.
('24', 400, 3, 15, 922292) He asked the audience not to carry that resolution if they did not believe in swadeshi and the power of the spinning wheel to banish poverty from the land.
('24', 400, 3, 16, 922448) The resolution told the soldier that he could earn his living by carding and weaving.
('24', 400, 3, 17, 922534) He verily believed with Maulana Mahomed Ali that they did not need lead and gunpowder.
('24', 400, 3, 18, 922621) Yarn balls were their lead and the spinning wheel was their gun.
('24', 400, 3, 19, 922686) He said last September that it was possible to gain swaraj, to redress the Khilafat and the Punjab wrongs during the twelve months following if they fulfilled certain conditions.
('24', 400, 3, 20, 922865) Twelve months had passed but there was no swaraj.
('24', 400, 3, 21, 922915) The fault was theirs.
('24', 400, 3, 22, 922937) They had done much but had not fulfilled the minimum required.
('24', 400, 3, 23, 923000) He wished to share the blame.
('24', 400, 4, 24, 923030) He was sorry that he had not the power of convincing every lawyer that it was wrong to practise before the courts which gave no justice.
('24', 400, 4, 25, 923167) He was sorry that his tapasya was not enough to carry conviction to every student that it was wrong to
('24', 400, 5, 26, 923270) belong to Government schools.
('24', 400, 5, 27, 923300) He knew that he had not been able to convince every man and woman of Bombay that it was sinful to wear anything but khaddar.

('24', 402, 2, 4, 927196) 201. SPEECH TO WOMEN, BOMBAY
('24', 402, 3, 5, 927225) October 9, 1921
('24', 402, 4, 6, 927241) Under the auspices of the Rashtriya Stree Sabha a public meeting of women was held on Sunday afternoon at the Marwari Vidyalaya Hall, when Mahatma Gandhi, Lala Lajpat Rai and others spoke on The Present Situation.
('24', 402, 4, 7, 927455) The meeting was for ladies dressed in khaddar and swadeshi clothes alone Mrs. Naidu presided.
('24', 402, 5, 8, 927549) Mahatma Gandhi said before him were sitting Hindu, Mohammedan and Parsi women.
('24', 402, 5, 9, 927628) They had come there, knowing well that they had to attend in khaddar dress only.
('24', 402, 5, 10, 927709) He personally had come there not to tell them anything new, but to give them an account of the countrys doings.
('24', 402, 5, 11, 927821) By becoming members of the Congress they had shown their willingness to follow its mandates, come what might.
('24', 402, 5, 12, 927931) They knew that eight of their countrys leader had been arrested in Karachi for passing certain resolutions and he wanted the meeting to pass those very resolutions and to go to jail if necessary.
('24', 402, 5, 13, 928127) They should not think that because they were women they would not; that was wrong.
('24', 402, 5, 14, 928210) They must know that the Government would do anything to gain their object.
('24', 402, 5, 15, 928285) They knew from what had happened in South Africa that the Government were not willing to leave their women free.
('24', 402, 5, 16, 928398) Lala Lajpat Rai had asked them to steel their hearts so that they should not shed a single tear when their nearest and dearest were arrested.
('24', 402, 5, 17, 928540) They had to Follow the example of the mother of the Ali Brothers and Maulana Mahomed Alis wife.
('24', 402, 5, 18, 928636) Although none of their religions taught them to weep for the dead, still they did weep are mourn for their dead relations.
('24', 402, 5, 19, 928759) That was wrong.
('24', 402, 5, 20, 928775) They should not mourn to those who were sent to Jail, because they knew that they were fighting for dharma raj, for swaraj.
('24', 402, 5, 21, 928899) The swaraj he wanted to establish was dharma raj, it was Rama raj.
('24', 402, 5, 22, 928966) So long as a single Indian was starved to death, whatever rights the might get in the parliament, real swaraj was not theirs; so long a there was godlessness in the country, what was the use of getting rights and votes.
('24', 402, 5, 23, 929186) He wanted dharma raj, a raj based on all that was good and virtuous.
('24', 402, 5, 24, 929255) They would get that only when they were resolved upon getting it.
('24', 402, 5, 25, 929321) Lalaji had already told them that they should not shed a single tear ever if their leaders were hung by their necks by their Government.
('24', 402, 5, 26, 929458) He hoped that the women would do that and never forsake their dharma.
('24', 402, 6, 27, 929528) Coming to the question of swadeshi, Mahatma Gandhi said he saw before him many women who were not wearing even swadeshi clothes; some of the were wearing mill made clothes.
('24', 402, 6, 28, 929701) He asked them whether they had empty their boxes of all their foreign clothes.
('24', 402, 6, 29, 929780) They must also remember that mill made clothing was for the poorest of the poor and not for the well to do likethose present
('24', 403, 0, 1, 929905) 404 THE COLLECTTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 403, 1, 2, 929948) They must only wear those clothes which they had made with their own hands.
('24', 403, 1, 3, 930024) Formerly people were known by the dress they wore and a mans worth was assessed by his clothes.
('24', 403, 1, 4, 930120) That mentality they should change in these days.
('24', 403, 1, 5, 930169) He had been to see a village called Dattamandal in the Nizams dominions and he saw there people starving for the last four years on account of famine.
('24', 403, 1, 6, 930320) Those men and women had no work to do and they were slowly dying, starving.
('24', 403, 1, 7, 930396) If he but told the audience what he had seen in that place they would cry for mere shame.
('24', 403, 1, 8, 930486) People were dying uncared for.
('24', 403, 1, 9, 930517) He regretted much that although he had been preaching to them swadeshi for the last one year not much progress was done.
('24', 403, 1, 10, 930638) He had seen in this country men, women and children dying of hungermere bags of bones, mere skeletons because they had no work to do.
('24', 403, 1, 11, 930772) They were ready to do any work, but they were unable to do it for there was none for them.
('24', 403, 1, 12, 930863) Sometimes, Government was employing them to break stones on the road sides.
('24', 403, 1, 13, 930939) Seeing all these things, how could Indians, men and women, clothe themselves in fineries?
('24', 403, 1, 14, 931029) If they wanted to abolish poverty from this land, and abolish nakedness, then they must use the charkha.
('24', 403, 1, 15, 931134) Crores of their people would then be able to get their living by keeping their self respect.
('24', 403, 1, 16, 931227) If Indians would accomplish this, swaraj was theirs.
('24', 403, 1, 17, 931280) Indians had no right to waste their money in luxuries and also waste their time.
('24', 403, 1, 18, 931361) Whatever they saved they must give to the poor.
('24', 403, 1, 19, 931409) God was to be found in the houses of the poor, of the Chandalas, of Dhed and of Bhangis and not in the
('24', 403, 2, 20, 931512) houses of the rich and the great.
('24', 403, 2, 21, 931546) He would only pray to God that if he should be born in this land he might be born a Dhed.
('24', 403, 2, 22, 931636) The boycott of courts, the boycott of schools,
('24', 403, 3, 23, 931683) the giving up of titles, boycotting of the councilsall those had not been done successfully and people had failed in their duty towards the country.
('24', 403, 3, 24, 931832) The time was for the women to act now.
('24', 403, 3, 25, 931871) They had to use the charkha with a view to get victory.
('24', 403, 3, 26, 931927) Without dharma they would never get swaraj, they would never be able to right the wrongs of the Punjab, and they would never get their Khilafat wrongs righted.

('24', 404, 1, 2, 932713) 202. SPEECH ON SWADESHI, SURAT 1
('24', 404, 2, 3, 932746) October 12, 1921
('24', 404, 3, 4, 932763) Mahatmaji addressed the audience for about half an hour and exhorted the people to concentrate their attention on swadeshi only.
('24', 404, 3, 5, 932892) He said he knew Surat and Surat knew him.
('24', 404, 3, 6, 932934) He had heard very good reports about Surat during his recent tour, and the sea of white caps before him was not surprising to him.
('24', 404, 3, 7, 933065) He was, however, pained to find his sisters of Surat yet not taking to khaddar.
('24', 404, 3, 8, 933145) If, he said, swaraj was to be established through Gujarat, and if Surat was to lead, much yet remained to be done within the short period of two months and a half.
('24', 404, 4, 9, 933309) Good work was no doubt done by Surat till then, but yet much remained to be done.
('24', 404, 4, 10, 933391) Swadeshi must permeate every particle of their blood.
('24', 404, 4, 11, 933445) It ought to be realized that it was a sin to touch foreign cloth.
('24', 404, 4, 12, 933511) Mahatmaji said he had explained and said all he had to say and explain up till then.
('24', 404, 4, 13, 933596) Swadeshi was the only work now to be done.
('24', 404, 4, 14, 933639) For perfect peace, for Hindu Muslim unity, for relief to the poor and the famine stricken, for the chastity of the women, there was but one thing, viz., the charkha.
('24', 404, 4, 15, 933805) Khaddar cap or a coat for the meeting only was not enough, though that was something.
('24', 404, 4, 16, 933891) He was now thinking of economizing his time and energy and instead of wasting words was going to employ himself whole heartedly in khaddar production only.
('24', 404, 4, 17, 934047) That would be a better service to the country.
('24', 404, 4, 18, 934094) He then explained why he adopted the present change in his dress and took only to the loin cloth.
('24', 404, 4, 19, 934192) He wanted to set an example, when so many of his own countrymen and women were going naked.
('24', 404, 4, 20, 934284) Hand spun and hand woven khaddar was the need of the hour, and if Surat alone did this no civil disobedience will have to be resorted to.
('24', 404, 4, 21, 934422) They should give up all processions and even meetings.
('24', 404, 4, 22, 934477) Time was to be spared for spinning and weaving.
('24', 404, 4, 23, 934525) That was more eloquent than his own speech.
('24', 404, 4, 24, 934569) He was going to set the example shortly.
('24', 404, 4, 25, 934610) His message to Surat was swadeshi and swadeshi alone.
('24', 404, 4, 26, 934664) Time though short was enough for the honest and determined persons.
('24', 404, 4, 27, 934732) This was a religious crusade and they could not cheat God.
('24', 404, 4, 28, 934791) To Hindus he especially pointed out the sin and curse of untouchability.
('24', 404, 4, 29, 934864) God would not forgive them if untouchability remained.
('24', 404, 4, 30, 934919) God hears these six crores of untouchables and he has consequently made their oppressors untouchables to the rest of the world.

('24', 405, 0, 1, 935136) 406 THE COLLECTTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 405, 1, 2, 935179) 203. NOTES
('24', 405, 2, 3, 935190) ALL ABOUT THE BROTHERS
('24', 405, 3, 4, 935213) It is the good fortune of the Brothers to have staunch friends.
('24', 405, 3, 5, 935277) It is equally their good fortune to have strong critics.
('24', 405, 3, 6, 935334) A friend writes to me that I am so infatuated with them that I refuse to see anything bad in them.
('24', 405, 3, 7, 935433) He is right.
('24', 405, 3, 8, 935446) It is the privilege of friendship not to be suspicious.
('24', 405, 3, 9, 935502) But he is a bad friend who does not know his friends weaknesses.
('24', 405, 3, 10, 935567) I know those of the Brothers, but having weaknesses myself I am tender towards theirs.
('24', 405, 3, 11, 935654) I feel that they are the best and the bravest among co workers with whom I have had the privilege of working.
('24', 405, 3, 12, 935764) So much for the general charge.
('24', 405, 4, 13, 935796) THEIR INCONSISTENCY
('24', 405, 5, 14, 935816) But here is a particular charge against them.
('24', 405, 5, 15, 935862) Says a crores pondent:
('24', 405, 6, 16, 935885) May I put before you the following problems, which I have even after a very long and deep deliberation been unable to reconcile with the non co operation doctrine.
('24', 405, 6, 17, 936049) Will you kindly say whether my difficulties are something real or only superficial?
('24', 405, 7, 18, 936133) Non co operation requires that no accused should give any help whatsoever to the proceedings in the British court in which he is tried.
('24', 405, 7, 19, 936269) But, is not the statement given by the Ali Brothers, a sort of help given to the court?
('24', 405, 7, 20, 936357) This the Crown Prosecutor himself made clear, when he said that his work was much lightened by the utterances of the accused.
('24', 405, 8, 21, 936483) The second problem which perplexes me is this.
('24', 405, 8, 22, 936530) We have not as yet launched on civil disobedience.
('24', 405, 8, 23, 936581) Hence we all must obey at present the orders of the British officials.
('24', 405, 8, 24, 936652) Even you did not infringe the order which prohibited you from entering Malabar.
('24', 405, 8, 25, 936732) If so, was it proper for Maulana Mahomed Ali to disobey the Magistrate of Karachi and lose temper with him, when he asked him to sit down?
('24', 405, 8, 26, 936871) Was this not an express breach of the Magistrates order?
('24', 405, 8, 27, 936928) Was it creditable to Maulana Mahomed Ali to ask the Magistrate whether he did not believe in God, and to decline to sit down when asked to do so and say, Let me see what you can do?
('24', 405, 9, 28, 937110) To my mind, even when civil disobedience is started, we all must be humble.

('24', 434, 4, 19, 1001768) The Shah merchant of Pals market brought over to the meeting his whole stock of foreign cloth and threw it into the fire.
('24', 434, 4, 20, 1001890) The charkha has not yet spread so much, but I am expecting better results now.

('24', 436, 1, 2, 1004923) A MAGISTRATES APOLOGY
('24', 436, 2, 3, 1004945) The reader will recollect the assault instigated by the District Magistrate of Bulandshahr upon Mr. Tyagi who was being tried in his court and who was therefore under his protection.
('24', 436, 2, 4, 1005128) 1 I have now before me the apology he tendered to the accused.
('24', 436, 2, 5, 1005191) Here it is.
('24', 436, 3, 6, 1005203) PRISONER AT THE BAR,
('24', 436, 4, 7, 1005224) Before todays proceedings go any further, I wish to say something.
('24', 436, 5, 8, 1005291) I do so for two reasons,the first, that I am trying you, and it is not right that you or anyone else should Suspect that you will not be tried fairly and in a proper manner.
('24', 436, 5, 9, 1005465) The second, that no officer of Government can wish that any incident should happen to give any section of the community reasonable grounds for resentment, especially as unscrupulous persons are ready to exaggerate such incidents.
('24', 436, 6, 10, 1005695) At the first hearing I was impatient and you were insolent.
('24', 436, 6, 11, 1005755) I did wrong in having you slapped; and I regret that I did so.
('24', 436, 7, 12, 1005818) I now tell you, that if you are respectful to the Court, you will find me courteous.
('24', 436, 7, 13, 1005903) If you do not behave properly, I shall find proper means of dealing with you.
('24', 436, 7, 14, 1005981) You will in any case be tried fairly andpatiently; and you will have a full opportunity at the proper stage to make any relevant remarks you have to offer.
('24', 436, 8, 15, 1006137) I may add that out of regard to the loyal members of your community who are doing good work in this District, if you are proved innocent of the offence of which you are accused in this or in any other court, I shall send 50/ to the Malabar Relief Fund.
('24', 436, 8, 16, 1006390) W. E. J. DOBBS
('24', 436, 9, 17, 1006405) It is evident to me that the apology was offered under pressure, even as Sir Michael ODwyer was made to apologize to the late Council for his offensive remarks.

('24', 437, 2, 15, 1008414) ACCUSEDS STATEMENT

('24', 437, 4, 17, 1008538) Vandemataram

('24', 437, 6, 19, 1008605) From Mahavir Tyagi accused under Sections 124 and 153 I.P. Code.
('24', 437, 7, 20, 1008670) I, Mahavir Tyagi, an innocent accused, am compelled to file the following statement: I want to say through this writing that as the said Magistrate, while proving his tyranny and incompetency on the 3rd instant, treated me in the open Court in a way which was calculated to insult and wound myself, my creed and my nationality, by forcing me to stand with attention, threatening to have me kicked by the Police and actually getting me slapped, an action on the part of the Magistrate which was absolutely illegal and barbarous, therefore in order to preserve my national, religious and personal honour and self respect, I have, as a protest, decided to take a vow of silence and make a speech strike in this Court which has set every law at naught.

('24', 439, 2, 14, 1013185) A RELEVANT QUESTION
('24', 439, 3, 15, 1013205) And just as we need the cool courage described above, we need perfect discipline and training in voluntary obedience to be able to offer civil disobedience.
('24', 439, 3, 16, 1013362) Civil disobedience is the active expression of non violence.
('24', 439, 3, 17, 1013423) Civil disobedience distinguishes the non violence of the strong from the passive, i.e., negative non violence of the weak.
('24', 439, 3, 18, 1013546) And as weakness cannot lead to swaraj, negative non violence must fail to achieve our purpose.
('24', 439, 3, 19, 1013641) Have we then the requisite discipline?
('24', 439, 3, 20, 1013680) Have we, a friend asked me, evolved the spirit of obedience to our own rules and resolutions ?
('24', 439, 3, 21, 1013775) Whilst we have made tremendous headway during the past twelve months, we have certainty not made enough to warrant us in embarking upon civil disobedience with easy confidence.
('24', 439, 3, 22, 1013952) Rules voluntarily passed by us and rules which carry no sanction save the disapproval of our own conscience must be like debts of honour held far more binding than rules superimposed upon us or rules whose breach we can purge by paying the penalty thereof.
('24', 439, 3, 23, 1014209) It follows that if we have not learnt the discipline of obeying our own rules, in other words carrying out our own promises, we are ill adapted for disobedience that can be at all described as civil.
('24', 439, 3, 24, 1014409) I do therefore
('24', 440, 0, 1, 1014424) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 441

('24', 443, 2, 5, 1021456) 216. HINDU MUSLIM UNITY A CAMOUFLAGE?
('24', 443, 3, 6, 1021494) The editorial notes in the current number of The Modern Review contain reflections on Hindu Muslim unity, which deserve a reply.
('24', 443, 3, 7, 1021623) The talented editor has headed them with the word camouflage and has evidently come to the conclusion that the unity is only so called.
('24', 443, 3, 8, 1021759) In my opinion, however, it is not only not a camouflage but is fast becoming a permanent reality.

('24', 456, 5, 15, 1053833) 221. OPTIMISM
('24', 456, 6, 16, 1053847) Optimism indicates faith; only an atheist can be a pessimist.
('24', 456, 6, 17, 1053909) The optimist lives in fear of God, listens with humility to the inner voice, obeys its promptings and believes that God ordains everything for the best.
('24', 456, 6, 18, 1054062) The pessimist vainly thinks that it is he who does everything.
('24', 456, 6, 19, 1054125) When he fails in some undertaking, he leaves himself out and blames others; indulges in vain prating about not being sure whether God exists and, finally, concluding that this world is worthless and he alone good, but that his merit is not recognized, puts an end to his life.
('24', 456, 6, 20, 1054402) If he does not do that, he merely endures an existence which is little better
('24', 457, 0, 1, 1054480) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 457, 1, 2, 1054522) than death.
('24', 457, 1, 3, 1054534) The optimist lives delighting in thoughts of love and charity and, since there is none whom he looks upon as his enemy, he moves without fear whether he is in the forest or in the midst of men.
('24', 457, 1, 4, 1054728) He has no fear of ferocious animals or equally dreadful men, for his soul cannot be bitten by snakes nor pierced by the sinners sword.
('24', 457, 1, 5, 1054863) Such a one will not give too much thought to his body, will rather look upon it as a fragile vessel of glass which is fated to break some day and will not go roaming all over the world to preserve it in health.
('24', 457, 1, 6, 1055074) The optimist will not kill or harass any human being.
('24', 457, 1, 7, 1055128) With his inner ear ever attuned to the sweet music of his soul, he will live floating on an ocean of joy.
('24', 457, 1, 8, 1055234) The pessimist, being himself a prey of violent attachments and dislikes, looks upon every person as his enemy and fears him.
('24', 457, 1, 9, 1055359) He has of course no such thing as the inner voice.

('24', 459, 1, 2, 1059381) 222. TO MILL WORKERS
('24', 459, 2, 3, 1059402) BROTHERS, Ever since my return to Ahmedabad at the end of my tour, I have been hearing that the drink habit has decreased among all sections of people but that the liquor booths which are frequented by mill workers continue to flourish, that, moreover, the customers there pay no heed to volunteers, actually abuse them and even beat them.
('24', 459, 2, 4, 1059742) I do not know what truth there is in this.
('24', 459, 2, 5, 1059785) I am sure that there are hundreds of workers who would not approve of such conduct.
('24', 459, 2, 6, 1059869) Those who are labouring in your cause have been doing so in the hope that you will reform yourselves and be happy, that you will give up your bad habits, learn to save money and pay off your debts, that you may have good houses to live in and your children may get education, that you will learn to be clean and, in your free time, will read good books and reflect over them, in every way, you should enjoy a good reputation in society.
('24', 459, 2, 7, 1060306) Those who are trying to help you will not be satisfied by merely getting a wage rise or some bonuses for you.
('24', 459, 2, 8, 1060416) If you accept their services only for securing an increase in wages and do not change your way of life, you will lose their services and public opinion, which today is on your side, will no longer be there.
('24', 459, 2, 9, 1060623) Not only should you become good, but you should also take part in the holy movement of self purification going on in the country today.
('24', 459, 2, 10, 1060759) You should understand and do your duty about the Khilafat and the Punjab agitations and in the movement for swaraj.
('24', 459, 2, 11, 1060875) If you wish to do so, you must give up your vices.

('24', 460, 1, 3, 1061722) You, readers, most likely do not drink; how, then, can you be held responsible for your co workers ?
('24', 460, 1, 4, 1061823) The answer to this question is that swaraj lies in accepting responsibility for ones associates.
('24', 460, 1, 5, 1061920) It is for you to win over other workers and shame them into reform.
('24', 460, 1, 6, 1061988) You should keep a watch on those of them who are drink addicts.
('24', 460, 1, 7, 1062052) Yours should be the burden of improving them.
('24', 460, 1, 8, 1062098) It is only when, in this manner, you bring about a daily improvement in your conditions, that you will have earned a wage rise, bonus and so on.
('24', 460, 1, 9, 1062243) You can easily see that public sympathy will not remain on your side for ever if you do not improve.
('24', 460, 1, 10, 1062344) I hope, therefore, that you will make every effort to rid yourselves of the evil of drinking.
('24', 460, 2, 11, 1062438) Your well wisher,

('24', 460, 5, 14, 1062535) CONDITIONS FOR VISITING
('24', 460, 6, 15, 1062559) I keep getting requests to visit various parts of Gujarat.
('24', 460, 6, 16, 1062618) It was suggested that I should go to Dakor and other places.
('24', 460, 6, 17, 1062679) I also received requests to visit Petlad and Sojitra.
('24', 460, 6, 18, 1062733) I have, however, begged to be excused, till the end of this month at any rate.
('24', 460, 6, 19, 1062812) I have then to go to Delhi.
('24', 460, 6, 20, 1062840) After returning from Delhi, I intend to go round a little in Gujarat.
('24', 460, 6, 21, 1062910) I have certainly not given up my hopes of Gujarat.
('24', 460, 6, 22, 1062961) I assuredly cherish the hope that Gujarat will make every sacrifice in this holy fight and, therefore, I expect that I shall be taken to such places only where men and women use khadi for all purposeson public holidays and important occasions, at home and outside.
('24', 460, 6, 23, 1063226) Everyone should see to it that my time is not wasted.
('24', 460, 6, 24, 1063280) Even if we have only one district well prepared, we shall be able to put up a strong fight and win.
('24', 460, 6, 25, 1063380) I shall be ready to encamp in such a district.
('24', 460, 6, 26, 1063427) For that, however, the following conditions must first be fulfilled: 1. Hindus and Muslims there should be living like blood brothers; not in fear of each other, but in loving harmony.
('24', 460, 6, 27, 1063612) 2. The Hindus, Muslims, and Parsis in the district, all should be convinced in their hearts that victory on the Khilafat issue with Indias
('24', 461, 0, 1, 1063751) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 461, 1, 2, 1063793) help is possible only through a peaceful struggle.
('24', 461, 1, 3, 1063844) 3. The people of that district should have realized that, together with the spirit of non violence, they need to have courage even to mount the gallows.
('24', 461, 1, 4, 1063997) At least one in a hundred must have such courage; that is, in a population of five lakhs, there should be not less than 5,000 such persons quietly determined to face death.
('24', 461, 1, 5, 1064170) 4. The Hindus of that district.
('24', 461, 1, 6, 1064202) should have I learnt to regard untouchability as a sin and to treat the Bhangis, Dheds and others with kindness.
('24', 461, 1, 7, 1064315) So much by way of action on the mental plane.

('24', 461, 1, 9, 1064744) It is not at all difficult to satisfy these conditions, and even one such district will be able to win swaraj.
('24', 461, 1, 10, 1064855) The whole of Gujarat prepared in this way, then, would undoubtedly win it.
('24', 461, 1, 11, 1064930) Similarly, if any district has one man in ten who is ready, if necessary to lay down his life for the cause, then, too, swaraj would be a certainty.

('24', 461, 1, 13, 1065147) We describe our struggle as one of truth and non violence.

('24', 462, 1, 2, 1066057) quality.

('24', 462, 1, 4, 1066227) The yarn so produced should be credited in our books to the countrys account.
('24', 462, 1, 5, 1066305) Children will of course want new things.

('24', 462, 1, 10, 1066834) Till hunger has disappeared, we simply cannot spend anything on crackers; but, in order to cleanse ourselves we could have on the Diwali day a pretty good bonfire of whatever foreign clothes still remain with us and enjoy the sight of our own garments in flames.
('24', 462, 1, 11, 1067097) A Jain correspondent, however, points out that innumerable insects perish in these bonfires and there is so much destruction of lifethe sight is simply unbearable.
('24', 462, 1, 12, 1067261) Would it not be better, he asks, to put away our garments of foreign cloth and lock them up?
('24', 462, 1, 13, 1067354) From the present Jain point of view, this is a relevant question.
('24', 462, 1, 14, 1067420) That the smallest insects are our kin, our brethren, and that it is our dharma, therefore, to have compassion on them,these are deathless words.
('24', 462, 1, 15, 1067565) But we cannot stop there.
('24', 462, 1, 16, 1067591) Despite their truth, we light ovens and cremate dead bodies.
('24', 462, 1, 17, 1067652) Creation as much as destruction is a form of violence.
('24', 462, 1, 18, 1067707) There is no destruction not followed by creation and no creation which is not preceded by destruction.
('24', 462, 1, 19, 1067810) We cannot escape paying for our own actions.
('24', 462, 1, 20, 1067855) If we admit that we must give up the use of foreign cloth, destroying it through fire does the least degree of violence.
('24', 462, 1, 21, 1067976) In a situation in which we are obliged to choose between two forms of violence, we can do no more than choose the lesser one.
('24', 462, 1, 22, 1068102) If the garments are locked away, white ants, etc., will get at them and the work of destruction and creation will proceed so rapidly that destruction through fire would have been a much lesser evil.
('24', 462, 1, 23, 1068301) There is less violence in at once killing a man than in letting him starve to death.
('24', 462, 1, 24, 1068386) This is why I have said that it is against the principles of our struggle to refuse to supply food and water to anyone living in our midst.
('24', 462, 1, 25, 1068526) For the present, however, I shall not go deeper into this question, for we can discuss it more fully when we have an
('24', 463, 0, 1, 1068643) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('24', 463, 1, 2, 1068685) opportunity some other time.
('24', 463, 1, 3, 1068714) Here, I shall only state my opinion that setting fire to garments of foreign cloth is, from every point of view, an act of lesser violence and is necessary for the good of India and hence for that of the world.
('24', 463, 1, 4, 1068925) But what can Diwali possibly mean to Muslims ?
('24', 463, 1, 5, 1068972) It is purely a Hindu festival.
('24', 463, 1, 6, 1069003) For this very reason I would suggest that Muslims too should associate themselves with it.
('24', 463, 1, 7, 1069094) The religious part of it will of course be for the Hindus only, but as it is for them a festival day, the Muslims too might join in and, to the extent that it can be used to serve the cause of the whole nation, they and all the other communities should join in celebrating the day.
('24', 463, 1, 8, 1069376) We should also offer our greetings to Muslims, Parsis and Christians on their respective New Year Days and join in any public celebrations they may have on those days.
('24', 463, 1, 9, 1069544) It is surely our duty to share one anothers joys and sorrows.
('24', 463, 1, 10, 1069606) I hope, therefore, that during this Diwali festival of the Hindus, all the other communities will join in the celebrations and help forward the cause of swadeshi in every possible way.
('24', 463, 2, 11, 1069791) MESSAGE OF SPINNING WHEEL IN THE GITA
('24', 463, 3, 12, 1069829) In last Sundays issue of the Navajivan, I tried to answer the Poets 1 arguments on the subject of the spinning wheel.
('24', 463, 3, 13, 1069947) I said in the course of my reply that personally I read the message of the spinning wheel even in the Gita.
('24', 463, 3, 14, 1070055) In support of my argument, I quoted some verses from Chapter III.
('24', 463, 3, 15, 1070121) I know full well that the meaning I have read into them will not be found in any of the commentaries on the book, interpreted literally.
('24', 463, 3, 16, 1070258) It is not recently that I have come to read the meaning which I do; I have read it, the commentaries notwithstanding, since 1909. The verse says that he is a thief who eats without performing yajna.
('24', 463, 3, 17, 1070457) If here we understand the meaning of yajna rightly, there will be no difficulty in accepting the interpretation I have put upon it.
('24', 463, 3, 18, 1070589) The straightforward meaning of the line, Yajna brings rain 2 can only be that, if man labours trees will grow and if trees grow they will attract rain.
('24', 463, 3, 19, 1070741) Physical work for the welfare of the people is the only true yajna.
('24', 463, 3, 20, 1070809) The yajna in which some living creature, or be it even fruit, is given as an offering is no true yajna.
('24', 463, 3, 21, 1070913) Agriculture is one such yajna for the welfare of all.
('24', 463, 3, 22, 1070967) The farmer
('24', 463, 4, 23, 1070978) 1 Rabindranath Tagore; the reference is to a Gujarati translation of Gandhijis article, The Great Sentinel, 13 10 1921. 2 Bhagavad Gita, III.
('24', 464, 0, 1, 1071120) VOL. 24 : 22 JULY, 1921 25 OCTOBER, 1921 465
('24', 464, 1, 2, 1071165) consumes only a part of the fruit of his labour; whether he means to or not, he toils chiefly for the people.
('24', 464, 1, 3, 1071275) Not everyone, however, can take up this work; it requires a strong body hardened by work in cold andheat.
('24', 464, 1, 4, 1071381) But everyone can operate the spinning wheel.
('24', 464, 1, 5, 1071426) Even a scientist like Dr. Ray has convincingly showed how a man, though he may not be able to support himself exclusively by the spinning wheel, may still help in meeting the peoples needs.
('24', 464, 1, 6, 1071616) Today, moreover, when the country is on the verge of ruin, the spinning wheel is the only means of saving it.
('24', 464, 1, 7, 1071726) Spinning, therefore, is a true yajna.
('24', 464, 1, 8, 1071764) He who does not conform to this universal wheel lives merely for the gratification of his own desires, lives his life, in other words, to no purpose. 1 At the present time, that universal wheel can mean for us only the spinning wheel.
('24', 464, 1, 9, 1071999) It is possible that, when the verse in question was written, the great poet and seer might not have had the spinning wheel in mind, but then poets write for all time and it is the perfection and beauty of a poem that it lends itself to meanings which its author never had in mind.
('24', 464, 1, 10, 1072280) As statements of principles, such lines are timeless.
('24', 464, 1, 11, 1072334) They yield rich fruit.
('24', 464, 1, 12, 1072357) It is my humble opinion that we have a right to pluck any number of beautiful fruits which may grow on the tree of such priceless and imperishable able poetry.
('24', 464, 1, 13, 1072517) Poet and menial, master and servant, mistress and maid, all must work for the common good.
('24', 464, 1, 14, 1072608) The millionaire may not work or ply the spinning wheel for himself, but he must for the sake of the country and the people; otherwise, in the words of the Gita, he lives his life to no purpose.

('24', 468, 3, 4, 1079830) JAWAHARLAL NEHRUS NOTE ON REPRESSION IN THE UNITED PROVINCES
('24', 468, 4, 5, 1079891) Repression in U.P. has on the whole not been of the flashy typethe arrest of prominent leaders, etc.but it has been very thorough and there are few who have not felt the force of it.
('24', 468, 4, 6, 1080074) It may be considered under three heads :
('24', 468, 5, 7, 1080115) 1. In its relation to the kisan movement,
('24', 468, 6, 8, 1080157) 2. The trial and conviction of young workers,
('24', 468, 7, 9, 1080203) 3. The use of Security Sections and Sec.
('24', 468, 7, 10, 1080244) 144. 1. THE KISAN MOVEMENT
('24', 468, 8, 11, 1080271) A very determined and persistent effort made by Government to kill this movement.
('24', 468, 8, 12, 1080353) Early in February, Ramchandra, Kedarnath and Deo Narain were arrested.
('24', 468, 8, 13, 1080424) There was no disturbance of any kind and Government was emboldened to take concerted action to crush the kisans.
('24', 468, 8, 14, 1080537) Columns of cavalry, artillery and infantry were marched through the principal districts and people were forced to supply rasad 1, etc., to the troops.
('24', 468, 8, 15, 1080688) In one place schoolboys were made to salute the European troops.
('24', 468, 8, 16, 1080753) In Rai Bareli and Fyzabad, large numbers of kisans were arrested ostensibly for the part they took in the looting in January.
('24', 468, 8, 17, 1080879) Most of these kisans were innocent and their sole offence was that they were panchas 2. Hundreds were kept in jail and then released without trial.
('24', 468, 8, 18, 1081027) Hundreds are still in jail awaiting trial.
('24', 468, 8, 19, 1081070) Some weeks ago there were nearly 700 kisans in the Fyzabad jail.
('24', 468, 8, 20, 1081135) They had been there for three months without trial.
('24', 468, 8, 21, 1081187) Prisoners who have been released say that the men in jail are given such bad food that cholera has broken out and they are dying in numbers.
('24', 468, 8, 22, 1081328) In Sultanpur and Pratapgadh districts there was no disturbance of any kind.
('24', 468, 8, 23, 1081404) But even here hundreds of panchas and sarpanchas 3 are in jail or have been made to give security.
('24', 468, 8, 24, 1081503) The usual offence charged against them is:
('24', 468, 9, 25, 1081546) Sometimes it is added that
('24', 468, 10, 26, 1081573) 5 There was some truth in these allegations in December last and in
('24', 468, 11, 27, 1081641) January.
('24', 468, 11, 28, 1081650) But since then, there has hardly been a single case of social boycott in these districts.
('24', 468, 11, 29, 1081740) False cases are started on these allegations and conviction almost invariably follows.
('24', 468, 11, 30, 1081827) Most of these cases are instituted by private parties at the instigation of the local police or zamindar.

('24', 469, 1, 8, 1082514) Our workers in these districts are harassed in a variety of ways.

('24', 469, 2, 14, 1083009) Six young student workers in Pratapgadh were sent to jail for distributing leaflets.
('24', 469, 2, 15, 1083094) They were asked to give security but they refused to do so.
('24', 469, 2, 16, 1083154) A similar case was started against six others at Sultanpur but it has been withdrawn.
('24', 469, 2, 17, 1083240) Two workers have been sentenced to 6 months rigorous imprisonment on a false charge of breaking the provisions of the Seditious Meetings Act.
('24', 469, 2, 18, 1083382) One of these was beaten and kicked by a policeman.
('24', 469, 2, 19, 1083433) It is difficult to give a proper idea of the hundred and one methods by which Government has tried to crush the kisans.

('24', 469, 4, 22, 1083755) In the other districts of the U.P. a similar attempt, but on a much smaller scale, has been made to put an end to the kisan movement.
('24', 469, 4, 23, 1083889) 2. CONVICTION OF WORKERS A considerable number of Congress and Khilafat workers have been proceeded against and sentenced.
('24', 469, 4, 24, 1084012) None of the leaders of the movement have so far been touched but many of their efficient lieutenants have gone.

('24', 469, 7, 29, 1084409) having made a speech in which, after enjoining non violence for the present, he said

('24', 470, 1, 2, 1084778) 3. SECURITY SECTIONS AND SEC.
('24', 470, 1, 3, 1084808) 144 There has been an extraordinarily wide use of the sections and there is hardly a prominent worker who has not been served with a notice under Sec.
('24', 470, 1, 4, 1084959) 144. Even Maulana Mahomed Ali has received such a notice.
('24', 470, 1, 5, 1085017) I have a list of over a hundred with me and this is very incomplete.
('24', 470, 1, 6, 1085086) 144 has also been used to proclaim whole districts and prohibit meetings there.
('24', 470, 1, 7, 1085166) It has been made to serve the purpose of the Seditious Meetings Act.
('24', 470, 1, 8, 1085235) In one case at least a notice under Sec.
('24', 470, 1, 9, 1085276) 144 ordered that no Khilafat receipts should be sold and the person concerned should not belong to any such organization.

('24', 470, 2, 12, 1085555) certain articles written therein.
